	<wp:term><wp:term_id>51</wp:term_id><wp:term_taxonomy>sp_events_cat</wp:term_taxonomy><wp:term_slug>blog-yourself-a-brand</wp:term_slug><wp:term_parent></wp:term_parent><wp:term_name><![CDATA[Blog Yourself a Brand]]></wp:term_name><wp:term_description><![CDATA[These days, a blog is one of quickest and most effective was to build a strong brand for you and your services or products. Avoid bloviating or treating the blogosphere as your own personal megaphone by figuring out what your brand is first. We’ll help you identify the “authentic” you that other people will be interested in hearing about. We’ll brainstorm blog topics, practice writing short and long posts, and show you tips on writing your blog so that search engines find you, categorize your posts and push you up in the page rankings so the rest of the world can find you.]]></wp:term_description></wp:term>

		<title>Signaling Thumbs Up © 2012 dmatt</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/great-writing-increases-social-signals/305px-rello_thumbs_up-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Jun 2012 23:52:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/305px-Rello_thumbs_up1.jpg</guid>

	<item>
		<title>stylized hashtag</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/understanding-twitter-hashtags/stylized-hashtag-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Oct 2012 16:43:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/stylized-hashtag1.png</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hashtags let you be creative.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Master the #hashtag and you’ve mastered one of Twitter’s most creative literary tools.]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4136</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-10-11 09:43:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-10-11 16:43:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<title>@reply to Margaret Atwood tweet</title>

	<item>
		<title>About</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/about/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Oct 2010 23:07:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http:/?page_id=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Our Philosophy</h1>

<strong>Great business writing matters. </strong>Write a well-reasoned and readable proposal, and it’s your turn to sign the contract. Write an informative, entertaining blog post, and start interacting with customers and communities.

Great business writing, like writing of any kind, starts with figuring out the main idea. What’s the best way to do that? Let go and write in a messy flow, without regard to rules. Once you have words on paper, it’s time to craft your draft for publication. Two Pens courses teach you how to get going, polish your work, and finish quickly.
<div>
<h2>Who We Are</h2>
<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1698" style="padding-right: 30px; float: left;" title="Emily Warn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/emily-leaves-1-small.jpg" alt="Emily Warn" width="200" height="300" /><strong>Emily Warn</strong>'s talents span two worlds—online and mobile technology, and writing, editing, and teaching. Her book <em>Shadow Architect</em> is the latest of her five published poetry collections. Her essays, poems, and reviews appear widely in such media as the <em>Seattle Times</em>, <em>Poetry</em>, <em>BookForum</em>, <em>Critical Mass</em>, <em>KUOW</em>, <em>The Writer's Almanac</em>, <em>Parabola</em>, <em>Seattle Weekly</em>, and <em>Poetry Daily</em>.

As a writer and editor she has worked in both the business and nonprofit worlds, having served as editor-in-chief of Microsoft.com and of poetryfoundation.org, and having written and edited a wide variety of marketing collateral, web copy, and social media content. Her experience as a writing teacher is equally broad. She recently taught creative writing as an associate professor at Lynchburg College, and is currently offering courses at Richard Hugo House and Mountain Lamp Retreat Center. She has also worked as a teacher at the Bush School, the North Cascades Institute, and Centrum, and has been a writer-in-residence for many state arts commissions and universities.

She earned a BA in English from Kalamazoo College and an MA in creative writing from the University of Washington, and was a Stegner Fellow at Stanford University. Her career in high technology has included managing high-profile sites for Microsoft (for seven years), directing an online initiative for the Poetry Foundation (for five years), and developing and managing websites for nonprofits.


<a href="mailto:emily@twopens.com">emily@twopens.com</a>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />


</div>
<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1698" style="padding-right: 30px; float: left;" title="Emily Warn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/cynthia-3-small.jpg" alt="Emily Warn" width="200" height="300" /><strong>Cynthia Hartwig</strong> Cynthia Hartwig has been writing from both sides of her brain since she started her advertising and marketing communications agency, Sharp Hartwig, in 1979. Her nontraditional approach to online and offline communications has garnered some of the highest honors in the industry, including Clios, Echos, Obies, and John Caples awards, as well as awards from <em>Communication Arts</em>, the One Show, and the Art Directors Club of New York. Her film work has been honored with a Best-of-Show and a Gold Medal at the International Film and Television Festival of New York.

During the past 30 years she has taught at the University of Washington School of Communications, Western Washington University, and Seattle’s School of Visual Concepts. She inspires students with hands-on exercises that get them writing often and well; her highest compliment came from a student who said, “You helped me conquer my fear of the blank page.”

Cynthia is an accomplished short story writer. Francis Ford Coppola published her first story in <em>Zoetrope All-Story</em>; her stories have also been recognized by <em>Writer’s Digest</em>, Humboldt State University, and Manhattanville College of New York, among others. She is at work on a novel set in a roadside serpentarium.

Check out <a href="https://www.vizify.com/cynthia-hartwig" title="what Cynthia looks like graphically">what Cynthia looks like graphically</a> with Vizify, the new graphic bio service. 

<a href="mailto:cynthia@twopens.com">cynthia@twopens.com</a>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

</div>
</div>
<div style="clear: both;">

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
</div>
<div style="clear: both;">

	<li>Washington Traffic Commission</li>
</ul>

	<li>Seattle Art Museum</li>

	<item>
		<title>Creative Services</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/creative-services/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Oct 2010 21:17:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=8</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Creative Services</h1>
What matters most in your organization’s boardroom—a strategy spiffed up in Power Point for executives or board members, or the creative content that achieved its goals? If you answered both, you’re probably right. But more often than not, the content side of the equation gets short shrift, and the marketing strategy limps along.

Two Pens helps you craft a winning strategy and content that makes it happen. Our consultants are seasoned. We’ve built award-winning websites and advertising campaigns. Our team of social media writers and social media community managers supply the talent you need to tap the power of social networks.

<h2>In-House Training</h2>
 
Two Pens frequently presents on-site writing seminars to corporations and small businesses as well as not-for-profit organizations and foundations. We like to meet with you before we schedule a training so that we can better understand the problems or issues you’d like us to address. We’ll come back to you with a proposal for a workshop that’s tailored to your industry and your people.

We typically book half-day or full-day sessions, but can teach shorter, multiple-day sessions if you are in the Seattle-Tacoma area. 

Seminar prices are based on the number of people attending. We prefer to limit class size to 15 so that everyone receives personal attention. Travel and expenses are billed net; 50% of the seminar fee is due two weeks prior to the event. 

All topics related to writing from both sides of the brain are fair game for in-house seminars. Large corporations consistently book classes on Effective Email Writing and The PowerPoint Make-Over. How to Write a Creative Brief is popular with in-house creative groups. And small business owners often ask for Branding 101 and Attracting a Social Media Following. We can provide you with a full list of possible classes. Just email cynthia@twopens.com and we’ll be happy to provide you with more details.


&nbsp;
<div>
<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">
<h2>Social Media Content Services</h2>
Two Pens develops social media strategies that help your organization reach your customers and build communities. Successful strategies depend on producing content that gets shared across a network. Our skilled writers craft content that gets Liked and re-tweeted, help you invent your online brand and increase your social media profile. Two Pens’ specialty is making social media content work hand-in-hand with SEO to reach huge audiences.
<h2>Social Media Community Management</h2>
Our social media community managers support your efforts to respond to your customers or members of your community. They are welcoming, witty and constructive. They can encourage conversation or point people to the information they need.

</div>
<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

<h2>Branding</h2>
Two Pens has extensive branding experience. Our services include brand strategy, naming, logo design and graphic standards. We've named many new entities (Sound Transit, for example, and its products, Link, Sounder and ST Express); rebranded old ones (we handled the transition from WPPSS to Washington Energy); and conceived hundreds of new products identities, from Armstrong floors to Peterbilt Trucks to Microsoft Development Network cloud, mobile and web apps.

[caption id="attachment_1439" align="aligncenter" width="395" caption="Recently, Two Pens worked with Microsoft Developer Network to develop names and graphic identities for resources in the MSDN developer archive."]<img class="size-full wp-image-1439" title="msftDevGuideFinalTrio" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/msftDeveloperGuidanceTrio3.jpg" alt="" width="395" height="177" />[/caption]

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Non-Profit Blogger Super Stars</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?page_id=1912</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What can your organization learn from some of the most talented bloggers writing for non-profits and causes today? Three non-profit star bloggers will show you how content quality can help build a social media presence and a community, two key ingredients for advocacy campaigns and delivering services.

Taught by bloggers Carla Saulter and Lauren Branden.

	<item>
		<title>Rock a Presentation</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?page_id=4011</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=4011</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Having trouble wowing your audience and selling your ideas? It’s not enough to learn a few PowerPoint basics and call it good. You need to figure out how to create a conversation and get the audience engaged with your material. Cynthia Hartwig, veteran of thousands of advertising presentations and a frequent national speaker, will lead you through an inspiring day of exercises designed to move you away from one way (and dead end) presenting. You’ll learn how to use a whiteboard, how to mind map and work with other brainstorming exercises to wake up your listeners. You’ll practice storytelling and use your own personal experiences to get an audience on your side. You’ll master pushing the Great Bugaboo of Nervousness behind you. And yes, you’ll get a tutorial on how to use PowerPoint without looking like a tool. Guarantee: You’ll never think about presenting in the same way.
<h3>Who should take this class?</h3>
Anyone who needs to increase your authority and power in front of a group, improve your ability to persuade people and make yourself look great in front of your boss.

<h3>Class Outline</h3>

<strong>Presentation zen</strong><strong>

a. Introduction to Writing to Think
b. Writing Exercise: write about a story about a presentation gone wrong
c. A Modest Proposal: video John Bohannon/TED video.com on replacing PowerPoint with dance
d. Let’s reorient your view of presenting: you are not the star, only the participant can make change
e. Ways to change up meetings from talk-at- you to continuous engagements
f. When to use PowerPoint, when to incorporate story telling, and how to incorporate whiteboard and brainstorming exercises
g. Ways to reveal information for different situations

</strong><strong>Presentation Logistics</strong>

a. PowerPoint mastery: how to control PowerPoint instead of letting it control you
b. How to work with imagery
c. Typography 101
d. Relieving boredom by alternating pictures, video and sound
e. Charting with humanity
f. Video: charts that break through
g. Scouting the room and managing tech
h. The “frying fingers” theory of point size
i. Writing exercise: Tips for managing anxiety and conquering nerves

<strong>The Art of Storytelling</strong>

a. Why stories are the best way to draw an audience closer
b. Examples of how to use stories in a business setting
c. The difference between listening and reading: analysis of This American Life Wedding Bells and Door Bells excerpt
d. Writing exercise: tell us a personal story and present to the group
e. Writing exercise: discover the universal meaning of your story and how to convey it
f. Video excerpt: analysis of Don’t Regret Reget by Kathryn Schulz/TEDVideos.com

<strong>Personal Tune-Up</strong>

a. Writing exercise: Write about yourself as a presenter and where you succeed and fail
b. Group story-telling exercises
c. Video excerpt: The Mehrabian Myth (Words Matter)
d. Presentation practice in front of the group: group critique]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4011</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-08-24 14:10:04</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>rock-presentation</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>Self-Publish on Amazon via CreateSpace</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/business-writing-self-publish/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Nov 2010 23:12:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=93</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Self-Publish on Amazon via CreateSpace</h3>
Digital publishing and e-book readers have up-ended the publishing world, giving writers many new opportunities to publish.  Publishing on Amazon gives writers access to the largest book distribution channel in the world—greater than any of the big New York publishers.  It also saves you the cost of manufacturing and shipping your book, which means you’re free to focus on promoting it. Amazon provides tools for that, too. This course provides a step-by-step guide to using CreateSpace, Amazon’s self-publishing and promotion platform. It also helps you define a marketing strategy that takes advantage of Amazon’s promotional tools. 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Book Proposals to Book Agents</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/book-proposals-to-book-agents/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 00:41:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=117</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Book Proposals to Book Agents</h3>
Convincing an agent to represent your book depends on writing a convincing proposal.  Agents are busy—just think of all the people peddling their manuscripts.  This means they’re more likely to read through a proposal if you’ve helped them do some of their work.  Conducting basic market research and a competitive analysis shrinks their to do list.  Clearly structuring and clearly writing your proposal eases their tired eyes .  Course elements include how to 1)conduct market research and competitive analysis, 2) write a concise yet informative chapter outline, 3) sell yourself by writing an interesting bio, 4) choose the best excerpt or sample chapter, and 5) develop a realistic marketing plan that can be integrated with a publisher’s to turn your book into a bestseller. 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>117</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base-become-a-social-media-star/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 00:41:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=119</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO</h3>
<strong>Level:</strong> Recommended for writers involved in marketing products or services. Also excellent for writers who want to build their careers.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> Grow your fan base and become a social media thought leader.  Writing tweets to attract followers and status updates to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks.  How can you create an online following? During the first hour, we’ll provide examples of a broad range of people who have, along with social media strategies that work. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook. We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever-widening audience.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Successful Social Media Strategies for Attracting a Following:</strong> Examples of writers with high social media profiles and how they built them.</li>
	<li><strong>Trolling for Comments:</strong> Writing blog posts that ignite conversations. Blog writing exercises focus on crafting openings to get people to click Read More, developing an engaging tone, and structuring and formatting content to make it easy to read, and give examples of topics that lead to comments.</li>
	<li><strong>Re-tweet after Me:</strong> Witty tweeting is just the first step. Exercise on how to get re-tweeted by combining compelling content with Twitter tools (hashtags, round trips, etc.).</li>
	<li><strong>Facebook Fanfare:</strong> Exercise on how to write status reports that get shared, including developing a Facebook style, topics that grow your fan base, and content formats to include with your post.</li>
<li><strong>Write great Content</strong> It’s a balancing act to write social media content that engages an audience while simultaneously helping your content show up at the top of search engine results.  We’ll you teach you tips and tricks on how to write great content that search engines find.</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

<strong>Date: </strong> 9-16-11
<strong>Time: </strong> 1-5pm
<strong>Place: </strong>Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<strong>Cost: </strong> $150
&nbsp;

	<item>
		<title>Closing the Loop</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/closing-the-loop/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 00:44:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=123</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Closing the Loop</h3>

<strong>Level:</strong> Recommended for corporate and small-business marketers as well as nonprofit advocates in charge of running online campaigns. 

<strong>Class Description:</strong> The creative worked. It’s gone viral and is driving traffic to your site. Now how do you close the loop with customers? Designing and developing a compelling landing page with a clear call to action is the answer. Producing one requires marrying the creative with great content and an effective user interface—and most importantly, defining goals. This course covers how to design and develop the content and information architecture to guide rather than divert or lose customers. It focuses on developing content that works together with the creative and user interface design to achieve campaign goals—whether you want to drive sales, increase customer acquisition, or build your brand.
 
	<ol>
<li><strong>Campaign Goals:</strong> Closing the loop depends on where the loop started: Did you launch an online campaign to build awareness, sell products or services or events, or increase donations? Exercise: Setting campaign goals and defining the call-to-action.</li>

<li><strong>The Simpler the Better:</strong>  Landing pages should serve one purpose. A landing page for an awareness campaign won’t work for a product campaign. Exercise: Defining the purpose of a landing page. Looking at successful landing pages for inspiration.</li>

<li><strong>The Perfect Marriage:</strong> Eye-pleasing designs can’t work without brain-teasing web content. Examples include well-designed and well-written landing pages. Exercise: Writing a short creative brief that defines how look-and-feel works together with the content.</li>

<li><strong>Defining the Information Architecture:</strong> A landing page guides a visitor in completing an action or learning more. Exercise: Approaching information architecture by merging landing page functionality with design and content in order to achieve goals.</li></ol>

<strong>Date: </strong>Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong>Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Content that Binds Online Communities</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/content-that-binds-online-communities/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 00:46:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=129</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Content that Binds Online Communities</h3>
Online communities form through affinity.  The liveliness and staying power of communities—whether they are knitting, beekeeping, or fans of open source programming—depend on their members sharing information and knowledge.  Is it possible for businesses to build and/or participate in an online community to the benefit of both? Businesses who listen and share ideas with communities related to their business can tap expertise and learn what customers want in products and service.
 
 How do you begin?  First you need to develop a clear strategy based on your core mission and on understanding which online communities related to your business already exist. A content plan plays a huge role in implementing the strategy—after all, information exchange is at the heart of community interactions.

Course covers the steps required to develop both a network strategy and content plan to implement.  Types of content covered in the course include developing content with a point of view to generate lively debate; identifying expertise within the company that can be shared, and social media content that builds relationships and positions the company as a player within the community. 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>content-that-binds-online-communities</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1345</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>Writing We Like</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/writing-we-like/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 01:23:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=152</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<H1>Writing We Like</H1>


<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">
<div style="padding-right: 30px;">

</a><h2>Track these</h2>

<a href="http://www.subversivecopyeditor.com/" target="_blank">The Subversive Copy Editor </a>
Carol Fisher Saller is the editor behind the attitude of The Chicago Manual of Style’s 16th edition. She’s an editor’s editor. Who else would say, “There are two kinds of people in the world: There are those who could be given this book [The Chicago Manual of Style] and not be able to put it down, and there are people who would, you know, rather slit their wrists than read it.”

<a href="http://www.austinkleon.com/" target="_blank">Austin Kleon</a>
Austin Kleon is “a writer who draws.” His blog consistently delivers on his brand promise to deliver interesting writing with a visual spin. He also does a great job of marketing his books and poetry. He conveys an authentic brand and rewards the reader with interesting and quirky creativity.

<a href="http://www.doctorsyntax.net" target="_blank">Dr. Syntax</a>
Scattered observations on books and publishing.

<a href="http://horsfallcreative.com/horsfallcreative/Blog/Blog.html" target="_blank">The Talking Horse Blog</a>
David Horsfall publishes a weekly blog about the Seattle advertising and design world: small community, well written.

<a href="http://writersrainbow.blogspot.com/" target="_blank">Writer's Rainbow</a>
Writing advice and resources from Bainbridge Island, with a local focus.

<a href="http://www.midgeraymond.com/blog/" target="_blank">Midge Raymond</a>
This blogger from Ashland, Oregon, offers up interesting articles on writing.

<a href="http://maudnewton.com/blog/" target="_blank">Maud Newton</a>
One of the first and most popular book blogs; her inside scoop on the publishing world keeps her traffic high. If you’re in a niche community, scoop up the news here and post a link to it. A word of advice to other bloggers: nastiness doesn’t play well, unless you’re the Gawker or Perez Hilton. Newton gets the tone just right.

<a href="http://www.samizdatblog.blogspot.com/" target="_blank">Samizdat Blog</a>
English professor and poet Robert Archambeau is one of the funniest literary critics you’ll read anywhere. And he updates his blog with quips, profiles, and commentary. His is a good model even if your blog is about cooking or fossil digging.

<a href="http://gawker.com/" target="_blank">Gawker</a>
And the God of the Internet said, “Let there be Gawker,” and there was Gawker. All the best writers in New York just needed somewhere to show off their scorchingly wicked wit—anonymously, of course. They don’t want to lose their day jobs at the <em>New Yorker</em>. Visit Gawker to read great writing disguised as gossip.

<a href="http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/" target="_blank">Galley Cat</a>
An insider’s blog on the publishing industry. It’s so “insider” that publishers like to leak their news here, much the way the White House sometimes leaks the news to the <em>New York Times</em>. If you really want to know which publishing houses have traded marketing VPs or how much of an advance your favorite author bagged for her next book, stop here. The writing’s great. It has to be.

<a href="http://www.slate.com/id/2065896/view/2085943/" target="_blank">Slate Magazine Blogs</a>
Unlike HuffPo, you can’t blog on Slate without nearly winning a Pulitzer for your other work. (Read Slate, too, if you want to study consistently fine writing.) My favorites are <a href="http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/browbeat/default.aspx" target="_blank">BrowBeat</a>, Slate’s culture blog, and <a href="http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/procrastinatebetter/" target="_blank">Procrastinate Better</a>, Slate’s “Guide to Consuming Culture.” Notice the catchy title—just as important as Google keyword ads for attracting an audience.

<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

</div>
</div>
<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">
<div style="padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px;">
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<h2>Re-tweet these</h2>

<a href="http://twitter.com/#!/colsonwhitehead" target="_blank">Colson Whitehead</a>
It's not enough to be a writer of fabulous books like John Henry Days and Sag Harbor and a MacArthur award-winning genius; the guy writes hilarious tweets. 

<a href="http://twitter.com/#!/BorowitzReport" target="_blank">Andy Borowitz</a>
OK, OK, guilty pleasure. We love how Andy the Comedian has a constant ear to popular culture and issues of the day.  Who else would make jokes about the Pope and Madonna in one tweet?

<a href="http://twitter.com/#!/ronsilliman" target="_blank">Ron Silliman </a>
First- ever poetry blogger. Influential, cranky, and an outsider who became an insider.  

<a href="http://twitter.com/#!/wrongologist"target="_blank">Kathryn Schulz </a>
Bill Clinton praised her book Being Wrong. On Twitter, she keeps expanding on the importance of embracing error.

<a title="Maud Newton" href="http://twitter.com/#!/maudnewton" target="_blank">Maud Newton</a>
When Maud Newton starts a book debate, the publishing world joins in.

<a title="Simon Mainwaring" href="https://twitter.com/simonmainwaring" target="_blank"> Simon Mainwaring</a>
His tweets are like a gateway drug into his world.

<a title="Guy Kawasaki" href="https://twitter.com/Alltop" target="_blank">Guy Kawasaki</a>
Very intelligent writer and business leader.

<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
<h2>Like these</h2>

<a title="Fremont Sunday Market" href="http://www.facebook.com/FremontSundayMarket " target="_blank"> Fremont Sunday Market</a>
The Fremont Sunday Market—a weekly Seattle neighborhood festival offering crafts, antiques, food, and more—typically posts “live” content on the morning of the market. It’s a great reminder and call to action.

<a title="Theo Chocolate" href="http://www.facebook.com/theochocolate " target="_blank">Theo Chocolate</a>
This Seattle chocolatier does a great job of generating interest, intimacy and community.

<a title="Sound Experience" href=" http://www.facebook.com/soundexp" target="_blank">Sound Experience</a>
Sound Experience recently blew the lid off of the National Historic Trust competition. Their social media strategy, dedicated volunteers and crew made a huge difference.

<a href="http://www.facebook.com/SVCSeattle" target="_blank">School of Visual Concepts</a> <a name="wwlfacebookSVC"></a>
We like the constantly updated mix of creative news on SVC’s Facebook page. Creative job listings, graphic design tips, HTML goodies, copywriting expertise; if it’s worth passing along, they’re on it. We also like the warm, friendly voice that tells you a human—and humane—being is posting.

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tip Of The Week</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/tip-of-the-week/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Nov 2010 01:18:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=237</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="size-full wp-image-265 aligncenter" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;" title="tipoftheweek-header" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/tipoftheweek-header2.jpg" alt="Tip of the Week" width="887" height="69" />

<h1>Web headers should help you find information</h1>
When you’re writing webpage headlines, remember that their role is to tell readers what the content is about. Readers are busy, so don’t irritate them by making them hunt for what they’re looking for. Augment an informative header with subheads that lead readers through the copy to the information they want.

<h1>Grammarphobia</h1>

<strong> Dangling participles</strong>

Dangling participles are the curse of writers and comic relief for editors. Usually they happen when a writer forgets what a participle is qualifying.

“Waiting in line at the grocery store, the eggs fell off the shopping cart and splattered the woman behind me. “

This sentence literally means that the eggs were waiting in line instead of the person. Fix it by adding a subject to the action, such as “While I waited in line, the eggs…”

&nbsp;
<h1>Effective Business Communications</h1>

<strong> Effective Emails </strong>
Make emails more effective by dealing with only one subject per email. Sum up the main point of the email in the subject line.

<strong> Creative Briefs</strong>
Do you wonder why assignments to creative people often run amok? Build the sturdy box called a creative brief to corral wild and woolly writers and art directors so they can deliver on-target work. Boil down the key selling proposition—what you most want to convey—into a single message. Creatives will kiss your feet, and you’ll be able to lay down your sword.

<strong> Postscript</strong>
What’s the most-read part of a direct mail letter?
The postscript.
P.S. Works in blog posts and emails too.

&nbsp;
<h1>Social Media Gold Stars</h1>
<strong> Blogging is not bloviating.</strong>

Keep blog posts short and on point. Deal with one topic per post. Encourage people to click past the jump point by telling them something that’s new or not widely known.

<strong> Which tweets are most likely to be retweeted?</strong>

Believe it or not, the best way to get people to re-tweet your tweets is to ask them. This doesn’t mean begging, "Please retweet my tweet." Instead, link your question to the tweet. For example, "Will Google’s new Department of Culture support poetry? Check out the cultural czar’s blog post."

<strong> Online communities form through affinity.</strong>

They may be focused on diverse topics— knitting, cooking, and beekeeping are just a few examples—but they all depend on their members sharing information and knowledge. Provide content that is valuable to the community without selling your own agenda or products in overt ways. If the content is relevant, the community will share it and your site will grow.

<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<h1>Write With Style</h1>

<strong>Don’t overuse the first person when blogging.</strong>

That probably sounds ridiculous. Isn’t the very definition of a blog a public, personal journal? Well, yes. But blogs have changed a lot since LiveJournal was introduced in 1999. Think of Huffington Post bloggers. They come in all shapes and sizes: news commentators, technology geeks, gadget nuts, divorce specialists, and dance critics. Now imagine if all their posts began with the equivalent of “This morning I got up and started thinking about …” Writing in the first person is often a failed attempt to create a conversational tone. Look for other ways to be personal. Try humor to engage your readers, or talk about something that bugs you. Get irritated about it. Stamp your feet. Just don’t overuse the “I” if you’re the one doing it. 

&nbsp;

<strong> No time for a full edit? </strong>

Zip through your document and circle all of the abstract words (words you can’t see, smell, taste, touch, or hear). Then replace each with a concrete or “sensory” word.

&nbsp;

<strong> Eliminate flabby phrasing </strong>

Speed up your writing by eliminating flabby phrasing and using stellar verbs. Replace “She walked around the apartment” with “She ping-ponged from table to chair.”

&nbsp;

<strong>Reword the run on sentence </strong>

A news editor taught Hemingway to replace “compendium” with “book” and “verbose” with “windy.” Guess who won the Nobel Prize?
Use Hemingway’s technique by keeping sentences short and tight. Replace long, complex run-on sentences with one punchy thought.

&nbsp;

<strong> When does a verb act like a noun? </strong>

The infinitive form of a verb can function as a noun.

The retired greyhound loved to race in his dreams.
In this sentence, the infinitive “to race” is the direct object of “loved.”

&nbsp;

<strong> Muscular Writing </strong>

Make your writing more muscular by editing out passive voice. Instead of using Nixon’s phrase “Mistakes were made,” go boldly out on the limb and write, “Spiro Agnew made mistakes and I played checkers.”

&nbsp;

<strong> We hate weak verbs</strong>

We hate weak verbs. We do not want to get rid of them. Or even to kill them. We want to eviscerate, smother, incinerate, explode, poison, cremate, or run them through with our very sharp pens.

<strong> Fresh Metaphors </strong>

A good metaphor carries more weight than a cliché. “He looked about as conspicuous as a tarantula on a slide of angel food cake,” wrote Raymond Chandler. Now there’s an image you won’t forget. Chandler also wrote, “Chess is as elaborate a waste of human intelligence as you can find outside an advertising agency.” We rest our case.

<strong> Assume you know something </strong>

Assume you know something. Write from your own stock of learning instead of passing on other people’s thoughts. In order to become a thought leader, you must think about your take on a topic. If you have just learned something new, include your experience with a breakdown of your old way of thinking and your new revelation. Your personal experience will resonate with other people and build your reputation as a thinker on the way to becoming a thought leader.

&nbsp;
<h1>Wordplay</h1>
<strong> Improve your writing</strong>

Improve your writing by "de-Latinizing" your language. Replace a multisyllable word, such as "obfuscate," with a concrete word that contains an image, such as "hide." Deep-six "lachrymose” for “tearful."

&nbsp;

<strong> Color your writing</strong>

Why settle for plain old green when you have a world of color words at your disposal? Shamrock green, jade green, kelly green, grass green, sea green, olive green, and algae, all provide strong imagery, specificity and (dare we say it) color to your writing. They'll be green with envy if you do it right.

&nbsp;

<strong> Subscribe to Word of the Day at <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/">dictionary.com</a>.</strong>
Every day an uncommon and interesting word, such as "nostrum," will arrive in your Inbox. Word of the Day provides the pronunciation and definition: 'Nostrum \NOS-truhm\, noun: "1. A medicine of secret composition and unproven or dubious effectiveness; a quack medicine.  2. A usually questionable remedy or scheme; a cure-all."'

The day’s word is shown in use: "Old ladies were always offering her their advice, recommending this or that nostrum." (Charlotte Brontë, Shirley: A Tale)

Best of all, Word of the Day provides the word’s root, which gives you an excellent memory aid. For example, "nostrum" derives from the Latin nostrum (remedium), "our (remedy)," from nos, "we." Remember the "we" at the heart of "nostrum," and the helpful folk origin of a quack remedy will stick in your brain.

&nbsp;

<strong>Headlines </strong>

Avoid see-and-say headlines and visuals. To sell a donkey, the last thing you want is a headline that says “Donkey for Sale” with a picture of old Ferdinand chewing a carrot. Instead, come up with a headline that asks the reader to participate in the process by putting your headline together with an unexpected visual. For example, you could show two identical donkeys, each plowing a field. Your headline would read, “Talking Donkey for Sale: $5,000. Nontalking Donkey: $500.” That all-important first line of copy that rewards the reader for playing the game? “Both donkeys will plow your field, but only one will complain about it.”

&nbsp;
<h1>Writing Wizardry</h1>
<strong> Jump-Start Your Writing.</strong>
Make the timer your friend. Jump-start a writing assignment by breaking it into manageable chunks, then write in a notebook for 15 minutes in about each topic. Type up what you’ve written, and you’ll see that you’ve gotten a good start.
<strong> Write the end first.</strong>

If you know where you’re going, you’ll write toward the conclusion more quickly and efficiently.
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<strong> Write with a model. (It’s like working with a net.)</strong>

From Shakespeare to Mozart, the world’s most brilliant writers and musicians have imitated the work of others to learn their tricks. Copy a sentence you admire by hand, and you will absorb the writer’s style. Take your learning a step further by imitating the diction, rhythm, color words, and form of the sentence with your own material. More fun for writers than crossword puzzles.
<strong> Push That Metaphor. </strong>

Metaphor is usually described as comparing one unlike thing to another. Actually, the true definition of metaphor involves one thing becoming another. If you have trouble remembering this rule, remember that the Greek root of “metaphor” conveys movement or transport: meta + pherein (“to bear”).

Thus, in “Her hair is a Brillo pad under her cap,” a woman’s unkempt curly hair “becomes” a stiff, wiry, crimped cleaning pad. (Not literally, obviously.)

In other tips, we’ve described ways to find attributes that two unlike objects might share. But what if you want to extend a metaphor and push the limits of comparison?

We offer this stellar simile from Winston Churchill, a strong writer in addition to a good leader (and quaffer of stiff drinks).

<strong>“Martinis are like women's breasts. One is not enough and three is too many.”
—Winston Churchill</strong>

Best Churchill at his own game. Come up with at least five similes that compare one thing to another in totally unexpected ways, as above.

&nbsp;
<h1>Usage Abuse</h1>
&nbsp;

<strong>Exclaiming Too Much(!!) </strong>

Have you noticed how ubiquitous exclamation points are on Facebook posts and tweets, and in text messages? Such small spaces lend themselves to using this punctuation mark which some editors call “screamers.” They help you emphasize your point quickly and convey strong emotion, both keys to attracting followers on social media. But relying on them too much weakens their effect. For example, if you tweet, “Can’t wait to see you!!” AND “I heard the restaurant where we’re meeting is fabulous!!,” your friend won’t know which is more important, your date or the restaurant.

<strong>Using exclamation points sparingly, heightens their effect</strong>—kind of like people who don’t say much but when they do, people listen to every word. One way to decide whether to use one or not is to re-read your sentences to see if your words already convey urgency or emotion. You’ve already told your friend the restaurant is “fabulous,” so do you really need an exclamation point to make that point? Here’s another example: “We had a marvelous time at our gadget-free Thanksgiving in the mountains--fresh powdery snow, a full moon and quiet river, and close friends to share it with.” No need to exclaim. The descriptive details prove it was a “marvelous” time.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Social Media Rules Retail or Does It?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/social-media-rules-retail-or-does-it/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Nov 2010 00:17:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=307</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Social Media Rules Retail - or Does It?</h3>
Today social media marketing rules, but even it cannot replace customer touch, or customers touching your products. The longer they sip coffee, play with gadgets, or read a book’s back cover, the more likely they are to reach into their pockets.  The key to successful social media retail campaigns is to use content whether in blog posts, Facebook status reports, or tweets to get people into the store.
Course includes how to strategize integrated content for retail social media campaigns and how to write effective social media posts that gets customers to click and then walk into the store.  (These same strategies can be applied to online retail sites.)

	<item>
		<title>Cures for Attention Deficit Disorder</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/cures-for-attention-deficit-disorder/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Nov 2010 00:19:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=310</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Cures for Attention Deficit Disorder </h3>

<strong>Level:</strong> Recommended for business and nonprofit marketing professionals, small business owners, and online writers. 

<strong>Class Description:</strong> The mind-boggling expansion of the Internet means there are more websites, blogs, and social networks than eyeballs. As the Internet has increased, the amount of time people spend on any one website has shrunk. The “bounce rate” deflates many online campaign and content strategies. The result? ROI tanks. Curing this curse requires a two-pronged attack: analyzing website traffic data in relation to content, and revising content based on the story that the numbers are telling.

Course provides an overview of analytics-driven content strategies. We focus on two web statistics in relation to content—the bounce rate or time-on-site, and the referrals or entrance pages. The first statistic helps you identify content that sends people away; the second statistic helps you figure out what sends them to you. 
 
<ol>
<li><strong>The Sea of Data:</strong>  Every organization is awash in it. Executives and board members demand metrics, and then their eyes glaze over when you present them. The course covers picking the most useful data to track and how to present it. </li>

<li><strong>Reducing Bounce Rates:</strong>  It’s typical for people to spend less than a few seconds on your site. Just think of your own browsing habits. How do you get them to stay?  Covers crafting headlines and content that stops people from clicking away. </li>

<li><strong>Meet and Greet:</strong>  How many hours did you spend figuring out home page content while ignoring its lower-level siblings?  Knowing where people are coming from and where they enter your site tells you where to focus your time and energy. Class focuses on analyzing referral and entrance page data, and creating content to take advantage of the numbers.</li></ol>

<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong>Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Applying Proven Direct Marketing Tactics to Social Media </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/applying-proven-direct-marketing-tactics-to-social-media/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Nov 2010 00:24:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=314</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Applying proven direct marketing tactics to social media </h3>
In all the hoopla about social media as the hot new thing, many people have lost sight of its roots in traditional direct marketing.  This course shows you how to apply successful direct marketing tactics (specific calls-to-action, easy ordering, scannable subheads, use of post scripts, even Johnson Boxes!) to social media. We’ll show you examples of clever direct marketing that has boosted results off-line and been successfully “repurposed” for online marketing.  
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />

	<item>
		<title>Content to Launch Products into the Stratosphere</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/content-to-launch-products-into-the-stratosphere/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Nov 2010 03:47:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=322</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Content to Launch Products into the Stratosphere</h3>
<strong>Level:</strong> Recommended for business and non-proft marketing professionals and small business owners.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> Why do companies claim that almost every new software product will make it easier, faster, and simpler to get something done? If that were true, we’d all work four days per week and spend the fifth on the beach. Writing compelling and original marketing collateral for product launches takes elbow grease and lots of creativity. Course includes how to write effective marketing content, including product overviews, value propositions, and whitepapers—for both online and print.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Editorial Plan:</strong> Without one, redundancy happens. With one, each marketing document and web page conveys a consistent message while serving a related purpose.  Covers identifying what’s in your marketing content toolkit, defining the purpose of each piece, and putting together an editorial content calendar.</li>
	<li><strong>Product Overviews:</strong> What makes your product different? What are its key features and their benefits to customers? You’ll see examples of good and bad product overviews and feature/benefit content. Exercise: You’ll write on your own on a variety of collateral projects.</li>
	<li><strong>Short and Sweet</strong>: What’s the trick to writing spiffy elevator pitches and web content that people actually read? They’re condensed versions of your marketing strategy. Covers how to write snappy, informative, short content.  Exercises in editing for brevity, writing with wit, and adding attitude.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong> Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Creating Videos Designed to go Viral</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/creating-videos-designed-to-go-viral/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Nov 2010 03:49:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=324</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Creating Videos Designed to go Viral</h3>
Everybody wants to create a viral video shared by millions but in reality, only a few videos achieve stardom in the YouTube universe.  In this course, we’ll show you a variety of highly creative videos that have broken through the viewing barrier and then take a hypothetical product and start concepting.  You will walk away with a video script and a better understanding of the process of creating low-budget video. We will include a short demo of the various steps involved, from writing a script to storyboarding to shooting and contracting for post-production. However, this is not a nuts-and-bolts production course; our focus is on creating fun, compelling content that speaks to your target audience.

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>324</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-26 19:49:40</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Readable Whitepapers</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/writing-readable-whitepapers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:03:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=357</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Writing Readable Whitepapers</h3>

Do you groan when an account rep leaves behind a whitepaper to read? Or worse, do you run screaming when the VP of marketing assigns you to write one?  Effective whitepapers follow the same principles as magazine articles—snappy lead, bold assertion that the paper will prove, interesting prose, tone and style appropriate for its audience, and more.  

Course includes how to structure a whitepaper, define its audience and purpose, figure out its tone and writing style, and integrate graphics into the text. 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>When is a Manual Not a Manual?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/when-is-a-manual-not-a-manual/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:08:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=363</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>When is a Manual Not a Manual?</h3>

Hefty print manuals are a thing of the past, yet there’s still a need to show new customers how to use a new product and how they’ll benefit from it.  The “new” manuals include Quick Start and Reviewers’ Guides, on-page laminated cards and brochures, and how-to videos.  They’re challenging to produce because their word count is mind-bogglingly short and the space for graphics tight.  

Course includes how to write condensed versions of product guides that teach customers how to use a product and articulate its benefits at the same time.  The course also covers how to write copy that can be easily integrated with graphics. 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />

	<item>
		<title>Writing to Think</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/writing-to-think/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:09:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=367</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Writing to Think</h3>
<strong>Level: </strong>This class is designed for both experienced and inexperienced writers. If you consider yourself among the writing-averse, get ye hither, quaking quill in hand.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> Do you find yourself ruminating, cogitating and chewing the end of a pen while staring into blankness. This course will teach you how to let the pen do the thinking while you sit back and play. Bring a nettlesome problem to class:  something you don’t understand, an issue you’re trying to solve, something that interests or bugs you, or simply a question whose answer eludes you. Through a series of writing prompts, you’ll learn how to follow the pen’s meanderings across the page and make meaning where you thought chaos reigned. This class is a blast. It involves a lot of writing, but the environment is low-stress and low stakes, i.e., no pressure. You’ll walk out of this class with new confidence in your writing and a tool to get at what you already know that’s buried in the rubble of your brain.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Writing to Play</strong>: How can you befriend your pen? We’ll start with writing prompts designed to transform your pen from foe to ally. You’ll learn to play with writing through exercises such as answering questions with non-sequiturs, sketching portraits of classmates, and toying with lexicons.</li>
	<li><strong>Writing the Problem</strong>: You’ll be asked to think of a problem to solve that’s driving you crazy. With five-minute writing prompts, you’ll break down the problem in half of a dozen ways. For instance, you’ll define its worst and best characteristics, and write about the animal it resembles.</li>
	<li><strong>Writing the Solution</strong>: Now that you know your problem inside and out, you’ll write your way to a solution through exercises designed to playfully generate ideas. For instance, you’ll write about how ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY NOT to solve the problem.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Date: </strong> 9.30.11
<strong>Time: </strong> 1-5pm
<strong>Place: </strong>Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<strong>Cost: </strong> $150

<strong>Register Now</strong>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Practice 101</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/writing-practice-101/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:10:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=369</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Writing Practice 101</h3>

<strong>Level:</strong> This class is good for inexperienced writers who struggle with writing, and for experienced writers who want to tap into more emotion and creativity.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> If you stare at the blank page with dismay and would rather go to the dentist than write, consider signing up for this class. Writing requires practice. You wouldn’t step out on a golf course and expect to drive the ball two hundred yards down the fairway. Why would you approach the blank page without learning some skills first? In this class, we’ll teach you to jump-start a writing assignment through timed writing exercises. After you get going, we’ll show you how to use emotion and storytelling to mesmerize your audience. Bring a pen you like to write with (no laptops) and a spiral-bound notebook with lined pages.  

	<ol>
<li><strong>Just Do It:</strong> The “Just Do It” school is writing fast, writing easy, writing without regard for grammar, spelling, or politically correct thinking, and writing without stopping (until the timer goes off).  Short, timed writing exercises that will help you break through writer's block and get you laughing, remembering, and scribbling.  </li>

<li><strong>Practice, Practice, Practice:</strong> Now that you’ve filled the blank page, it’s time to learn some tricks to make your writing flow. Short, timed writing exercises that each focus on a writing or editing skill. </li>

<li><strong>What’s Emotion Got to Do with It?</strong> Readers won’t stop until they reach the end when you write with emotion. Emotions are dramatic. They come with built-in tension. What do you do after embarrassing yourself in a meeting? Why did that taxi driver give you the creeps? Timed writing exercises that will intensify your writing. </li>

<li><strong>Writing Journeys:</strong> We are wired for story. If you look hard enough, even cut-and-dried business problems have stories hidden inside. Exercises designed to help you see business problems as mythic stories, complete with interesting characters who struggle to resolve dilemmas.  </li>

</ol>

<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong> Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to Write a Creative Brief</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/how-to-write-a-creative-brief/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:10:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=371</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>How to Write a Creative Brief</h3>
<strong>Level:</strong> This class is designed for people responsible for managing and working effectively with creative teams, which can include writers, art directors, designers, web producers, or video/film teams who work as outside consultants or in-house staff.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> Creative people love to invent wildly creative ideas. Surprisingly, letting them go wild might produce a published, beautiful piece for their portfolios, but not a highly effective marketing creative. This class will teach you how to write a creative brief that reduces design cycles while generating creative advertising that wows. 

<ol>
	<li>“<strong>Why do you need a creative brief? It’s just a banner ad!:</strong>”  It doesn’t matter whether you’re working on a mobile app, website, e-newsletter, blog, promotion, banner ad, radio spot, TV campaign, or video. Briefs are not optional. They keep you within budget and on track, and set clear parameters within which your creative team can be wildly imaginative. We’ll provide an overview of how to structure creative briefs, using samples from real-world branding campaigns and integrated online and traditional media marketing campaigns. </li>

	<li><strong>Will you or won’t you? Tips for proposing:</strong> The most important element of a creative brief is the selling proposition. Draft a muddled one and you’ll find yourself scheduling and rescheduling meetings with stakeholders and, more importantly, boring customers. Exercises to show you how to make your stakeholders and customers say, "I do." </li>

	<li><strong>Blueprint:</strong> Now that you know your goal, you need to figure out how to get there. We’ll dissect a sample creative brief so you can see how each element contributes to the whole. Then we’ll provide exercises showing you how to strategically think through and write each section, which can include an analysis of previous marketing efforts, advice on choosing the mix of online, mobile, and traditional media channels, and guidelines for relating your target audience to your creative. </li></ol>

<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong> Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing With a Model</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/writing-with-a-model/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:11:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=373</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Writing With a Model</h3>
<strong>Class Description:</strong> In this class, we’ll show you how to use great writing to inform your own. From Shakespeare to Hemingway, the world’s most brilliant writers and musicians have imitated the work of others to learn their tricks. Working at the level of the sentence, we will analyze writing by the masters.  You’ll physically copy them out (to help you absorb them at the level of your cells) and then you’ll imitate the diction, rhythm, color words, and sentence structure with your own material.  In the second half of the class, we will focus on using longer “structural” models to help you find the right form for longer essays, articles, or white papers.
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>373</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-29 17:11:23</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-11-30 01:11:23</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>writing-with-a-model</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Seven Editing Tips to Make Your Writing More Muscular</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/ten-editing-tips-to-make-your-writing-more-muscular/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:12:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=375</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Seven Editing Tips to Make Your Writing More Muscular</h3>
<strong>Level:</strong>Recommended for all business writers who want to write more effectively and reduce the time it takes. 

<strong>Class Description:</strong> When you’re pressed for time, it’s hard to write well. But believe it or not, it’s okay to write as fast as you can, churning out boring, repetitive, and overwritten pieces.  Putting words on a page is always the most difficult part.  It’s easier to revise if you know these seven editing tips. They’ll keep you from torpedoing your deadline.

	<ol>
<li><strong>Editing for Speed Reading:</strong>  Simple sentences sell.  Write convoluted, wandering sentences, and you’ll lose your readers. Editing exercises to cut a straight path with your pen. </li>

	<li><strong>Act, Don’t Hang Back:</strong>  Jazz up your writing by switching from passive to active verbs. Writing and editing exercises to turn flabby writing into muscular prose. </li>

	<li><strong>Adjective and Adverb-Ectomies:</strong>  Simplify your sentences by reducing the number of adjectives and adverbs you use. We’ll take ho-hum copy and run it through the Adjective-and Adverb-Ectomizer to clean up clutter and clarify meaning. </li>

	<li><strong>No Abstractions, Please:</strong>  People engage with the world through the senses. Adding sights, sounds, tastes, and smells to your writing creates a visceral experience.  Writing and editing exercise to identify abstractions and replace them with concrete language. </li>

	<li><strong>Repetition Run-through</strong>:  Write fast, and inevitably you’ll write repetitively. Writing and editing exercise to remove repetitious language to let the meaning stand on its own. </li>

	<li><strong>Punching Up the Opening:</strong>  Catch the attention of the reader at the beginning, or the rest of the work will be for naught. We’ll look at great openings and then rewrite our own first paragraphs. </li>

	<li><strong>Speak the Speak:</strong>  Every industry has a specific set of words—a lexicon—that only people working within it know. Using their language in your writing builds your authority with them. Even if you’re not an air conditioning expert or a diesel-engine engineer, you can build a lexicon of 100 words to join their world. We’ll provide sample lexicons and show you how to build on them. </li></ol>

<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong> Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Jump Start a Writing Assignment</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/jump-start-a-writing-assignment/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:12:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=377</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Jump Start a Writing Assignment</h3>
Writing would be wonderful if we had all the time in the world. And writing would take all the time in the world if we never had a deadline. Everybody needs to write faster and meet on-rushing deadlines efficiently. You’ll learn the efficiency of investing one hour in answering questions prior to beginning the “real” draft. Bring a writing assignment or a topic in which you’re interested and we’ll guide you through a series of prompts that will allow you to think on the page and save time in the finished draft.
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-67" title="RegisterNowBtn" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/RegisterNowBtn.jpg" alt="Register Now!" width="198" height="43" />
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Business Proposals 101</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/business-proposals-101/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Nov 2010 01:13:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=379</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Business Proposals 101</h3>
<strong>Level:</strong> Recommended for anyone who’s starting or managing a business or non-proft organization, or a major program or department.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> From venture capital funding requests to PR proposals or a plea to get a raise, there are a multitude of proposal formats. But in reality, the purpose of all proposals is to sell: they all propose an idea and a winning strategy. We will break down the main elements of a standard business proposal and use hands-on writing exercises to draft one sure to get approved. You’ll learn the psychology behind successful proposals. We’ll also provide sample winning proposals, which you can use as models for your real-world assignments.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Methodical Dreaming:</strong> Setting an inspiring yet feasible goal is essential to selling your plan and motivating your team. Provides writing exercise to help you define your business or program goal.</li>
	<li><strong>From Stagecraft to Strategy:</strong> Realizing your goal requires getting real. To design an achievable strategy, you’ll learn to focus on the challenges your business or program faces, and the possible tactics, tools, and positioning for surmounting them. Combines writing and business brainstorming exercises to discover the best strategy for your organization, and the metrics and timeframe for achieving it.</li>
	<li><strong>Drafting and Crafting the Plan:</strong> What’s the trick to writing a proposal that will be approved?  Conveying your goals with passion and clearly articulating how you’re going to get there.  Guides you through structuring a business proposal based on your goals and strategy, and then provides writing exercises to draft and polish each section.</li>
</ol>

<strong>Date: </strong> Coming This Fall
<strong>Place: </strong> Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104


</form><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Upcoming Courses</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/upcoming-courses/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 18 Jan 2011 20:17:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=756</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="size-full wp-image-265 aligncenter" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;" title="upcomingcourses-header" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/upcomingcourses-header.jpg" alt="Upcoming Courses" width="887" height="69" />
<div style="float: left; width: 70%;">
<p style="font-size: 125%;">You can attend a Two Pens course at our offices or <a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=866">contact us </a>about teaching one at your organization. We can tailor any course to meet your writing needs.</p>
<p style="font-size: 125%;">Our offices are conveniently located in Pioneer Square:</p>
<strong>Two Pens</strong>
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
206-321-0826
<a href="mailto:info@twopens.com">info@twopens.com</a>
(206)321-0826

<!--p style="font-size: 125%;">We also teach at other writing centers.  This month we're teaching a course at Richard Hugo House on how writers can create a social media presence.</div>
<div  _mce_tmp="1"><-->
<h3>Attract Followers, Grow Your Fan Base, Become a Social Media Thought Leader</h3>
Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks, especially if you’re a writer. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will provide examples of successful social media strategies of other writers and the content that made them happen. Course includes blog, Twitter and Facebook writing exercises. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences. Recommended for all writers who want to build their careers.
<a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=119">More Info</a>

<!--Meets: Sunday, April 10, 2011 - Sunday, April 10, 2011
