<div  _mce_tmp="1"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" _mce_src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" /></div>
<div style="font-size: 125%;" _mce_style="font-size: 125%;" _mce_tmp="1">We're offering the same social media class at our offices in April and May.<-->

<strong>Date: June 9, 2011</strong>
<strong>Time: 9 am - 1 pm</strong>
<!--Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. And these days, many agents and editors expect you to know how.  Building an online audience makes it more likely they’ll take a look at your manuscript. How can you create an online following? <-->

<form action="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr" enctype="application/x-www-form-urlencoded" method="post"><input name="cmd" type="hidden" value="_s-xclick" /> <input name="hosted_button_id" type="hidden" value="8KQ6ETPVRK2GJ" /> <input alt="PayPal - The safer, easier way to pay online!" name="submit" src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110401-1/en_US/i/btn/btn_cart_LG.gif" type="image" /> <img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110401-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
</form><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110401-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
<h3>Re-Tweet After Me</h3>
Don’t get Twitter? Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream? In this class, you’ll learn Twitter basics—its lingo, tools, and how to write tweets to huge followings. We’ll give you writing prompts that will help you join the conversation and learn how to get re-tweeted. As models, we’ll share great tweets from elite tweeters who have built their reputations in 140 characters or less.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/re-tweet-after-me/">More Info</a>

<strong>Date: June 9, 2011</strong>
<strong>Time: 4 pm - 6 pm</strong>

<form action="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr" enctype="application/x-www-form-urlencoded" method="post"><input name="cmd" type="hidden" value="_s-xclick" /> <input name="hosted_button_id" type="hidden" value="EBYCT3F8K9CQA" /> <input alt="PayPal - The safer, easier way to pay online!" name="submit" src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/btn/btn_cart_LG.gif" type="image" /> <img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
</form><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
<h3>Blog-O-Rama</h3>
How can you grow an audience for your blog? By writing great posts that people share where the conversation is happening—on Twitter and Facebook. Writing blog posts that make you part of the conversation is an art. You’ll learn how to write a snappy opening that gets people to click Read More, strategies to engage an audiences, and tips on structuring your content to make it easy to read—by both human beings and search engines.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/blog-o-rama/">More Info</a>

<strong>Date: June 9, 2011</strong>
<strong>Time: 4 pm - 6 pm</strong>

<form action="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr" enctype="application/x-www-form-urlencoded" method="post"><input name="cmd" type="hidden" value="_s-xclick" /> <input name="hosted_button_id" type="hidden" value="YCR8SX324BBA6" /> <input alt="PayPal - The safer, easier way to pay online!" name="submit" src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/btn/btn_cart_LG.gif" type="image" /><img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
<img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110401-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
<h3>Blog Yourself a Brand</h3>
These days, a blog is one of quickest and most effective was to build a strong brand for you and your services or products. Avoid bloviating or treating the blogosphere as your own personal megaphone by figuring out what your brand is first. We’ll help you identify the “authentic” you that other people will be interested in hearing about. We’ll brainstorm blog topics, practice writing short and long posts, and show you tips on writing your blog so that search engines find you, categorize your posts and push you up in the page rankings so the rest of the world can find you.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/blog-yourself-a-brand/">More Info</a>

<strong>Date: June 8, 2011</strong>
<strong>Time: 4 pm - 6 pm</strong>

<form action="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr" enctype="application/x-www-form-urlencoded" method="post"><input name="cmd" type="hidden" value="_s-xclick" /> <input name="hosted_button_id" type="hidden" value="FBDMRPJXQ2LDQ" /> <input alt="PayPal - The safer, easier way to pay online!" name="submit" src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/btn/btn_cart_LG.gif" type="image" /> <img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
</form><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
<h3>Writing to Think</h3>
Do you find yourself ruminating, cogitating and chewing the end of a pen while staring into blankness. This course will teach you how to let the pen do the thinking while you sit back and play. Bring a nettlesome problem to class: something you don’t understand, an issue you’re trying to solve, something that interests or bugs you, or simply a question whose answer eludes you. Through a series of writing prompts, you’ll learn how to follow the pen’s meanderings across the page and make meaning where you thought chaos reigned. This class is a blast. It involves a lot of writing, but the environment is low-stress and low stakes, i.e., no pressure. You’ll walk out of this class with new confidence in your writing and a tool to get at what you already know that’s buried in the rubble of your brain.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/writing-to-think/">More Info</a>

<strong>Date: June 23, 2011</strong>
<strong>Time: 1 pm - 5 pm</strong>

<form action="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr" enctype="application/x-www-form-urlencoded" method="post"><input name="cmd" type="hidden" value="_s-xclick" /> <input name="hosted_button_id" type="hidden" value="JBC6PCH3FCHVC" /> <input alt="PayPal - The safer, easier way to pay online!" name="submit" src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/btn/btn_cart_LG.gif" type="image" /> <img src="https://www.paypalobjects.com/WEBSCR-640-20110429-1/en_US/i/scr/pixel.gif" border="0" alt="" width="1" height="1" />
</form><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

</form></div>]]></content:encoded>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
<img class="size-full wp-image-265 aligncenter" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;" title="upcomingcourses-header" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/upcomingcourses-header.jpg" alt="Upcoming Courses" width="887" height="69" />

Classes are frequently added, so bookmark this page and check it often.
<div style="float: left; width: 70%;">
<p style="font-size: 125%;">You can attend a Two Pens course at our offices or <a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=866">contact us </a>about teaching one at your organization. We can tailor any course to meet your writing needs.</p>
<p style="font-size: 125%;">Our offices are conveniently located in Pioneer Square:</p>
<strong>Two Pens</strong>
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
206-321-0826
<a href="mailto:info@twopens.com">info@twopens.com</a>
(206)321-0826

<!--p style="font-size: 125%;">We also teach at other writing centers.  This month we're teaching a course at Richard Hugo House on how writers can create a social media presence.</div>
<div  _mce_tmp="1"><-->
<h3>Attract Followers, Grow Your Fan Base, Become a Social Media Thought Leader</h3>
Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks, especially if you’re a writer. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will provide examples of successful social media strategies of other writers and the content that made them happen. Course includes blog, Twitter and Facebook writing exercises. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences. Recommended for all writers who want to build their careers.
<a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=119">More Info</a>

<h3>Blog Yourself a Brand</h3>
These days, a blog is one of quickest and most effective was to build a strong brand for you and your services or products. Avoid bloviating or treating the blogosphere as your own personal megaphone by figuring out what your brand is first. We’ll help you identify the “authentic” you that other people will be interested in hearing about. <a href="http://twopens.com/courses/blog-yourself-a-brand/">More Info</a>

<h3>Writing to Think</h3>
Do you find yourself ruminating, cogitating and chewing the end of a pen while staring into blankness. This course will teach you how to let the pen do the thinking while you sit back and play. Bring a nettlesome problem to class: something you don’t understand, an issue you’re trying to solve, something that interests or bugs you, or simply a question whose answer eludes you. Through a series of writing prompts, you’ll learn how to follow the pen’s meanderings across the page and make meaning where you thought chaos reigned. This class is a blast. It involves a lot of writing, but the environment is low-stress and low stakes, i.e., no pressure. You’ll walk out of this class with new confidence in your writing and a tool to get at what you already know that’s buried in the rubble of your brain.

		<title>Thank You!</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/thank-you/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Apr 2011 03:06:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=923</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Thank You!</strong>

Thank you for registering for a Two Pens' course!  We look forward to helping you improve your skills whether you're writing for social media or business.  Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions about this course.  

Directions to our offices are below. 

Write On,

Emily Warn
emily@twopens.com

Cynthia Hartwig
cynthia@twopens.com

<strong>Contact Us</strong>
Two Pens
401 Second Avenue South
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
206-321-0826
<a href="mailto:info@twopens.com">info@twopens.com</a>
Two Pens' Phone Number: 206-321-0826

<strong>Directions to Two Pens</strong>

Our offices are located directly across from King St. Station in Pioneer Square, and are part of the offices of Cocker Fennessy. When you enter the building on the 2nd Ave. S. side, be sure to take the RIGHT bank of elevators (in the direction of Zeitgeist, the coffee shop in the same building) and go to the 4th floor. Turn left and walk up one flight of stairs to the Cocker Fennessy offices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>$50 Four O&#039;Clock: Re-tweet After Me</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/re-tweet-after-me/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 May 2011 17:20:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1167</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>$50 Four O'Clock: Re-tweet After Me</h3>
Don’t get Twitter? Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream? In this class, you’ll learn Twitter basics—its lingo, tools, and how to write tweets to huge followings. We’ll give you writing prompts that will help you join the conversation and learn how to get re-tweeted. As models, we’ll share great tweets from elite tweeters who have built their reputations in 140 characters or less.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

		<title>$50 Four O’Clock: Blogging 101</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/blog-o-rama/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 May 2011 18:30:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1193</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>$50 Four O’Clock: Blogging 101</h3>
How can you grow an audience for your blog?  By writing great posts that people share where the conversation is happening—on Twitter and Facebook. Writing blog posts that make you part of the conversation is an art. You’ll learn how to write a snappy opening that gets people to click Read More, strategies to engage an audiences, and tips on structuring your content to make it easy to read—by both human beings and search engines.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

	<item>
		<title>$50 Four O’Clock: Building Your Brand on Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/blog-yourself-a-brand/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 May 2011 18:47:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1212</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>$50 Four O’Clock: Building Your Brand on Social Media</h3>
Building a personal identity, or brand, is essential to using social media effectively. The first step is identifying the authentic you so you can stand out in the social media crowd. Are you a technocrat with more passion and knowledge about technology?  Are you deeply interested in film and want to build a reputation as an insightful movie critic? Are you a tireless advocate for a cause like water quality or Alzheimer’s research or people with chronic pain?  Whatever your passion, we’ll show you how to use it as a springboard to create a presence on social media that that grows over time.   


</form><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

	<item>
		<title>Learn Tweeting with Two Pens at Hugo House Write-O-Rama</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=1265</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 May 2011 17:49:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1265</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1276" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Writing by Hand © Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=1276" rel="attachment wp-att-1276"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1276" title="black nail writing" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/black-nail-writing-300x200.jpg" alt="Hugo House Write-O-Rama " width="300" height="200" /></a>[/caption]

Sign up for a dizzying day of timed writing and support Hugo House, Seattle’s premier writing resource, at the same time. Write-O-Rama, one of Hugo House’s most popular events, takes place on June 4th from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., featuring classes from more than 30 Hugo House writing teachers, including Two Pens. <!--more Read On...-->

Practice writing the world’s shortest memoirs, get lost in travelogues, try out an instant novel, learn the importance of the letter “z” and brainstorm great opening lines.

Two Pens will donate a class on Twitter tweets for this annual Hugo House fundraiser. You’ll learn to get noticed in 140-characters or less and build your social media reputation at Re-Tweet After Me, slated for 4 p.m.

Peruse the <a href="http://www.hugohouse.org/content/write-o-rama" target="_blank">schedule</a> and <a href="https://co.clickandpledge.com/advanced/default.aspx?wid=38432" target="_blank">register</a> for Write-O-Rama soon.

<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=1016" rel="attachment wp-att-1016"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1016" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>

PS: Your choice of turkey burger, veggie sandwich, or spicy peanut chicken noodle salad for lunch.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Classes</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 May 2011 02:28:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1345</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="clear:both;">

    <div style="float: left; width: 45%;">
        <h1>Social Media Courses</h1>
        <p style="font-size: 125%;">Social media campaigns fail or succeed based on whether their content is shared across social networks, photo and video sharing services, blogs, and even offline meetings. Two Pens' social media classes are unique. You’ll learn to create content that fits each social media space so well that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.</p>
  
    </div>
    <div style="float:right;width:45%;">
        <h1>Business Writing Courses</h1>
        <p style="font-size: 125%;">Whether your business needs more effective communications or you need to develop your writing skills and style, we can help. As the world has migrated to doing business on the Internet, it’s become increasingly important to learn how to write for new media. From blogs to email newsletters to Facebook and Twitter posts to web site copy, Two Pens offers social media classes that will improve your online communications.</p>
    </div>
</div>

<div style="clear:both;">

    <div style="float: left; width: 45%;">
            
        <h3>$50 Four O'Clock: Blogging 101</h3>
        <p>How can you grow an audience for your blog?  By writing great posts that people share where the conversation is happening—on Twitter and Facebook.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/courses/blog-o-rama/" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
        <h3>$50 Four O'Clock: Building Your Brand on Social Media</h3>
        <p>Building a personal identity, or brand, is essential to using social media effectively.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/blog-yourself-a-brand/" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>

        <h3>$50 Four O'Clock: Re-Tweet After Me</h3>
        <p>Don’t get Twitter?  Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream?</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/courses/re-tweet-after-me/" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>

        <h3>$50 Four O'Clock: SEO Content Strategies</h3>
        <p>SEO tips on writing social media content to make sure your content shows up on search engines.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/courses/blog-writing-for-seo/" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
        <h3>Closing the Loop</h3>
        <p>The creative worked. It’s gone viral and is driving traffic to your site. Now how do you close the loop with customers?</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=123" target="_blank">More Info</a>
        
        <h3>Content to Launch Products into the Stratosphere</h3>
        <p></p>Writing compelling and original marketing collateral for product launches takes elbow grease and lots of creativity.
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=322" target="_blank"> More Info</a></p>

<h3>Creative Nonfiction for Grantwriters</h3>
<p>A grant proposal is only as good as the program it supports, but one need look no further than the Declaration of Independence to see what can happen when a great idea is supported by powerful prose.</P>
<p><a href="http://twopens.com/class/creative-nonfiction-for-grantwriters/">More Info</a>

<h3>Cures for Attention Deficit Disorder</h3>
        <p>This course provides an overview of analytics-driven content strategies, then focuses on two web statistics in relation to content—the bounce rate, or time on site, and the referrals or entrance pages.</p>  <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=310" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>

<h3>Non-Profit Blogger Super Stars</h3>
<p>What can your organization learn from some of the most talented bloggers writing for non-profits and causes today? </p>
<a href="http://twopens.com/class/non-profit-blogger-super-stars/"target="_blank">More Info</a>

        <h3>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO </h3>
        <p>Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. How can you create an online following?</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=119" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
        <h3>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO for Non-Profits </h3>
        <p>Social networks are fundamentally changing how non-profits and the communities they serve communicate, collaborate, and learn together. </p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/courses/social-media-content-workshop-for-non-profits/" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
    </div>
    <div style="float:right;width:45%;">

        <h3>Business Proposals 101</h3>
        <p>We will break down the main elements of a standard business proposal and use hands-on writing exercises to draft a winner.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=379" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
<h3>How to Write a Creative Brief</h3>
        <p>Do you wonder why assignments to creative people often run amok? This course will teach you how to shape the sturdy box that’s needed to corral wild and woolly writers and art directors so that they can deliver work on target.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=371" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>

<h3>Seven Editing Tips to Make Your Writing More Muscular</h3>
        <p>So you have a rough draft and you want to make it sing.  This fast-paced class focuses on specific exercises designed to transform weak writing and make it strong.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=375" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
<h3>Tell Your Story in Words & Pictures</h3>
<p>Building an author identity is essential to building a writing career. What trips up many writers is not the paucity, but the plethora, of things that could define your brand.</p>
<p><a href="http://twopens.com/class/tell-your-story-in-words-and-pictures/">More Info</a></p>

<h3>Writing Practice 101</h3>
        <p>This is a course for the writing averse. If you’ve been told you can’t write, browbeaten by a fourth-grade teacher for not being “creative,” or otherwise abused when you tried to get your thoughts on the page, come and experience the fun of writing without rules.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=369" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
        
<h3>Writing to Think</h3>
        <p>Using timed writing exercises and prompts, you’ll learn how to use a pen like a miner’s light. Bring a problem or assignment that’s troubling you and we guarantee you will walk away with a solution that will surprise and delight you.</p>
        <p><a href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=367" target="_blank">More Info</a></p>
             

    </div>
</div>




<div style="clear:both">
<h1>Two-Pens' In-House Seminars</h1> 
 <p>We book in-house teaching seminars specifically tailored to your industry and have ongoing relationships with corporations. We'd love to work with your business or non-profit. You can choose from the classes listed below or the ones we’re currently offering this summer and fall. </p>

<h3>Applying Proven Direct Marketing Tactics to Social Media</h3>
<p>With all the hoopla about social media, many people have lost sight of its roots in traditional direct marketing. Course covers how to apply successful direct marketing tactics to social media channels.</p>

<h3>Book Proposals to Book Agents</h3>
<p>Convincing an agent to represent your book depends on writing a convincing proposal. Course covers how to research and write a proposal, and write a marketing plan.</p>

<h3>Content That Binds Online Communities</h3>
<p>Online communities stay connected through sharing information and knowledge. Course covers analyzing an online community in order to identify content required to participate in it.</p>

<h3>Creating Videos Designed to Go Viral</h3>
<p>Everybody wants to create a viral video, but only a few achieve stardom in the YouTube universe. Course covers how write a highly creative script and provides an overview of steps required to produce a low-budget, fun video.</p>

<h3>Jumpstart a Writing Assignment</h3>
<p>Everybody’s under pressure to meet on-rushing deadlines while writing effectively. Course covers how to generate ideas quickly in order to save time for spit and polish.</p>

<h3>Self Publish on Amazon via CreateSpace</h3>
<p>Digital publishing and e-book readers have upended the publishing world, giving writers new opportunities to publish. Course covers how to publish books on Amazon and how to gain access to the largest book distribution channel in the world.</p>

<h3>Social Media Rules Retail - or Does It?</h3>
<p>Today, social media marketing rules, but even it cannot replace customer touch. Course covers how to integrate online content with retail social media campaigns so as to get customers to click <em>and</em> walk into your store.</p>

<h3>When Is a Manual Not a Manual?</h3>
<p>Hefty print manuals are a thing of the past, yet you still need to give customers an overview of your new product, including its benefits and feature set. Course covers writing reviewers’ and product guides.</p>

<h3>Writing Readable Whitepapers</h3>
<p>Do you run screaming when the VP of marketing asks you to write a white paper?   Course covers how to develop a white paper’s structure, define its audience and purpose, and integrate graphics into text.</p>

<h3>Writing with a Model</h3>
<p>Great writers from Shakespeare to Hemingway have imitated the work of others to learn their craft. In this course, you’ll learn to analyze and imitate the writing of masters to improve your own.</p>


</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing for Social Media and SEO </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/grow-your-following/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 May 2011 20:10:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1378</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Grow Your Following: Writing for Social Media</h3>
<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>  This workshop is for anyone who writes for social media — whether to build their personal brand, or on behalf of an organization or company.

<strong>Class Description:</strong> Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.  Some of the topics we’ll cover:
<ul>
1. The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels
2. How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can 
3. How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared
4. Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite
5. Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear
6. Understand the tricks of writing for “findability” so your communications call out to the search engines 
7. How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</ul>


Supply List:
A lined notebook and two or three of your favorite pens. Pen tablets are OK, but laptops aren’t, if you want to get through to the well-defended heart.   No Prerequisites
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />

<strong>Date:</strong> July 26, 2011
<strong>Time:</strong> 9am - 4:00pm
<strong>Cost:</strong> $275
<strong>Place: </strong> School of Visual Concepts
500 Aurora Ave N.
Seattle, WA 98109

<a href="http://www.svcseattle.com/classes/grow-your-following-writing-for-social-media-summer-2011"target="_blank">Register at the School of Visual Concepts</a>
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" title="spacer" width="1" height="20" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Sizzling Summer Social Media Writing Classes </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=1518</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Jun 2011 17:46:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1518</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1521" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Summer Beach Reading © Anna Pepper"]<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=1521" rel="attachment wp-att-1521"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1521" title="Summer Beach Reading" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Summer-beach-300x229.png" alt="Summer Beach Reading" width="300" height="229" /></a>[/caption]

This summer make sure your brain doesn't turn into a beach ball. Sign up for social media writing classes at Two Pens. Our classes give you practice writing content that search engines will find and people will want to read--two keys to building a social media brand. <!--more Read On...-->
<h3>Summer Class Schedule</h3>
<a href="http://http://twopens.com/re-tweet-after-me/"><strong>Re-Tweet After Me</strong></a>
Learn Twitter basics: its lingo, tools and how to tweet to attract followers.
<strong>June 4: 4-5pm June 9: 4-6 pm July 14: 4-6 pm</strong>

<a href="http://twopens.com/blog-yourself-a-brand/"><strong>Building Your Brand on Social Media</strong></a>
Stand out in the social media crowd by turning your passion for business into a memorable brand.
<strong>June 8: 4-6pm</strong>

<a href="http://twopens.com/blog-writing-for-seo/"><strong>SEO Content Strategies</strong></a>
SEO tips on writing social media content to make sure people find your content on search engines.
<strong>July 13: 4-6pm</strong>

<a href="http://twopens.com/blog-o-rama/"><strong>Blogging 101</strong></a>
Practice writing posts that people will share where the conversation is happening--on Twitter and Facebook.
<strong>July 15: 4-6 pm</strong>

<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base-become-a-social-media-star/"><strong>Attracting a Following in Social Media</strong></a>
This four-hour course puts it all together. You'll practice writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook updates that will build your brand and improve SEO.
<strong>June 10: 8 am-12 pm June 23: 1-5 pm July 26 9 am-4pm</strong>
<h3>See our complete <a href="http://twopens.com/classes/month/"> calendar</a></h3>

	<item>
		<title>Writing for Social Media and SEO for Non-Profits </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/courses/social-media-content-workshop-for-non-profits/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 16:50:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1637</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>A Social Media Content Workshop for Non-Profits</h3>
<strong>Class Description:</strong> Social networks are fundamentally changing how non-profits and the communities they serve communicate, collaborate, and learn together. Quickly sharing information across a network contributes to successful advocacy campaigns and fundraising. Listening to the online conversation helps identify the latest trends and takes advantage of just-breaking information. Using networks to direct people to services or in-depth information helps organizations deliver on their promises.

But building a useful social network requires more than just putting up a Facebook page, opening a Twitter account, or even designing a great strategy. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook. We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing writing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever-widening audience. During the first hour, we’ll provide examples and analyze the strategies of non-profits who are successfully using social media. Then we’ll teach you how to write blog posts that get shared, tweets that attract followers, and Facebook status updates that build credibility and grow a fan base.

<strong>Successful Social Media Strategies for Attracting a Following:</strong> Examples of successful non-profit social media profiles and how they were built.

1.	<strong>Branding 101:</strong> Before making the leap to social media, it pays to decide who your organization wants to be. Mind-map and brainstorm possible public identities Write about the authentic attributes that set your organization apart. Identify how your brand will be reflected in voice, visuals, photography, and video.

2.	<strong>Trolling for Comments:</strong> Learn to write blog posts that ignite conversations. Blog writing exercises focus on crafting openings to get people to click Read More; developing an engaging and unique voice; and structuring and formatting content to make it easy to read.  Many examples of topics  other non-profits have used to generate comments.

3.	<strong>Re-tweet after Me</strong>: Witty tweeting is just the first step. Exercises on how to get re-tweeted by combining compelling content with Twitter tools (hashtags, round trips, etc.).

4.	<strong>Facebook Fanfare:</strong> Exercises on how to write status reports that get shared, including developing a Facebook style, topics that grow your fan base, and content formats to include with your posts.

5.	<strong>SEO:</strong>  It’s a balancing act to write social media content that engages an audience while simultaneously helping your content show up at the top of search engine results.  Two Pens and SEO consultant <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/"target="_blank"><strong>Dan Gayle</strong></a> will teach you tips and tricks on how to write compelling content within a format that search engines find.  
&nbsp;

<strong>Date: </strong> 10-8-11
<strong>Time: </strong> 9am-3pm
<strong>Place: </strong>Two Pens
401 Second Avenue S.
Suite 501
Seattle, WA 98104
<strong>Cost: </strong>$200

	<item>
		<title>Two Pens Teachers</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jul 2011 21:24:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=1719</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Two Pens Teachers</h1>
<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/portrait-iris-t/" rel="attachment wp-att-1864"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1864 alignnone" title="portrait Iris T" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/portrait-Iris-T-189x300.jpg" alt="Iris Taboh" width="147" height="234" /></a>
<strong>Iris Taboh</strong>
Iris has followed her passion for creating and teaching photography for over twenty years. Born in Brooklyn, she moved to San Francisco to live and study after high school. After attending San Francisco Art Institute, San Francisco State University, and Waseda University in Tokyo, she worked as a graphic designer and freelance photographer. Over fifteen years ago she started teaching photography and art to high school and college students. In addition to teaching, she has been very fortunate to have the opportunity to travel around the world and photograph people and places that have enriched her life. For more than ten years her home has been in Seattle, where she has taught and led workshops in digital photography and Photoshop for students of all ages and backgrounds.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/cimg0215/" rel="attachment wp-att-2205"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2205 alignnone" title="CIMG0215" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/CIMG0215-287x300.jpg" alt="" width="172" height="180" /></a>
<strong>ALIX WILBER</strong>
Alix Wilber is currently the grants and corporate sponsorship development officer at the Seattle Aquarium. From 2002 to 2011 she was grants manager and later program director at Richard Hugo House, a literary center in Seattle. She is the author of a novel, The Wives' Tale, published by W.W. Norton, and numerous book reviews for the Sunday New York Times Book Review, the Seattle Times, and other papers; and was a literary editor at Amazon.com from 1997-2000.

</div>
<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/lauren-wta-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1870"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1870" title="lauren WTA" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/lauren-WTA.jpg" alt="Lauren Braden" width="200" height="174" /></a>
<strong>LAUREN BRADEN</strong>
Given her passion for hiking trails, Lauren jumped at the chance to join the staff at Washington Trails Association as the Communications and Outreach Director in 2003. Lauren coordinates WTA’s media relations, messaging, program communications, and publicity. Lauren enjoys hiking, gardening, birdwatching, and traveling with her husband and son, and runs a travel blog in her spare time. Her favorite areas to hike are North Cascades National Park, Marmot Pass, Umtanum Canyon, and anywhere with lots of Ponderosa Pine.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/carla-saulter-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1942"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1942" title="Carla Saulter" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/trans_carla2-223x300.jpg" alt="Carla Saulter" width="161" height="216" /></a>
<strong>CARLA SAULTER</strong>
Carla Saulter has been living without a car-and using public transit as her primary form of transportation-since March of 2003. Though she gave up driving because of concerns about the detrimental effects of car culture (pollution, traffic, sprawl), the decision has profoundly and positively changed her life. Some of these positive changes include: enforced exercise, time to read, reduced expenses, and contact with her community on a level that would never have been possible in the isolated bubble of a single-occupancy vehicle.

</div>
<div><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-family: Helvetica; line-height: normal; font-size: medium;">

	<item>
		<title>Social Media Playbook Training</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/in-house-social-media-content-training/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2012 16:33:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?page_id=3677</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Two Pens specializes in social media content training for businesses of all sizes. We've customized seminars for Microsoft, Starbucks, Daimler Chrysler North America, the University of Washington, and many other businesses.

<h3>Writing for Social Media Five-Course Package</h3> 
It’s easy to start your own blog, or set up Facebook and Twitter accounts. But how do you get people to follow and interact with you?

Our five-course social-media package trains your staff to write content that gets shared across social media spaces and gets found by search engines.Then we show you how to put it all together in a social media playbook--a content strategy for planning a campaign or building a following across social media channels. 

You can choose the five-course package or create your own by choosing any combination of classes.

<h3>Re-Tweet After Me</h3>
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/2012-Twitter_20120518_6599.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/2012-Twitter_20120518_6599-150x150.jpg" alt="Blue Twitter bird" title="Tweet, Tweet" width="150" height="150" class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-3713" /></a>Writing tweets that get re-tweeted rapidly builds a following for your business. When you start out, Twitter can seem like so much noise. We'll teach you how to write tweets that help you join the conversation. You’ll learn Twitter tools, and then how to write different tweets for different purposes: marketing campaigns, PR, and building relationships for the long-term.
<h3>Facebook Fanfare</h3>
Participating on Facebook can accelerate building your brand because it lets you tell your story, and be responsive, transparent, and likeable to your customers. Our writing exercises teach you how to write updates that facilitate customer interaction, whether that's creating a poll, contest, or a teaser to a blog post or landing page.
<h3>Blogging 101</h3>
<div class="mceTemp">Starting a blog a blog is easy, writing and publishing posts for the long-term isn’t. You’ll learn how to generate blog ideas and turn them into posts that get shared on social media. Our blog writing exercises teach you how to keep people reading by creating a tone, telling a story, adding images, and formatting the content so it's easy to follow.</div>

<h3>Writing Sticky Headlines</h3>
<div class="mceTemp"></div>
Headlines are often all that people read when they're deciding whether to stay and read or click away.  Our headline writing exercises teach you how to write snappy headlines that set the tone, identify the audience, and tell people what they’ll learn. <strong></strong>

<h3>How to Write Content that Search Engines Will Find (SEO)</h3>
We believe high-quality content is as important as knowing how to optimize it for search engines (SEO).  In this class you'll learn how to balance great writing with SEO best practices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Where to Start</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/hello-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 10 Apr 2011 13:00:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http:/?p=1</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-19" title="Writer's Block" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/firstBlogImage2.jpg" alt="Where to Start" width="232" height="348" />

What do whitepapers have in common with Jane Austen’s <em>Pride and Prejudice</em>? A well-written whitepaper won’t ever top the best-seller lists. It won’t snare as huge a business audience as <em>Winning</em> by Jack Welch. Or a business book about Jack Welch, for that matter.
<!--more-->

But both Jack Welch and Jane Austen had to stop tidying their studies and face the blank page. Each had a goal in mind.  Each knew that braving the distance between setting the goal and writing a clinching ending was like stepping out onto a slippery log bridge. They could take the step because they had a measure of confidence. They knew from experience that crafty sentences lead to persuasive arguments and riveting plots, and that well reasoned business cases and page-turning novels captivate audiences, and that captivating audiences achieves any author’s goal.

At Two Pens, we know the hardest part is setting out. Our courses help you get beyond the first word. We believe that effective business writing—whitepapers that lead to signed contracts, creative briefs that reduce design cycles—begins where novelists and essayists begin: putting pen to paper and writing in a white-hot messy flow without regard for rules, grammar, or political correctness.

That’s the right-brain pen. It’s just as necessary as the picky, logical perfectionist pen. Once you have words on paper, you’ll know what you want to say. Then it’s time to craft your draft with all the tricks and techniques of the best writers writing today.

We, too, had to start here—to write our first blog post that starts a conversation with you. Check out our <a title="Two Pens Courses" href="http://twopens.com/?page_id=4" target="_self">courses</a>. They’re designed to turn the headache of writing into a pleasure.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-04-10 06:00:04</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-04-10 13:00:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>hello-world</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Announcing Two Pens</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/announcing-two-pens/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Apr 2011 23:28:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=985</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_987" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Photo Credit: Iris Taboh"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/coffeephoto.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-987" title="coffeephoto" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/coffeephoto-300x300.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

We like starting businesses. In the past three decades, Cynthia Hartwig and Emily Warn have launched or funded more than a dozen marketing, advertising and e-commerce firms, and non-profit organizations. Of them all, we're most excited about Two Pens, a business devoted to teaching people to write effective business communications and social media content.
<!--more-->

Teaching writing is our passion. We believe all great writing comes from working with the creative, messy half of your brain and the logical precise one. Emily is a well-known poet, and Cynthia is a published short-story writer who has recently finished writing a novel. Over the past thirty years while we worked on our poems and stories, we were also writing for national brands.

We've handled hundreds of editorial and marketing/ advertising assignments for Microsoft, Hewlett Packard, US Bank, Kenworth and Peterbilt Trucks, LA Cellular and Royal Caribbean, along with a host of non-profits, including from Seattle Opera to Pacific Science Center to Social Venture Partners.

What we've learned in our careers as artists and businesswomen is that art and commerce overlap.

While the purposes of business and artistic writing are different, the tools and much of the craft are the same. Both kinds of writers often struggle with getting words on paper. Clarifying and ordering one's thoughts, revising for variety and interest, figuring out the hook, learning how to keep the readers reading, are the challenges all writers face. Two Pens teaches writers to meet those challenges with ease and grace -- by showing you how to write from both sides of the brain.

Write On,
Cynthia and Emily
cynthia@twopens.com
emily@twopens.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>My Trajectory as a Writer </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/my-trajectory-as-writer/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 23:20:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=994</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_998" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Photo Credit: Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Trajectory-as-Writer-bridge-with-mirror.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-998" title="Trajectory as Writer (bridge with mirror)" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Trajectory-as-Writer-bridge-with-mirror-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a>[/caption]

I’ve been thinking a lot lately about my trajectory as a writer, now that I’ve finally finished my novel. What parts of my journey would be helpful to share with people starting out or midway between learning to craft a sentence and earning the right to call oneself a writer?
<!--more-->

Thoreau said he’d traveled a lot in Concord, Massachusetts (a town of about two square miles), in an age when most educated men went to Europe to expand their horizons. You could say that I have traveled a ways from my girlhood days of propping my feet against the oil furnace in our ramshackle cabin in Montana, reading <em>Susannah of the Yukon</em> and watching the snow drifts carve out a dreamscape of my own adventure stories.

Maybe Thoreau and I share a love for nonlinear exploration. If he circled the footpads of rural Massachusetts for years, I took the path of the recursive loop. After learning how to put sentences together (thank you, Mrs. Mikaelson, my eighth-grade teacher!) I would identify a skill that I needed to master, say scene setting, and then draft what seemed like a million scenes until I’d mastered that step. I would progress an inch or two as a writer, then find something else that was hard for me (say, dramatic structure) and practice some more before moving on.

I figure I must be 20 percent through the task list by now—on a good day.

It’s a myth that people jump out of Zeus’s head fully formed as writers, able to write like Shakespeare. Most of us stumble on a few things that we do well; the rest, we have to learn by trial and error. It doesn’t matter whether you’re writing for love, money, or business; you’ll advance faster if you inventory your gifts and work on the skills that aren’t as well developed.

Lately I’ve been working on incorporating Grace Paley’s practice of “surprising juxtapositions.” Paley is the master of jamming two opposing thoughts together. Here she is on childhood: “I was a fantastic student until ten, and then my mind began to wander.” It’s an interesting method; it’s one of the ways Paley achieves her unique voice. You, too, can juxtapose two warring thoughts in one sentence for effect. Give it a try and post your sentence in the comments below. I’ll pick my favorites and highlight them in an upcoming blog post. I might even juxtapose the announcement of the winner with the surprise of a prize.

Write on.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1009" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Talk to Me: Blogging Tips to Grow an Audience </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/talk-to-me-blogging-tips-to-grow-an-audience/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2011 16:45:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1067</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1022" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="© Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Talk-to-Me-megaphone.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1022" title="Talk to Me megaphone" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Talk-to-Me-megaphone-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></a>[/caption]

Do you remember what “blog” is short for? Web log: A daily diary written for anyone out there to read—not your private thoughts scribbled in a notebook by your bedside. Blogs were a revolutionary idea when <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorn_Barger">Jorn Barger</a> published the first one in 1997. Now there are more than 150 million blogs on the Internet. And free, easy-to-use tools such as WordPress and Blogspot mean that thousands more are launched by individuals and businesses each day. How can you make sure your voice is heard by the audience you care about most?
<!--more-->

One way is to make people feel that you’re talking one on one to them. People will stick around for a while if your blog feels like a table for two at a café. Begin each blog post as if you’re starting a conversation with a close friend. Imagine your readers saying, “I feel like she’s talking just to me.”

To help you set that tone, look for bloggers in your topic area who engage in a friendly repartee with their audience. All of us at Two Pens teach writing and are writers ourselves. Some of us have published books we want to peddle on the Internet. I discovered a writer-blogger named <a href="http://www.midgeraymond.com/blog/blog/2011/04/07/book-promo-101-the-virtual-book-tour/">Midge Raymond</a> who is a fellow writing teacher and recently published a book. Here’s what I learned from Midge about writing a blog post to engage an audience.

<strong>Tattletale Title</strong>
<ol>
</ol><ol>Treat your title as a front-page headline in 48-point font. Don’t rush to publish the post you’ve just finished polishing. Brainstorm a title that makes people curious. (Humorous ones work, too—people love to be entertained.) Midge Raymond titled one post “A Virtual Book Tour.” She piqued my interest—I’m a writer who wants to keep selling my book, even though my book tour has ended. Midge didn’t waste any time, and you shouldn’t either, in telling people what they’re going to learn.</ol>

<strong>Lead Them On</strong>
Once you’ve made people curious, you need to deliver the goods. Your first two or three sentences should start the lesson. What is the first thing you’d write on a blackboard if you were a teacher?

In Midge’s case, her first sentence announced the publication of her book, then told people to hold off on the celebration—her book tour wouldn’t take place for some time. This is a familiar predicament for a writer, one that reinforced my feeling that Midge was talking to me.

Midge then shared a solution to a common problem. How did she present it? By restating the problem as a question, and answering it in the next sentence.

Forgetting English will be reissued next week—on April 11, to be exact!—yet my official “book tour” doesn’t start until this summer, stretching into the fall. Q: So what can an author do when scheduling doesn’t allow travel between the book launch and the book tour? A: She can set up a Virtual Book Tour.

In one paragraph I’ve learned that Midge is a successful writer—her book is being reissued—and she’s going to teach me how to use the Internet to help sell it—she’s set up a virtual, online tour. Who would care about such things? Other writers. I’m hooked.

So how can you start building an audience? Use the title and first paragraph to let readers know you’re offering information that they want. Treat them as friends or colleagues who can’t wait to meet you and hear what you have to say.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1016" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-include</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-prio</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Blogging 101: What Should I Write About?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/blogging-101-what-should-i-write-about/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2011 18:30:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1095</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1097" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="© Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/crane-chair.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1097" title="crane chair" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/crane-chair-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

The number one question people ask us in our course on blog writing is: what should I write about?

There are as many answers to that question as there are writers. Our favorite solution that works for all is writing about what you<strong> know that your readers want to know about.</strong>
<!--more-->

Each one of us, by dint of living, has stored up a lot of wisdom learned along the way. Emily and I share unique backgrounds as both business women and writers, so we’ve chosen to focus our Two Pens’ blog on what we’ve learned about business writing that we think will help other business writers.

We might include peripheral information about rowing (we both row on Lake Washington for Conibear Rowing Club) or possibly, bird watching (I just got back from seeing sage grouse courtship in the Malheur Wildlife Refuge), but these incidental facts will only be used in the service of explaining something useful about business writing.

If one of us mentions the mindfulness required to sit tall in a rowing shell, it will be because this tip might help business writers prevent injuries from slumping in despair at the desk. If I describe the fascinating gurgling and popping noises that male sage grouse make by inflating the air sacs on their chests to attract their mates, it’s to provide an example of how a business writer can use specific sensory detail to ground their white papers and trade articles in the natural world.

Get the difference? I can’t just describe how sage grouse tails stick up like popping quills because it interests me. It has to interest you, in your quest to write more effectively to a business audience. By the way, that popping sounds more like a grunt.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Reach for it!  Registration Open for Fall Social Media Content Classes</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=1978</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Aug 2011 21:01:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1978</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1983" align="alignleft" width="200" caption="Fall courses at Two Pens are ripe for picking © Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=1983" rel="attachment wp-att-1983"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1983" title="fall class apple" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/fall-class-apple-200x300.jpg" alt="Statue with an apple" width="200" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

Fall courses at Two Pens are ripe for the picking. We’re continuing to teach our popular classes on writing content for social media, and we’ve teamed up with SEO expert Dan Gayle to show you how to move your content higher in search engine rankings. We’ve also created a brand-new class with photographer Iris Taboh to show you how to include enticing visual images that make people click. <!--more Read On-->

<strong>Classes for Nonprofits</strong>
We’ve added three classes especially designed for nonprofits. We’ll show you how to use social media content to grow your organization’s community—the key to running successful advocacy campaigns and building awareness of services and issues. Plus, two of Seattle’s superstar nonprofit bloggers will share their know-how and success in building audiences. Finally, Alix Wilber, an über-successful grantwriter, will lead a writing workshop designed to help you land the funding your organization needs.

You can also register for Two Pens classes that we will be teaching at <a href="http://hugohouse.org/classes/catalog" target="_blank">Richard Hugo House</a> and the<a href="http://www.svcseattle.com/classes" target="_blank"> School for Visual Concepts</a>. Both organizations just opened their online registration.

	<item>
		<title>Writing and publishing human content for human minds</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=2095</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 13 Dec 2011 17:22:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2095</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I just read this article <a href="http://www.seo-theory.com/2011/09/15/these-arent-the-meta-descriptions-youre-optimizing-for/">These Aren’t The Meta Descriptions You’re Optimizing For</a>, and I thought it had some insightful commentary that it would be useful for you to read.

Why I'm sharing this with you is that I hope you can avoid going down the SEO plug hole like everyone else who starts learning about the subject. Technical things on the page, e.g., nofollow, canonical, meta keywords, are subject to change, but relevancy and usefulness to the human mind will not. Don't train yourself to dance to every suggestion and gossipy thing you hear about SEO, and instead focus on writing and publishing human content for human minds. The main unequivocal truth about SEO is that the search engines are always, always, always looking to provide the most useful and intelligent results for a search query, and that they will always be improving that by making the algorithms more human-like.

There was one line in this article that caught my attention:
<blockquote>"Your Holy SEO Mantra for Meta Descriptions for the next THREE YEARS must now be: “The Entire Page Is The Meta Description”.</blockquote>
I agree with this statement 100%. What good is a meta description for a page that isn't worth reading? What good is an article that doesn't provide real solutions and answers to real questions? Google will read your content, and if it stinks, then no amount of meta descriptions will help. If the description doesn't match the page, the relevancy determined algorithmically, then Google will write their own description. The meta descriptions are only useful for click-throughs anyway, meaning that they only come into play on SERPs AFTER Google has determined to show your page, IF they're going to show it at all.

The idea is that SEO must be a holistic approach to the web. You must start and end with useful and distinctive content. It must be relevant, not to keywords, but to people. I've seen SEOs look at a page and say "you're not including XYZ keyword on this page. How do you expect to rank for XYZ without that keyword?" If you ever meet this SEO, RUN AWAY! Never ever ever plug keywords into an article. If you want to rank for XYZ in Google, then you need to write an article that is clearly about XYZ, provides distinctive information about XYZ, and satisfies the user intent of the person typing in XYZ.

<hr />

<small>Also, referencing Star Wars in your titles = win!</small>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>writing-and-publishing-human-content-for-human-minds</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="google"><![CDATA[Google]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="seo"><![CDATA[SEO]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_focuskw</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Writing and producing human content for human minds - Two Pens]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Commentary on Michael Martinez' SEO-Theory blog article "These Aren’t The Meta Descriptions You’re Optimizing For" article, plus advice ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key>dsq_thread_id</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Alix Wilber Teaches &quot;Creative Nonfiction for Grantwriters&quot;</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=2253</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Nov 2011 05:56:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2253</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ATSuFmDaPKs

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2206" align="alignleft" width="287" caption="Alix Wilbur, uber-successful grant writer, will teach &quot;Creative Nonfiction for Grant Writers&quot; Nov. 12, 2011"]<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/cimg0215-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-2206"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2206 " title="CIMG0215" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/CIMG02151-287x300.jpg" alt="" width="287" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

Ask anyone to define what a "grantwriter" does, and you'll find that most of the emphasis is on the "grant" part—i.e., researching the funders, defining the need, identifying the goals and objectives,
describing the activities, and outlining the evaluation process. This class assumes you already know that stuff is important, and you know how to find the information you need.
<!--more Read On...-->
This four-hour workshop will focus on the "writer" part of the equation, instead. We're going to send our inner reference librarian on vacation for a few hours and give our inner best-selling author
a chance to shine.

Activities will include group discussions, writing exercises, and sharing your work with your peers. After a short introduction to the basic literary elements—plot, character, conflict, setting, etc.-- we'll spend our time thinking about, talking about and practicing creative ways to apply literary techniques to actual grants.

Alix Wilber, an uber-succesfull grantwriter who has raised $600,000 for organizations from Hugo House to Seattle Aquarium, will provide some grant scenarios, but feel free to bring an actual grant you're working on. Be prepared to write like Charles Dickens!

Sign up for or learn more about Two Pens <a href="http://twopens.com/class/creative-nonfiction-for-grantwriters/" target="_blank">Creative Nonfiction for Grant Writers</a> class.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />]]></content:encoded>

		<title>The Subversive Copy Editor</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/the-subversive-copy-editor/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Feb 2011 20:00:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2382</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Carol Fisher Saller is the editor behind the attitude of The Chicago Manual of Style’s 16th edition. She’s an editor’s editor. Who else would say, “There are two kinds of people in the world: There are those who could be given this book (The Chicago Manual of Style) and not be able to put it down, and there are people who would, you know, rather slit their wrists than read it.”

<a href="http://www.subversivecopyeditor.com/" title="http://www.subversivecopyeditor.com/">http://www.subversivecopyeditor.com/</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Fremont Sunday Market</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=2422</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 19:00:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2422</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Fremont Sunday Market—a weekly Seattle neighborhood festival offering crafts, antiques, food, and more—typically posts “live” content on the morning of the market. It’s a great reminder and call to action.

<a href="http://www.facebook.com/FremontSundayMarket ">http://www.facebook.com/FremontSundayMarket </a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2422</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-15 12:00:18</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>Two Pens to Teach &quot;Re-Tweet After Me&quot; at Hugo House’s Write-O-Rama</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=2488</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Nov 2011 22:30:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2488</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2553" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="Two Pens will be teaching at Write-O-Rama at Hugo House Dec 3"]<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=2553" rel="attachment wp-att-2553"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2553" title="Write O Rama" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/Write-O-Rama-225x300.jpg" alt="" width="225" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

Sign up for a dizzying day of genre hopping and support Hugo House at the same time. This popular semi-annual Write-O-Rama fundraiser takes place December 3rd from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hugo House’s writing teachers will offer more than 30 one-hour workshops. And Emily Warn will represent Two Pens by teaching Re-Tweet After Me by popular demand at both 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. Now’s your chance to learn how to use Twitter to build an author platform!

Peruse the classes here and <a href="http://hugohouse.org/write-o-rama" target="_blank">register</a> before it fills up.

&nbsp;
&nbsp;

<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/2011-emily-warn-signature-with-contrast-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1666"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1666" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>

PS The best way to distress your holidays is to write your way through them.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Postscript</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/postscript/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 02 Dec 2012 13:00:55 +0000</pubDate>

The postscript.

P.S. Works in blog posts and emails too.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Do you still need a business card in a social world? (Short answer: Yes.)</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?p=4205</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4205</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4208" align="alignnone" width="720"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Slide12.jpg" alt="" title="Anatomy of a Social Business Card" width="720" height="540" class="size-full wp-image-4208" /> Visual prioritization is the key to a well-designed business card. These elements are required.[/caption]

Last March, the LA Times reported that Passing Out Business Cards is Quickly Becoming Passe. <a href="http://articles.latimes.com/2012/mar/16/business/la-fi-business-cards-20120316" title=""Passing Out Business Cards is Quickly Becoming Passe""></a> Reporter Matt Stevens's opening line: “Chalk up another looming casualty of the Internet age: business cards.”) 

<h3>If business cards are dead, how come the corpse is rolling in revenue?</h3>

According to Statistic Brain <a href="http://www.statisticbrain.com/business-card-statistics/" title="Statistic Brain"></a> 10 billion business cards are printed annually. That’s 27, 397,260 cards that spin off the thermography presses every day. 

It’s true, as the LA Times reported, that this year’s annual revenue of $211 million has declined—-off 6% since 2006. But what industry hasn’t gone down since the financial meltdown?

More troubling than the dip in business card revenue is where those 10 billion cards end up. Statistic Brain says that 88% are tossed within a week of receipt. With all this paper and ink going into the garbage, you might well ask, why not get rid of this wasteful and resource-chewing habit? 

<h3>A business card is still your hard copy in a virtual world.</h3>

People love our Two Pens business cards. Every time I give one out, they either exclaim over our double-nibbed pen logo or they flip it over and read one of writing tips we print on the back. (Sometimes, they ask me for two or three cards so they can read more tips.)

More is going on with this business card love than a nifty logo design by Michael Thomas (link) or the cool factor of 50 different writing tips on the back, compliments of Moo.com and its customized printing options.

You might be aware of the moviemaker’s trick of showing an object to reflect the emotions of the character. Think of the diamond necklace in The Titanic  that Rose, the heroine, flings into the ocean; or the iron lung shown in The Sessions that both emprisons and extends the life of <a href="http://www.snagfilms.com/films/title/breathing_lessons" title="Mark O'Brien, the sex-starved (and paralyzed) hero "></a>

For those of us who don’t have movie lives, a business card operates as our personal object, or surrogate in the world. You hand a card to someone you meet as both an introduction to who you are—-and a way to get in touch with you. They hold the card in their hands and via the magic of metaphor, the card becomes you in two-dimensional form.

<h3>Today’s business card need a few “social” tweaks.</h3> 
<h3>Do’s for a "social" business card</h3>

Nice heavy stock says you’re not a cheap skate

Great logo type shows your aesthetic taste

Tag line tells what you do

Name and title identifies who you are and what you do

Phone number and email (or social networks)say how to get in touch

Include a QR code for sharing.

Consider how to use the back for more real estate.


<h3>Don’ts to prevent card read errors</h3>



Some optional maybe’s to consider]]></content:encoded>
