	<item>
		<title>Why Online Dictionaries Suck </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/why-online-dictionaries-suck/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 May 2011 00:07:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1134</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1515" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Stockholm Public Library © Anna Pepper"]<a href="http://twopens.com/why-online-dictionaries-suck/dsc01872-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1515"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1515" title="Stockholm Public Library" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/DSC018721-300x225.jpg" alt="Stockholm Public Library Book Stacks" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

Now what is that word? Countless times I’ve turned to Google for the answer. In the middle of writing a sentence, I rack my brain for a more zesty word than the bland one staring back at me. Frustrated, I type my word plus the term “synonym” into Google’s search box. Up pop ten different links to ten different online dictionaries. But all of their definitions are white bread when compared to the sprouted wheat bread of real dictionaries. Here’s one example of why, when you’re stuck—writing or reading,you should close onlinedictionary.com and pull <em>Webster’s</em> off the shelf.
<!--more-->

This morning I was reading a poem by <a href="http://www.poetryfoundation.org/bio/c-k-williams">C. K. Williams</a> in his book <em>Tar</em>. (For those of you who don’t know Williams’s work, he writes gritty urban narratives that show you how to turn the lanky prose rhythms of sentences into poems.) In the first line of “From My Windows,” the speaker leans on a windowsill, looking out at a street scene, and inhales the first scent of spring after a wretched winter. He describes spring’s scent as “sweet, laminar and complex.” Now what the heck is “laminar”?

I open my favorite dictionary—the <em>Shorter Oxford English Dictionary</em>—and the definitions lead me in three or four or maybe even ten directions at once—kind of like the multiplier effect of a social network such as Facebook, where you share a photograph with a few friends, and they share it with their friends, who share it with their friends, and so on.

I discover that “laminar” is a term used in the fields of botany and physics. In botany, laminar can be a flat leaf or thallus. In physics, the term means the normal flow of a liquid. I guess that knowing what “thallus” means would help me better understand the poem. My hunch is correct. The root of “thallus” is a Greek word that means “to bloom.” Its more modern, botanical definition is a category of plants, such as lichens, that are not “differentiated into stem and leaves” and lack “true roots or a vascular system.” This helps explain the poem to me. C.K. Williams’s spring has a fragile foothold after winter. It’s about to happen, about to bloom, but right now there’s only a hint of it, a scent on the wind.

Each word in a good dictionary functions like a web page, a tiny information store in the measureless data-cloud of language. Looking up a word can take me on a journey. Sometimes I travel so far from the original definition that it’s tricky finding my way back. Hours pass. But this never feels like a waste of time, the way surfing the web does. The definitions add to my own virtual store of words. They become keyholes into worlds and fields I’ll never ever master—physics, botany, metallurgy, or lacrosse. They make me a better writer and reader.

Online dictionaries direct you down a freeway. Just for curiosity’s sake, I look up “laminar” in <a href="http://www.freedictionary.com/">www.freedictionary.com</a>. There’s only one definition: “a motion of a fluid in which parallel layers have different velocities relative to each other.” A physics major might find that useful, but this poetry reader and writer did not.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1016" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1134</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-05-17 17:07:28</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-05-18 00:07:28</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>why-online-dictionaries-suck</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="dictionaries-2"><![CDATA[dictionaries]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="famous-american-poets"><![CDATA[famous American poets]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="grammar-usage"><![CDATA[Grammar &amp; Usage]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="libraries"><![CDATA[libraries]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="oxford-english-dictionaries"><![CDATA[Oxford English dictionaries]]></category>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_focuskw</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[online dictionaries]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_title</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-noindex</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_canonical</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_redirect</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metakeywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Use Role Models for Better Business Writing</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Jun 2011 18:09:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1611</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1620" align="alignnone" width="239" caption="Shakespeare in Business © Anna Pepper"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1620" title="Shakespeare_with_tie_cropped" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Shakespeare_with_tie_cropped-239x300.png" alt="Shakespeare used role models in many of his plays." width="239" height="300" />[/caption]

<strong>If you wish you’d written something, use its form or structure as a model.</strong> Imitation isn’t just the sincerest form of flattery. It’s the quickest way to write better business proposals, blog posts, or tweets. Take apart any piece of good business writing—really study its structure—and you will learn a lot about how to hook your reader, present arguments for or against, and sustain interest just as the role model does.
<!--more-->

<strong>Once you know how a role model works, re-create its moves.</strong> Form is universal. Think of a symphony if you’re worried about copying or stealing: Mozart, Haydn, and Beethoven all used the symphonic form or structure, but not one of them copied the others’ music. A still life of radishes and onions from an ancient Egyptian tomb will never be mistaken for some Cubist pears. So, too, a Supreme Court argument written by John Roberts, a master of legal clarity, can use the same form as an article for PETA that builds the case for animal rights.

<strong>Form is universal in art and business.</strong> Think of form as the container for your ideas. How you use the form, and what content you pour in, is individual to you. Most business proposals, for example, use the same format for expressing goals, objectives, target audiences, strategies, and tactics. However, the business proposal for the Apple iPad looks nothing like the business proposal for a Lifepak heart defibrillator.

<strong>Using writing role models is not stealing.</strong> It is not even copying. Shakespeare “borrowed” stories from Holinshed’s Chronicles many times during his playwriting career. No one presumes to call him unoriginal. Into his sixties, Bach copied note for note the “new” music of Verdi, a musician thirty years his junior, in order to learn the popular music of the day. Artists from Michelangelo to Titian to Gauguin apprenticed as painters by drawing the works of older, more experienced artists in order to learn the masters’ tricks of perspective, light play, and expressive use of color. Why shouldn’t you imitate the structure of the blog posts of Susan Orlean and learn from the best?

[caption id="attachment_1623" align="alignleft" width="214" caption="Tamara Sellman&#39;s blog, The Writer&#39;s Rainbow, is a great writer&#39;s resource."]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1623" title="2011Apr10_tamarasellman" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011Apr10_tamarasellman-214x300.jpg" alt="" width="214" height="300" />[/caption]

<strong>When you find good writing, model it.</strong> Lately, Emily and I have been reading blogs we admire in order to figure out what gets read and commented on in the blogosphere. We like Tamara Sellman’s blog Writer’s Rainbow, for example, because Tamara does a great job of sharing writing resources and information. She continually gives the gift of relevant information to her readers. You, too, can read Writer’s Rainbow not just for what Tamara says but also for how she shares with her readers the gift of her knowledge, the writing resources she finds along the way, and her passion for writing.

<strong>Tweets are sweeter when you model the elite.</strong> In Twitterland, I love to check in on Andy Borowitz, not just to be entertained but also to learn from his lightning-fast interplay with pop culture and the issues of the day. Andy’s reaction to the news of Donald Trump’s decision not to run for president, for instance: “With 9% unemployment, I’m not sure the US would have elected a president whose catchphrase was ‘You’re fired!’”

When writing gets you thinking, try to beat the authors at their game, using all the tricks they’re using. It’s a time-honored tradition.

Write on.

<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Saving the World One Bus Ride At a Time</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2011 18:45:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1656</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1663" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Seattle Bus © Anna Pepper"]<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/bus1a/" rel="attachment wp-att-1663"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1663" title="Bus1a" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Bus1a-300x224.jpg" alt="Bus Chick" width="300" height="224" /></a>[/caption]

<strong>You Know You’re a Bus Chick If …</strong>
I copied that line from one of the most successful bloggers who write about boring topics—though I’m sure not all of you think riding buses is boring. Carla Saulter certainly doesn’t. On her <a title="Bus Chick blog" href="http://www.buschick.com/">Bus Chick blog</a>, which was first published by the Seattle P-I, Saulter uses her wit to teach us the positive effects of giving up your car: as Saulter puts it, “enforced exercise, time to read, reduced expenses, and contact with her community on a level that would never have been possible in the isolated bubble of a single-occupancy vehicle.”
<!--more-->

<strong>Bus-Talk Blogging Tips</strong>
Why does Saulter succeed at saving the world one bus ride at a time when years of back-of-the-bus ads and glossy direct mail from your transit authority haven’t? She really cares about her subject matter, she loves writing and knows how to format it for the web, and she’s both entertaining and informative—kind of like the Click and Clack brothers on public radio’s <a href="Cartalk.com">Car Talk</a>.

<strong>Blog Your Beliefs</strong>
We believe in Saulter’s belief in riding buses. Someone who leaves lunch with a friend before she’s “had the chance to say a proper goodbye” rather than miss her bus is truly dedicated to relying on public transportation. Over coffee, she told me that at first, blogging seemed like a hobby. After all, she was writing about a topic she’s passionate about. You can say the same thing about Andrew Sullivan <a href="http://andrewsullivan.thedailybeast.com/">(The Dish)</a>, Jessica Crispin <a href="bookslut.com">(Bookslut)</a>, Cliff Mass <a href="cliffmass.blogspot.com">(Weather Blog)</a>, or Gideon Rosenblatt <a href="cliffmass.blogspot.com">(Alchemy of Change)</a>.

<strong>Make ’Em Learn and Laugh</strong>
Saulter’s series of posts titled <a href="http://blog.seattlepi.com/buschick/2008/03/12/you-know-youre-a-bus-chick-if--/">“You Know You’re a Bus Chick If …”</a> is a long-running list of humorous insider advice that establishes her authority and makes you want to join the club:
• You’ve traveled with an item that casual riders would consider bizarre (some examples: a chair, shelving, a backpack full of change).
• You’ve memorized the locations of public (or not-so-public) restrooms on your regular routes.
• You have a bus pastime (some examples: reading, knitting, drawing [not so easy in a moving vehicle], eavesdropping) and carry the necessary supplies with you at all times.
• You have a favorite seat.
(from Part I of the series)

<strong>Did I Say List?</strong>
(See example above.) Saulter’s entire post is a single list. It’s easy to scan. Each line reads like a one-liner—you can’t wait for the next chuckle—a format perfect for educating. And it builds momentum that suddenly ends. You know you’ll check back for Part II; without realizing it, you’ve become a loyal reader.

<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/2011-emily-warn-signature-with-contrast-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1666"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1666" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1656</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[70]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title> A Writing Role Model in Action</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/writing-role-model-in-action/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Jul 2011 19:24:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1679</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1680" align="alignleft" width="239" caption="Shakespeare with a Tie © Anna Pepper"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1680" title="Shakespeare in Business" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/Shakespeare_with_tie_2flatten_2-239x300.jpg" alt="Shakespeare with a Tie" width="239" height="300" />[/caption]

A few posts ago, I wrote about why it makes sense to use good writing as a role model for business writing. <a href="http://www.waverlyfitzgerald.com/"> Waverly Fitzgerald</a>, a terrific writer and friend, sent me an example of role modeling in action with a pitch she just finished for her new nonfiction book, <em>My Year in Flowers</em>.
<!--more-->

“I just finished <em>Libation, a Bitter Alchemy</em>, Deirdre Heekin’s wonderful book of linked essays. When I read the back-of-the-book blurb, I realized this blurb could be used to help me structure my pitch for a different kind of linked essays.”

<strong>The Role Model
From <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Libation-Bitter-Alchemy-Deirdre-Heekin/dp/1603580867/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1309978611&amp;sr=8-1">Libation, a Bitter Alchemy</a> by Deirdre Heekin</strong>
<ol>“For many years, Deirdre Heekin has been creating an unusual, revitalist wine archive of rare and traditional Italian varietals at Osteria Pane e Salute, the nationally celebrated restaurant and wine bar she shares with her chef husband, Caleb Barber. Self-taught in the world of Italian wines, she is known for her fine-tuned work with scent and taste and her ability to pair wines and food in unexpected yet terroir-driven ways.</ol>
<ol>
</ol><ol>“In</ol>

<em>Libation, a Bitter Alchemy</em>
<ol>,, a series of linked personal essays, Heekin explores the curious development of her nose and palate, her intuitive education and relationship with wine and spirits, and her arduous attempts to make liqueurs and wine from the fruits of her own land in northern New England. The essays follow her as she unearths ruby-toned wines given up by the ghosts of long-gone wine makers from the red soil of Italy, her adoptive land; as she embarks on a complicated pilgrimage to the home of one of the world’s oldest cocktails, Sazerac, in Katrina-soaked New Orleans; as she attempts a midsummer crafting of a brandy made from inherited roses, the results of an old Sicilian recipe she found in a dusty bookstore in Naples.</ol>
<ol>“Musing on spirits from Campari to alkermes, Heekin’s writing is as intoxicating, rich, and carefully crafted as the wines, liquors, and locales she loves.</ol>
<strong>The Re-Write
From My Year in Flowers by Waverly Fitzgerald</strong>

[caption id="attachment_1694" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Waverly Fitzgerald"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1694" title="jillianbig" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/jillianbig-200x300.jpg" alt="Waverly Fitzgerald" width="200" height="300" />[/caption]
<ol>“For many years, Waverly Fitzgerald has been writing about slow time, sacred time and seasonal time at Living in Season, a newsletter which goes out to over 6,000 subscribers. An amateur naturalist and teacher of writing, she sets out to connect with nature by learning about the flowers that grow in her urban neighborhood of Capitol Hill in Seattle.</ol>
<ol>
</ol><ol>“In</ol>

<em>My Year in Flowers</em>
<ol>, a series of linked personal essays, Fitzgerald describes her growing appreciation for plants as she progresses from scientific ways of knowing plants to more tangible ones, and her attempts to make perfume, cocktails and decoctions from the plants that grow in the gardens, front yards and parking lots of her neighborhood. The essays follow her as she forages for lilacs growing in local alleyways on midnight on May Eve, prepares a feast of flowers for friends at Midsummer and learns to communicate with a Japanese cedar at a plant communication workshop at the University of British Columbia’s Botanical Garden.”</ol>
I think Waverly did a great job crafting her pitch. Now the question is, can you find a good business writing role model to help you do the same?
<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1679</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Beach Reads: The Chicago Manual of Style?!</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/beach-reads-the-chicago-manual-of-style/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Aug 2011 17:30:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1760</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1794" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Chicago Manual of Style Proselytizing in Seattle ©Derek Johnson Photography"]<a href="http://twopens.com/beach-reads-the-chicago-manual-of-style/cmos-5-169-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1794"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1794" title="CMOS-5.169" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/CMOS-5.1691-300x235.jpg" alt="CMOS-5.169" width="300" height="235" /></a>[/caption]

When <a href="http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/home.html">The Chicago Manual of Style</a> published its 16th edition, many copy editors worried because it was simultaneously published online, albeit by subscription only.
<!--more-->

To many people, <em>CMOS</em> is a boring compendium of everything-you-didn’t-learn-in-English-class. To editors, it’s a bible. Well, perhaps that term isn’t exactly accurate. It doesn’t fit in the drawer of a bedside table. (Its 1,026 pages weigh in at 4.25 pounds.) It’s by turns lyrical and whiny, hilarious and dull, idiosyncratic and pompous—which, if you’re an editor, means you can’t put it down. In reality, it reads less like a bible and more like a book written by the author of Leviticus, if that person magically morphed into Mark Twain.

So why are editors upset? Are they anxious that the online advent of <em>CMOS</em> will shrink the need for copy editors, as ATMs did bank tellers? I concocted a test to determine whether offering <em>CMOS</em>’s wisdom to the masses would destroy the job security of editors.

&nbsp;

<strong>Buying Tomatoes at the Market</strong>

I needed advice on a point of grammar. I couldn’t remember when to use “on” rather than “about.” I paged through <em>CMOS</em>’s index and easily found the sections on prepositions (5.189 to 5.191). But the answer I was looking for wasn’t there.

I did learn about the use and misuse of the preposition “only.” According to CMOS, it’s the word most often misplaced in sentences:
<ol>
</ol><ol>Compare</ol>

<em>I bought only tomatoes at the market </em>
<ol>
</ol><ol>[I bought nothing else] with</ol>

<em>I bought tomatoes only at the market </em>
<ol>[I bought nothing other than tomatoes or I didn’t buy tomatoes from any other place?].</ol>
A pleasant half-hour passed while I steeped myself in the definitions and issues of prepositions—but, alas, none of the material I read addressed my query.

&nbsp;

<strong>Go online. Go online! Go online? Go online?!</strong>

On the <em>CMOS</em> site, I searched for every variation I could think of to get an answer (usage of prepositions, “on” vs. “about,” etc.). The result was always the same—the information contained in the book. I gave up and Googled.

I clicked through a long list of grammar Q&amp;A sites, loaded with ads and big, bold become-a-member buttons. Their advice was paper-thin and uninterestingly written. Where was <em>CMOS</em> when I needed it most?

&nbsp;

<strong><em>The Chicago Manual of Style</em> Social Network</strong>

I tried tweeting: “How come, @chicagomanual, you don’t have a section on the use and misuse of prepositions? If I can’t turn to you, who can I turn to?” Dead silence. I posted my question in the CMOS Online forum. Dead silence.

Then a day later an editor on the forum asked for an example. I replied:
<ol>
</ol><ol>Would you use "on" or "about" in the following sentence?</ol>

She gave a lecture on recycled plastics or about recycled plastics.

More editors chimed in. Here was their chance to show off their punctilious mastery of punctuation, their quibbles about quotation marks, and, yes, their pointed opinions about prepositions. Here’s one editor's contribution to what had become a lengthy discussion:
<ol>Regarding the specific example given, I think you're all picking fly specks out of the pepper. Use "on" or "about"; it just doesn't matter. The meaning is perfectly clear either way. You could also say the same thing half a dozen other ways:</ol>
<ol>She gave a lecture covering recycled plastics. She gave a lecture regarding recycled plastics. She gave a lecture explaining recycled plastics.</ol>
<ol>Now, if you really want to rev up this "on" versus "about" debate, try an illustration like this:</ol>
<ol>"He gave a lecture on an aircraft carrier deck." versus "He gave a lecture about an aircraft carrier deck." Big difference there. Duck! Here comes the wing of an F-18 Superhornet!</ol>
To which another editor replied, “I once attended a lecture on the surface of Mars. 'Twas rather chilly.

We need you, copy editors. Even 1,026 pages of advice—whether formatted for the web or in print—can’t answer all of our questions.

&nbsp;

<strong>So which is better? Offline or online Chicago Manual of Style?</strong>

Both. The basic information is the same, online or off. And the <em>CMOS Online</em> forum allows all those eager copy editors to prove their worth. The print version, though, is beach reading for those of us who care about language. Listen to the book’s snarky advice about whether to end a sentence with a preposition, for instance:
<ol>
</ol><ol>The traditional caveat of yesteryear against ending sentences with preposition is, for most writers, an unnecessary and pedantic restriction. As Winston Churchill famously said, “That is the type of arrant pedantry up with which I shall not put.” A sentence that carefully ends in a preposition may sound more natural than a sentence carefully constructed to avoid a final preposition. Compare, for example,</ol>

<em>this is the case I told you about</em>
<ol>
</ol><ol>with</ol>

<em>this is the case about which I told you</em>
<ol>.</ol>
<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/2011-emily-warn-signature-with-contrast-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1666"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1666" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Seven Things I Know About Improving Email Effectiveness</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/seven-things-i-know-about-improving-email-effectiveness/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Aug 2011 20:30:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=1816</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1953" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Consider the &quot;end&quot; in Send"]<a href="http://twopens.com/seven-things-i-know-about-improving-email-effectiveness/send-image/" rel="attachment wp-att-1953"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1953" title="Send Image" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Send-Image-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

Email still rules as the communication of choice in business. Learn how to write effective emails and watch your performance review take a bump up.
<!--more-->

<strong>1. “Lick” it or not, email speaks volumes about you.</strong> Recently, my brilliant and multitasking business partner, Emily, sent out a simple email asking friends to "like” our new Facebook page. Except somehow the word “like” magically retyped itself into “lick.” Oh man, did we get response. I won’t comment on what was going on in Emily’s subconscious that spilled into her typing, but clearly, the difference between “licking” Two Pens and “liking” us is the stuff of office lore.

<strong>2. Email reveals your personality, work habits, and ability to think about the big picture—</strong>even when it’s about the smallest details. Typos, grammatical errors, “fuzzy logic,” and lack of clarity telegraph questions you really don’t want the recipient asking: “What is this email about?” “What do they want me to do?” And such missteps may provoke the response you most want to avoid: “Are they wasting my time?” There are always two parts of an effective email communication: what’s said and what isn’t said but is intuited by the recipient. Would you like to be thought of as a strong, clear decision-maker or a ding-dong?

<strong>3. “Send” is the most dangerous part of an email. </strong>Many people respond to emails instantaneously, creating a kind of knee-jerk culture. Being accessible at all times is not doing the receiver a favor: you wouldn’t run to the door in your ratty underwear, would you? Then why would you fail to check the decimal placement on a financial report that the chief exec asked you for? If your index finger is magnetically attracted to the “Send” button, compose your email offline in Word. The act of composing, printing, and questioning your facts will slow you down enough to save yourself from looking stupid or unprepared. Remember: there’s a parallel relationship between speed and screwing up.

<strong>4. Email gives you unprecedented access to upper management.</strong> Access to the CFO or even your boss is a double-edged sword. An ineffective, wandering email exposes your weaknesses, especially if you accidentally went into autopilot. Because email is a written, archivable document, consider it to have the longevity of a radioisotope. Unlike a simple walk down the hall to ask a question or clarify an issue, a mistake in email says, for all the world to see, “(Your Name Here) has poor judgment.”

<strong>5. Indicate what the email is about in the subject line.</strong> Effective email responders constantly scan their in-boxes for “important” emails versus ones that can be automatically trashed or left till later. An email subject line receives 2.3 seconds of attention to determine if the email is worth opening. Use the subject line to clearly tell the recipient what your mail contains. Don’t try to be clever. “First-quarter financials thrill analysts” will outperform “Whoopee!” And later, when your email gets archived, the recipient won’t hate you because she can’t find it.

<strong>6. One topic per email is more effective.</strong> Sure, people can handle more than one task if you lump them together. But multitaskers will often miss tasks that are buried in the middle of a list. If you split your “to-dos” into separate emails, you’re more likely to get the action you need.

<strong>7. Last in, first out.</strong> The old LIFO accounting principle really improves email effectiveness. Sum up what should be done in the last line. “Please pick option A or option B today.” “Provide the sales team with a feature-benefit list by Thursday.” “All PPT slides are due 3/15!” If you include the “date needed by” with a clearly stated “action required,” it’s impossible for the recipient to claim they didn’t know what was expected. Why? You’ve got the email to prove it.

I’ll write more about composing effective email to people who don’t know you (for prospecting and lead generation) another day. For now, email onward. (Just think before you send.)

<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" />]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Link Title and URL to Spark SEO</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/link-title-and-url-to-improve-seo/</link>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2060</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2054" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Link Title and URL to Spark SEO <br />© Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=2054" rel="attachment wp-att-2054"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2054" title="fireworks sparks" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/fireworks-sparks-300x200.jpg" alt="Fireworks " width="300" height="200" /></a>[/caption]

Last week a coworker and I argued about whether a blog post’s URL and title should be the same. “That’s the best way for search engines to find your content,” she said. Not true. Many blog publishing tools do automatically create a URL that’s identical to your title, but they usually give you a chance to change it. Here’s why doing so can improve your SEO.
<!--more-->

<strong>What Search Engines Look For</strong>

When search engines are trying to figure out which content is most relevant to what people are searching for, they look at the URL first. They bet that if the URL and the title are the same, the site will deliver the content the reader wants. So far my coworker is winning. But here’s the catch: your title, and therefore your URL, might make a great headline and promote your organization’s goals, but it might not be what a reader interested in your topic would search for.

<strong>Why You Need to Change Your URL</strong>

Let’s say you’re really proud of a clever headline you concocted. I loved the one I wrote for my recent post on Buschick, Transit Authority—a blog written by Carla Saulter about how to live without a car. My headline was <strong>Saving the World One Bus Ride at a Time</strong>, but my content was really about teaching people how to write a blog that engages an audience, even if the topic is boring. If someone searched for how to write a blog, Google would notice that my title and URL didn’t match and wouldn’t display my post very high in the search results.

But what if I changed my URL to <strong>How to Write Blogs on Boring Topics?</strong> And changed my title to <strong>Bus Talk Meets Car Talk: How to Write Blogs on Boring Topics?</strong> Since I included the phrase “write blogs,” the search engines will guess correctly that they should deliver my post to someone searching for advice on how to write blogs. Readers get what they need, the search engines make a correct guess, and I still get to be clever.

<strong>How Does This Work for Businesses?</strong>

Let’s say you’re an alternative energy company called Greener World, selling solar systems for the home. A person interested in comparing different alternatives googles “home solar systems.” Your communications department just so happens to have written a post called <strong>What to Look for When Buying a Solar System for Your Home.</strong>

So far, so good. But if you make your URL the same as that title, potential customers could feel tricked after they come to your site. They may think they’re going to read an article and instead find an infomercial. They may feel misled. You could change your title to <strong>Compare Solar Systems for Your Home at Greener World.</strong> You’ve helped them find information they need to make a decision, and you’ve been honest. They know who your company is, and they trust it.

End of debate.
<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/2011-emily-warn-signature-with-contrast-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1666"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1666" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>In Branding: Multiple Personality = Fractured Identity</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/multiple-personality-fractured-identity/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Sep 2011 15:01:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2110</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2117" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Fractured Identity <br />© Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/multiple-personality-fractured-identity/multi-personality-nick_20110919_2343/" rel="attachment wp-att-2117"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2117" title="multi personality nick_20110919_2343" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/multi-personality-nick_20110919_2343-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a>[/caption]

Most people join the online conversation knowing they need to brand themselves. But why do so many people fail to create a singular identity?
<!--more-->

Remember the story of Sybil, the woman who battled sixteen different personalities? In 1973, the novel <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Sybil-extraordinary-possessed-separate-personalities/dp/0446359408" target="_blank">Sybil</a> was an overnight sensation, making the term “multiple personality” a household word. (In fact, Sybil’s story may have been largely fiction; the novel was based on the case of a real psychiatric patient, but many of the details may have been fabricated or changed.)

<strong>Multiple personas cause brand fractures and failures. </strong>
Most people who fail at Branding 101 fail by trying to say too much. Think of all the people on the Web who feel compelled to tell you everything there is to know about themselves. I found the following examples on Twitter in a five-minute search.

<strong>Dominica Myers</strong> <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/mydominica">@mydominica</a>
Seattle, WA
Seattle based Communications Professional, Actress, Playwright, Songstress, Interview/Audition Consultant, Non-Profit Enthusiast, Country Music Fan, Jack's Mom.

<strong>Jenny Zenner</strong> <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/jennyzenner">@jennyzenner</a>
Seattle, WA
Healthy people, profits &amp; planet-vinyasa instructor, meditator, triathlete, marketer, sustainable farm girl, MoM of multiples mindfully navigating twinsanity! <a href="http://www.seedsyoga.com">http://www.seedsyoga.com</a>

<strong>Ric Frazier</strong> <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/ricfrazier">@ricfrazier</a>
Creating Globally. LA based
Papa de trois et husband, photographer, director, skateboarder, traveler, scuba, SUIT UP! <a href="http://www.frazierproductions.com ">http://www.frazierproductions.com </a>

<strong>Clark Kokich</strong> <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/clarkkokich">@clarkkokich</a>
Seattle
Razorfish chairman, bad guitarist, proud father, mediocre husband, aging baby boomer <a href="http://razorfish.com">http://razorfish.com</a>

<strong>Here’s a rebranding assignment.</strong>

Pick just one person from the list above and tell me how many things you remember (and remember, you’re trying!). I picked Clark Kokich, someone I know, and I confess, the thing I remembered most from his current list was “mediocre husband.” Hmmmm. Who does that say more about? Me? Or Clark?

I’m betting that if you were diligent, you probably remembered, at best, one or two things about this person you don’t know.

Here’s the next part of the test: what do you remember about your pick that makes you want to check him or her out? Nada? Here’s the dirty secret of the brand laundry list: a random list is an enemy of memory. That’s why it’s called a list—it has to be carried around in our pockets, because it won’t stick in our heads.

<strong>If you’re everything, you’re nothing in branding.</strong>

Look at the five laundry lists above, and pretend that you know more about branding than they do. Pick two things that interest you, and yoke them together into a brand. (Don’t read the rest of this post till you finish.)
Here’s what I did:

<strong>Clark Kokich.</strong> Razorfish chairman, bad guitarist. (Now that’s fun and memorable. Of course, I also like “Razorfish chairman, mediocre husband,” but that’s just me.)

<strong>Ric Frazier.</strong> Papa de trois et husband. (We’ve created a French family man. I don’t know if it’ll get Ric a job, but at least it makes him look like he’s got his priorities in the right place.)

<strong>Jenny Zenner.</strong> Healthy people, healthy profits. (This brand says she specializes in health and likes to make money. Hmmmm. Maybe we ought to give Jenny another try.)

<strong>Jenny Zenner 2.0.</strong> Healthy people, healthy planet. This tagline could be consistent with her URL at seedsyoga.com. I don’t know if it’s the brand Jenny would pick, but somebody has to do the dirty work.

<strong>Avoid splitting your personality by picking the self that keeps you sane.</strong>

For great examples of singular identities, look to the people you remember best. There’s a reason we all know their names. They’ve chosen subjects they’re passionate about, and they keep exploring them. Follow their example and pick an identity that keeps you interested for the long run.
<ul>
</ul><ul>Michael Pollan = responsible food consumption</ul>

&nbsp;
<ul>
</ul><ul>Maria Popova/Brainpicker = brainy ideas</ul>

&nbsp;
<ul>
</ul><ul>Maud Newton = book maven</ul>

&nbsp;
<ul>Andy Borowitz = topical comedy</ul>
The goal in therapy for multiple personality disorder is to knit the fractured self into one. So it is, too, in establishing a memorable brand. Isn’t life crazy enough without adding a multiple personality?

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Three-Second Rule: Writing Headlines for the Web</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/how-to-write-headlines/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Oct 2011 14:30:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2168</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2184" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="© 2011 Seattle Times "]<a href="http://twopens.com/how-to-write-headlines/manmachineheadline/" rel="attachment wp-att-2184"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/ManMachineheadline-300x225.jpg" alt="" title="Man&amp;Machineheadline" width="300" height="225" class="size-medium wp-image-2184" /></a>[/caption]

If you drop toast with butter and jam on the floor, you get 30 seconds. If a visitor lands on your web page, you get three. Thirty seconds and your toast is toast. Three seconds on your web page, and you lose or keep a visitor.
<!--more-->

How do most readers decide whether to stay? They read the headline. More often than not, that’s the only thing they read. Good headlines make people curious. They promise to educate, titillate, rant, rankle, gossip, or inform. 

In one glance, the headlines say, you’ll know what Michele Bachmann said to Rick Perry, how low the temperature will drop, or that a great author has passed. You click because you want to learn what the headlines promise. When they work, they’re as sticky as flypaper. When they don’t, you’ll Google.

<strong>Writing Sticky Headlines</strong>

Writing great headlines is an art, but you can improve your skill at it if you make sure to do the following:

<ul>
•	Identify the audience.
</ul>


<ul>
•	Set the tone: For example, decide whether to write in a humorous or authoritative voice. </ul>


<ul>
•	Tell the readers what they’ll learn.</ul>


A good way to start is to pick one website to learn from—one that’s written for a very specific audience. It can serve as your headline role model. (My colleague Cynthia is big on <a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/" target="_blank">role models</a> because “people learn best by example.”) 

<strong>Great Headlines Say “I’m Talking to You”</strong>

TechRepublic is one of the most popular sites for IT professionals. Don’t yawn. Its headlines make even chefs want to read its stories. It publishes a lot of what are called “roundups”: lists on just about every topic—the ten funniest dog videos, the five tastiest condiments. Lists are everywhere on the web, and I doubt we’ll ever max out on them. Even if you have, writing headlines for them is a good way to start practicing.

Let’s take apart two headlines from <a href="http://www.techrepublic.com/?tag=hdr" target="_blank">TechRepublic</a> to see how they work.

<ul>
1. <a href="http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/10things/10-wacky-it-office-pranks/2695" target="_blank">10 wacky IT office pranks</a></ul>

Who knew that the guy or gal who troops to your office with an Ethernet cable, or hijacks your desktop from some remote server room, played jokes. Instantly curious? Other IT pros are. If you’re part of that community, you think this headline is addressing you, the stealth jokester. If you’re not, the headline promises that you’ll get to join an in crowd. 

And you know exactly what you’ll learn—practical jokes that you hope aren’t played on you. 

<ul>
2. <a href="http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/10things/10-things-i-dont-miss-about-pre-ribbon-office/2707" target="_blank">10 things I don't miss about pre-Ribbon Office</a></ul>

This headline is more personal. It’s written in the “I” voice, letting you know the writer is speaking directly from her experience, a strategy that also establishes her authority. She’s been there, done that. As a result, the tone is not just personal, it’s empathetic. She knows that other help desk IT pros know that the Ribbon in Microsoft Office 2010 replaced menus, and they suffered helping users learn it. Along with sympathy, the headline also offers to teach them some useful tips that will make their jobs easier.
 
Using a handful of words, three in one case, eight in the other, both of these headlines set a distinct tone, address a specific audience, and forecast what that audience will learn. If a site for computer professionals doesn’t interest you, check out the headline treatments on <a href="http://lifehacker.com/" target="_blank">Lifehacker</a> and <a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/" target="_blank">Daily Beast</a>—and, boasting a little, the headlines on this blog.

<a href="http://twopens.com/saving-the-world-one-bus-ride-at-a-time/2011-emily-warn-signature-with-contrast-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1666"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-300x225.jpg" alt="" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" width="300" height="225" class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1666" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>how-to-write-headlines</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Your Bio’s Great, But Your Author Photo…</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/your-bio%e2%80%99s-great-but-your-author-photo%e2%80%a6/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Oct 2011 00:33:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2210</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1703" align="alignleft" width="210" caption="Cynthia Hartwig"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/cynthia-3-small.jpg" alt="Cynthia Hartwig" title="Cynthia Hartwig" width="210" height="300" class="size-full wp-image-1703" />[/caption]

Why do writers ignore the power of imagery when they set about establishing an online presence? Our very own creative director Cynthia asks and answers that question in two different posts, one on <a href="http://www.shewrites.com/profiles/blog/show?id=3506464%3ABlogPost%3A490153&amp;xgs=1&amp;xg_source=msg_share_post">SheWrites</a>, and the other on <a href="http://writersrainbow.blogspot.com/2011/10/guest-post-cynthia-hartwig-on-using.html">Writer’s Rainbow</a>. Cynthia’s an expert on making your visual identity work with your words to present the real you. (Just look at how well our blog photos work with the post--she’s the genius behind it.)
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://writersrainbow.blogspot.com/2011/10/guest-post-cynthia-hartwig-on-using.html">Using Imagery To Brand Yourself</a>
<li><a href="http://www.shewrites.com/profiles/blog/show?id=3506464%3ABlogPost%3A490153&amp;xgs=1&amp;xg_source=msg_share_post">What Does Your Author Photo Say About You?</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Guy Kawasaki</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/guy-kawasaki/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Aug 2011 19:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2416</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Very intelligent writer and business leader.

<a href="http://twitter.com/Alltop" title="http://twitter.com/Alltop">http://twitter.com/Alltop</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Case History on How to Multiply a Singular Brand Identity</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/carla-saulter-brand-identity/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Nov 2011 15:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2345</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1942" align="alignleft" width="223" caption="Bus Chick Transit Authority, Carla Saulter"]<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/carla-saulter-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1942"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1942" title="Carla Saulter" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/trans_carla2-223x300.jpg" alt="Carla Saulter" width="223" height="300" /></a>[/caption]<strong>We’re all multi-faceted in personality and interests. That’s why picking one facet to emphasize in a personal brand or identity is hard.</strong> Think of the task of branding like shining a spotlight on one aspect of your life. It isn’t that you can’t be more than one thing: the point is that you have to become known as one thing (at most two) before you can be known by your wider interests or experience. Try to brand yourself with multiple personas and all those facets will just end up as distant points of light no one can see you by.
<!--more-->

<strong>Let’s use Carla Saulter as an example of how a brand identity can enlarge over time. </strong> In 2005, Carla, a 33-year-old Seattle woman (young enough and hip enough to call herself a chick) began blogging about transit, a topic she cared deeply about. “It was a hobby at first,” Carla says. “Something I was passionate about.” Carla branded herself early on as <a href="http://www.buschick.com/" target="_blank">Bus Chick, Transit Authority</a>. Short. Snappy. Easy to remember. Give Bus Chick a hand for a stellar brand!

Her online profile from her old Seattle P.I. blogging days says,
<blockquote>“Carla Saulter has been living without a car—and using public transit as her primary form of transportation—since March of 2003. Though she gave up driving because of concerns about the detrimental effects of car culture (pollution, traffic, sprawl), the decision has profoundly and positively changed her life. Some of these positive changes include: enforced exercise, time to read, reduced expenses, and contact with her community on a level that would never have been possible in the isolated bubble of a single-occupancy vehicle.”</blockquote>
<strong>Fast forward almost seven years of branding herself as Bus Chick</strong>, while (in her own words) Carla goes “from a poorly informed transit booster to a full-fledged transit geek.” She starts out writing a blog for the Seattle PI, moves to her own blog at http://www.buschick.com and graduates to writing a regular column on Grist for a wider audience. Carla has served on many transit-related boards and commissions, including the King County Transit Advisory Committee, King County Executive Dow Constantine’s Regional Transit Task Force, and Seattle’s Transit Master Plan Advisory Group. Essentially, the woman becomes a walking… I mean, busing authority on public transit by walking the walk and talking the talk.

<strong>Bus Chick’s brand morphs to Bus Mom.</strong> Something else happened to Carla that happens to all of us. Carla got older. She married Bus Nerd five years ago and two kids she calls Chicklet and Busling came along. Now here’s the interesting thing about Carla’s brand. Carla is still Transit Authority, but her Bus Chick identity has enlarged to include her motherhood and the passion she feels about being a transit advocate to her little ones. She often blogs about the reality of busing with kids. Example:
<ul>
</ul><ul>Chicklet: “I wish the bus would do certain things.”</ul>
<ul>Bus Chick: “What things?”</ul>
<ul>Chicklet: “Take us to Uncle Jeremy’s house right now.”</ul>

Now, Carla Saulter is a fine writer with a restless intellect; she branded herself smartly early on and she’s grown up to being a Transit Authority with small children in tow; I’m guessing her identity may morph again.

<strong>Will Carla Saulter eventually become Bus Grandma, Transit Authority?</strong> It’s not for me to say. But, it’s not a stretch to imagine her becoming an advocate for the issues that affect seniors who can no longer run for the bus.

In the meantime, rest assured that Carla’s singular brand will continue to work for her, while expanding to accommodate her changing life.

May you find an identity that does the same for you.

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" width="300" height="150" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2345</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>carla-saulter-brand-identity</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Sound Experience</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/sound-experience/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Nov 2011 19:00:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2433</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sound Experience recently blew the lid off of the National Historic Trust competition. Their social media strategy, dedicated volunteers and crew made a huge difference.

<a href="http://www.facebook.com/soundexp">http://www.facebook.com/soundexp</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Unlike HuffPo, you can’t blog on Slate without nearly winning a Pulitzer for your other work. (Read Slate, too, if you want to study consistently fine writing.) My favorites are <a href="http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/browbeat/default.aspx" target="_blank">BrowBeat</a>, Slate’s culture blog, and <a href="http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/procrastinatebetter/" target="_blank">Procrastinate Better</a>, Slate’s “Guide to Consuming Culture.” Notice the catchy title—just as important as Google keyword ads for attracting an audience.

	<item>
		<title>Snide, Snarky, and a Handicapped Parker: Steve Jobs’s Dark Side Didn’t Harm His Brand Appeal</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/steve-jobs-brand-appeal/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Nov 2011 15:30:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2439</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2440" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Steve Jobs"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-2440" title="Steve Jobs" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/Steve-Jobs-300x207.jpg" alt="Steve Jobs" width="300" height="207" />[/caption]

Steve Jobs understood the value of using his own personality to sell his products.
<!--more-->

He was unafraid to show his crankiness or his inability to suffer fools. Stories about his snarkiness, his impatience, his obsession with minute design details are legendary.

Was there a method to his personality madness?

After he dropped out of Reed College, Steve sat in for free on a class in calligraphy and fell in love with this ancient art. It was the start of a lifelong obsession with graphic design.

It informed his first career at Apple, his later work at Pixar, and then his return to Apple for a second career. His perfectionist personality—he was known to make grown engineers cry at design review time—reflected his drive for design perfection.

What you saw in Steve, the man in front of the giant screen displaying his keynote presentation, and what you saw in the iPod and iPhone and Mac products were all reflections of someone who was unafraid to say, “This is me. This I care about.”

In our classes, we talk a lot about how to use the power of your own personality—your desires, your interests, your values and concerns—in both the virtual and the real world to create a compelling online persona.

Take a lesson from Steve Jobs and convey all of yourself. Not less.

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>If you want to build a nonprofit community, follow these social media trail blazers.</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/using-social-media-to-build-nonprofit-communities/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 25 Dec 2011 02:15:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2681</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1870" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Lauren Braden, Washington Trails Association"]<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/lauren-wta-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1870"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/lauren-WTA-150x150.jpg" alt="Lauren Braden, Communications Director, Washington Trails Association" title="lauren WTA" width="150" height="150" class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1870" /></a>[/caption]There are purist and non-purist hikers. You can tell the difference by what’s in the side-pockets of their backpacks. You won’t find any electronic gadgets in the purist’s. There are no iPhones or Garmin GPS’s that nonpurists' lug into the wilderness. Purists would rather connect with marmots on scree slopes than Jon Stewart’s tweets. But many purists in Washington State find remote places to connect to because they connect with the <a href="http://www.wta.org/" target="_blank">Washington Trails Association’s website</a> and social media spaces.
<!--more-->

The WTA’s website reaches more than one million people each year because of great content that’s created by both WTA staff bloggers and by hikers. Last year, hikers filed over 5000 trip reports about inspiring hikes, the conditions of trails, and which direction to turn if the trail signs are down. And not only do people visit the WTA’s website, they stay connected to the organization and to each other via social media. To date, the WTA has attracted more than 12,000 followers on Twitter and 15,000 fans on Facebook.

Because of its expertise in using online tools to get people offline and connected to nature, the WTA received this year’s <a href="http://groundwire.org/blog/recap-2011-connector-award-event">Groundwire Connector Award</a>. The Award is given in recognition of an organization that understands how “connection leads to inspiration and education, to strength in numbers, to the larger consciousness being permeated, and to lasting cultural and institutional change.”

Why are we telling you about an environmental organization with a huge social media following? Because Lauren Braden, the Communications Director at WTA, will be co-teaching a Two Pens’ class in the new year about how to use social media to grow a following. She’ll be sharing WTA’s story, and offering exercises to both understand your community and write social media content to knit them to each other and to your organization.

She’ll be joined by Carla Saulter, aka <a href="http://www.buschick.com/">buschick</a>, who started blogging about living without a car as a hobby, built a social media following, became a transit authority, and parlayed that into a career at a nonprofit transportation organization.

Why take a general social media class when you can learn from the people who know the trails and the road? To read more and sign up for the class on January 19, visit our <a href="http://twopens.com/classes/">registration page</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Business Blog Needs People</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/tip-for-business-blogs/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 03:04:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2707</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2788" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="An environmental portrait of Dr. Arnie Smith while he was chief scientist at Seattle Biomed <br />© 2009 Cynthia Hartwig"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-2788" title="Dr. Arnie Smith" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/smallarnie-300x200.jpg" alt="Dr. Arnie Smith" width="300" height="200" />[/caption]It’s a fact of life that consumers don’t trust corporations, particularly large, monolithic ones (think of AIG, Enron, and British Petroleum if you wonder why). So a business needs to build a trustworthy bridge between customers and its workers. A knowledgeable product engineer, a software developer, an IT expert, a recipe tester, a scientist, a home economist, a funny salesperson, or even a crabby bookkeeper can personalize your products or services.
<!--more-->

Pick someone at your company to profile on your business blog who feels passion for whatever your company does. Make sure you use a real expert and include a “credibility” bio that explains his or her expertise and how it was built. 

Show your readers what the worker looks like, with at least a professional head shot; I especially like photographs of people in their work environments because it makes them more real.

I really like the job that Chris Jackson, aka <a title="The App Compat Guy" href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/cjacks/" target="_blank">The App Compat Guy</a>, does for Microsoft Developer Network; Chris puts a human face on what is to some an inhuman topic. He talks like a genuine person (though a very logical one), avoids jargon and corporate-speak, and makes tough, gnarly tech sound simple—a real art. Because Chris provides help that readers need, he’s become a resource they return to, and as a result, he’s got a loyal following. Wish we could convince Emily, who curates <a title="The Microsoft Office Blog" href="http://blogs.office.com/" target="_blank">The Microsoft Office Blog</a>, that she needs to add real people to the Excel and Word blogs (I’ll keep you posted).

Even if your company is small, you have people walking the halls who can speak for it better than the typical “behind the curtain” voice of Corporate Oz can. Seek them out. It’ll make your business blog stickier, and you won’t have to give away a million freebies.

If you’d like our help in building a bridge between your company and your customers, tell us and we’ll weigh in here. And feel free to recommend us for content strategy and business blog consulting. It’s how we pay for our expensive writing habits.

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>We Love Our Copy Editor</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/what-is-the-best-dictionary/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jan 2012 19:48:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2721</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2730" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Sherri Schultz Copy Editor"]<a href="http://twopens.com/what-is-the-best-dictionary/sherri-schultz-photo/" rel="attachment wp-att-2730"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2730" title="Sherri Schultz Copy Editor" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/Sherri-Schultz-Photo-150x150.jpg" alt="Sherri Schultz Copy Editor" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

If you find a typo—or, horrors, a dangling modifier—on our website, it means that our copy editor, Sherri Schultz, hasn’t read and approved that piece. Sherri “polishes prose to perfection” as part of her editorial services business, Words with Grace, and we count ourselves lucky to be one of her clients. Wouldn’t you brag, too, if you had the same copy editor as Nancy Pearl—you know, the rock-star librarian who wrote Book Lust?
<!--more-->

I swear that Sherri didn’t ask me to pitch her. I’m introducing her because she’s wonderful and because I wanted to pass along her recommendation for a writer’s holy bible.

<h3><strong>The Best Dictionary</strong></h3>
You can’t be a great copy editor unless you have the best, most current dictionary. Sherri’s choice: Merriam-Webster’s Collegiate Dictionary, 11th edition. “It’s pretty much the standard reference in book publishing. It’s also available for online searching at

http://www.merriam-webster.com/

(OK, Sherri, where do you put the closing quotation mark if the sentence ends in a URL? Asking editors this type of question is like asking film critics which Alfred Hitchcock movie they prefer—each one is likely to have a different view.)

(Sherri says: Ladies, the Two Pens style sheet says you prefer to delete the “http://www.” from URLs—so I’d do so, then run the sentence in: “It’s also available for online searching at merriam-webster.com.”)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Who vs. Whom? Ask Lucy Ferris</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/who-vs-whom-ask-lucy-ferriss/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Feb 2012 05:36:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2886</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2889" align="alignleft" width="200" caption="Pollinate or Pollenate?"]<a href="http://twopens.com/who-vs-whom-ask-lucy-ferriss/work-pollenate-type/" rel="attachment wp-att-2889"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Work-pollenate-type-200x300.jpg" alt="Pollinate vs. Pollenate" title="Pollinate vs Pollenate" width="200" height="300" class="size-medium wp-image-2889" /></a>[/caption]Figuring out which one to use is probably the biggest worry for people who obsess about being grammatically correct. There’s good news if you’re one of them: Stop trying; the vernacular has won out. Too many people stopped using “whom” long ago. Or so says <a href="http://lucyferriss.com/">Lucy Ferris</a> in a blog post on <a href="http://chronicle.com/blogs/linguafranca/2012/01/13/whomever-knocks-on-the-door/">Lingua Franca</a>. She warns against hypercorrecting. “It’s not that ‘Whom shall I say is calling?’ is wrong; it’s that it sounds snooty.”
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Headline Writing 101: An Alternative to Hacking and Lacking</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/writing-great-headlines/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Feb 2012 18:07:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=2908</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I’ve been an advertising creative director for more than thirty years so I’ve seen plenty of great headlines. There’s a snap and crackle to a solid headline; a good one makes you smile; the truly great ones make you sit up to read more. Unfortunately, the blogosphere settles for a lot of lank and dank heads that lie spineless on the page. If you want to get read, the single-most important thing you can do is improve the way you get attention.
<h3>What’s the role of cleverness in a headline?</h3>
[caption id="attachment_2977" align="alignnone" width="618" caption="An example of an attention-getter headline (dare you not to click this one)!"]<a href="http://gawker.com/5879339/50-cent-will-tweet-a-picture-of-his-penis-if-the-giants-lose-the-super-bowl"><img class="size-full wp-image-2977" title="50 Cent Will Tweet a Picture of His Penis if the Giants Lose the Super Bowl" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/50-cent-gawker-head1.jpg" alt="" width="618" height="477" /></a>[/caption]
<!--more-->

Copyblogger says to avoid cleverness in heads and I say, “Bunk!” A headline that plays with language is a time-honored enticement to the reader to read more. It’s a sign that the reader is in good hands with this writer. Typically, an attempt at cleverness has to be vetted by someone other than you (that’s why they pay me the big bucks as a Creative Director). Shop the headline in question around to your friends and ask,” Do you get it? Does it make you want to read more?” If people laugh, smile or nod, you’re golden. If they squint or wrinkle their foreheads, try again.
<h3>Figure out the takeaway before you write a headline</h3>
[caption id="attachment_2976" align="alignnone" width="555" caption="An example of a straightforward “how-to” headline that does heavy lifting."]<a href="http://lifehacker.com/5879115/how-to-look-your-best-in-photos"><img class="size-full wp-image-2976" title="How to Look Your Best in Photos" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/how-to-look-your-best-in-photos1.jpg" alt="" width="555" height="381" /></a>[/caption]

Many headlines fail because they don’t help the reader decide if they want to read more. A headline that sums up the subject matter will always trump an oblique attempt to be clever. Before you write a headline, do a pre-write on the single most important thing you want to say. If you know what the reader will take away, that’s the standard you’ll apply when you choose the best headline.
<h3>Collect good headlines and emulate them</h3>
[caption id="attachment_2978" align="alignnone" width="541" caption="Gawker.com is a great resource for headlines. So is Lifehacker.com."]<a href="http://gawker.com/5879373/what-ya-mamma-gave-ya-is-actually-depression"><img class="size-full wp-image-2978" title="What Ya Mamma Gave Ya is Actually Depression" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/depression-gawker1.jpg" alt="" width="541" height="498" /></a>[/caption]

There’s a reason newspapers typically have one person write the article headlines. Writing headlines is an art that requires creativity, the art of compression and an understanding of what grabs attention. On your way to becoming a better headline writer, start collecting good examples. Study how ads and article heads work. Then use them as a guide when you write your own. And remember, the headline writers at newspapers and the Creative Directors at ad agencies who vet all concepts get paid a lot to learn this skill. It’ll pay off for you too.
<h3>Short is better than long, unless long is better than short.</h3>
[caption id="attachment_2969" align="alignnone" width="667" caption="Here’s The Write Practice in action with a clever approach to punctuation."]<a href="http://thewritepractice.com/how-to-keep-a-clean-colon-um-the-punctuation-kind/?utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%3A+TheWritePractice+%28The+Write+Practice%29"><img class="size-full wp-image-2969" title="How to Keep a Clean Colon" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/how-to-keep-a-clean-colon3.jpg" alt="" width="667" height="352" /></a>[/caption]

I’ve seen plenty of great three-word headlines and I've seen three LINE headlines that knocked my socks off. Good headlines can be any length, as long as they speak to the reader and pull them in. A short headline is revered by art directors the world over; but a long headline can often provide a compelling thought that shows writers at their most engaging and persuasive. I used to tell my copywriters to expand their repertoire with all types of heads: screamers, word play, puns, alliteration, full paragraphs, story-forms, and even none at all (the visual does the work). All the tricks of language are at your disposal; in this, headline writing is no different than fiction and nonfiction. It’s just a specific form of writing with a job to do.
<h3>Headlines take time and effort</h3>
Take it from an experienced advertising copywriter: the first headline you write is rarely the best you can do. Brainstorm a list of options without judgment and don’t pick the one you’re going to use till the end. If you have time, leave the list and come back to it with fresh eyes. (This is the Two Pens approach in action: first, you generate, then you edit.)

Two Pens teaches a great class on headline writing that involves a lot of hands-on practice. We’d love to come into your organization and get you headed in the right direction. Leave a comment or email me here if you’d like someone to vet your ideas.

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2908</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-12 10:07:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-12 18:07:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>writing-great-headlines</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-noindex</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-adv</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[none]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-include</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-prio</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_canonical</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_redirect</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_google-plus-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_linkdex</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[80]]></wp:meta_value>
