	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The New Stupid: Don&#039;t Let Google Dumb You Down</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/dont-let-seo-squelch-good-writing/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 19 Feb 2012 04:18:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3126</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://twopens.com/dont-let-seo-squelch-good-writing/3-headed-stupid-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-3179"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3179" title="3 headed stupid" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/3-headed-stupid1.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="285" /></a>

<blockquote>"I have been complimented many times and they always embarrass me; I always feel that they have not said enough."<br />--Mark Twain</blockquote> 

Imagine if Mark Twain optimized his content to show up high in Google rankings. (Or, for that matter, imagine if he thought of writing as “content”!)
<!--more-->

For those of us who’ve memorized the SEO catechism, we’d beg the search engine’s forgiveness for making the reader laugh. Twain’s SEO sin? Meagerly “keyword density.” The penance? Repeat the focus keyword three times:
<blockquote>I have been <b>complimented</b> many times and <b>compliments</b> always embarrass me; I always feel that <b>compliments</b> have not said enough.</blockquote>
The search-robot high priests would be happy. They would “know” that someone searching for compliments (heehee) would be humbled by some author known as Mark Twain. But in order to make a machine understand this sentence, the sentence has been made machinelike. If the author is a copywriter by day and the next great American novelist by night, she knows she broke a cardinal rule dictated by Strunk and White, the real gods of sentencing: Omit Unnecessary Words.
<h3>Flat. Dull. Dumb.</h3>
Hit-you-over-the-head-with-a-flatiron writing for Google is all over the web. The Copyblogger site and social media marketing mavens in general rate a sentence that repeats a keyword as five-star; writers rate it as garbage. Even websites for writers and publishers fall under the lure of SEO stardom. In a post on Mediabistro.com—one of the most reputable publishing industry sites—Jason Boog rails against committing <a title="Twitter Profile Mistakes" href="http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/5-twitter-profile-mistakes-writers-should-avoid_b32527" target="_blank">Twitter profile mistakes</a>. (Who knew that such a sin existed?) Here are the blog post’s title and opening paragraphs:

<blockquote>
<b>Twitter Profile Mistakes</b> Writers Should Avoid

While updating our Twitter directories recently, this GalleyCat editor decided it was time to point out some simple problems we’ve seen in many <b>Twitter profiles</b>.

Below, we’ve listed five common <b>Twitter profile mistakes</b>. If you avoid these problems, you will build a stronger following and help readers find you online. These rules don’t apply to personal, satirical or artsy-craftsy <b>Twitter</b> feeds.

What <b>Twitter profile mistakes</b> have you seen?
</blockquote>

Repeating “Twitter profile mistakes” three times, and “profile” and “Twitter” four times each, makes our ears ring—it’s language that deafens us.

To add insult to injury, Jason includes the phrase “in your profile” in four out of the five intros in the bulleted list. Even recent MBA hires know that if you repeat a phrase in a bulleted list, you should include that phrase in the sentence (or phrase) that introduces the list. He could have easily written an alternative to “What Twitter profile mistakes have you seen?,” such as “Here are a few common mistakes we’ve found in Twitter profiles.” Here’s his list:
<ol>
	<li>No description of who you are in your <b>profile</b></li>
	<li>No link to your personal site in your <b>profile</b></li>
	<li>No picture in your <b>profile</b></li>
	<li>No location data in your <b>profile</b></li>
	<li>Don’t protect your tweets</li>
</ol>
If he’d included “in your profile” in the introductory sentence, and not repeated “profile” in each of the numbered items, his post would have been short and to the point, and thus speedier and more easily understood by the reader.

Jason Boog’s writing-style bogies might be an SEO boon to his blog, but they further dim our minds to the beauty of language. And in the long term, writing for SEO alone won’t grow his readership of writers and publishers (or at least I hope not).

So the question to ask yourself the next time you write a blog post is this: Would you rather write like Mark Twain or an SEO hack?

(Next week: Web formats and writing styles that pay homage to two gods: SEO and Strunk and White.)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The New Stupid, Part 2: Turning Your Nose Up at Personal Branding</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/personal-branding-101/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Mar 2012 18:58:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3239</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3234" align="alignleft" width="231" caption="© 2012 Cynthia Hartwig"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Sell-By-New-Stupid-post-231x300.jpg" alt="" title="Sell By New Stupid post" width="231" height="300" class="size-medium wp-image-3234" />[/caption]

I just read an interesting, well-written blog post. Intrigued, I checked the writer’s About page to learn more about her before I subscribed to her blog. Here’s how she rewarded me:

<blockquote>“I hate to talk about myself because I never know what to say. If I have to talk about myself, I feel like I’m bragging.”</blockquote>

Seriously? I come to you with a desire to know more about you, and all you can say about yourself is that you’re embarrassed? The old creative director and brand consultant in me wanted to howl.

<!--more-->
<h3>Personal branding is not about you.</h3>
Personal branding is about being helpful to your reader or viewer. If you are blogging or tweeting or posting or pinning, followers have a logical need to know more about you. Readers have to decide whether you’re a credible resource and if they should come to you for future entertainment or insight.

If you shirk this task, you disappoint rather than help the reader categorize you as a wit, a word player, a chess expert, a world authority on Microsoft apps, or whatever it is that you offer your social community.

<h3>Branding is not selling.</h3>
Individuals often have an aversion to thinking of themselves as a commodity. “I’m a person, not a bar of Dial!” one of our students cried in a recent class.

But think of the reason behind multimillion-dollar brand taglines such as Nike’s “Just Do It” or FedEx’s “When It Absolutely Positively Has to Be There Overnight.” Businesses create brands in order to separate their products from the zillions of other products that compete for your dollar.

So it is, too, in our new world of social influence; we all “compete” with one another for time and attention. If you identify one or two things you are passionate about, you can become known for your expertise. As you continue to reward people who follow you with your unique knowledge and point of view, your name starts to mean something.

<h3>It's a short form of ID.</h3>
Whether you work for a company or are an entrepreneur, the principle of branding yourself with a singular identity is the same. You pick one thing you want to be known for. Here’s a short list of solid personal brands you can emulate.

<ul>
	<li>Jessica Crispin. <a href="http://www.bookslut.com">The Book Slut</a></li>
	<li>Microsoft’s Chris Jackson. <a href="http://msdn.com/b/cjacks/">The App Compat Guy</a></li>
	<li>Emily Koon. <a href="http://twitter.com/emilykoons">Writer, fear biter</a></li>
	<li>Meeting Boy. <a href="http://meetingboy.com/">I hate my job</a></li>
</ul>

<h3>A brand doesn’t have to be serious and self-important.</h3>
It just has to represent you in a single-minded way. So back to our embarrassed and brand-phobic blogger. Darn it. I clicked away and forgot to save her link. And so it goes with people who don’t set themselves apart from the crowd.

If you’re interested in learning more, here are some recent posts on branding. 

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://twopens.com/steve-jobs-brand-appeal/" title="Snide, Snarky, and a Handicapped Parker: Steve Jobs’s Dark Side Didn’t Harm His Brand Appeal">Snide, Snarky, and a Handicapped Parker: Steve Jobs’s Dark Side Didn’t Harm His Brand Appeal</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twopens.com/carla-saulter-brand-identity/" title="A Case History on How to Multiply a Singular Brand Identity">A Case History on How to Multiply a Singular Brand Identity</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twopens.com/your-bio%e2%80%99s-great-but-your-author-photo%e2%80%a6/" title="Your Bio’s Great, But Your Author Photo…">Your Bio’s Great, But Your Author Photo…</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twopens.com/multiple-personality-fractured-identity/" title="In Branding: Multiple Personality = Fractured Identity">In Branding: Multiple Personality = Fractured Identity</a></li>
</ul>

Two Pens will be happy to give you feedback on your personal brand if you comment here. We’ll tell you what’s working and make suggestions for improving what’s not. 

<a href="http://twopens.com/role-models-for-better-business-writing/2011-cynthia-signature-with-contrast-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-1618"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1618" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast-300x150.png" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title> The VIDA Count is Changing the Conversation</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/vida-count-changing-the-conversation/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 12 Mar 2012 19:32:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3321</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3337" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="VIDA&#039;s count shows that at major literary publications, including The New Yorker, it&#039;s better to be a male author if you want to be published."]<a href="http://twopens.com/vida-count-changing-the-conversation/new-yorker-vida/" rel="attachment wp-att-3337"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/new-yorker-vida-300x160.jpg" alt="The Count&#039;s number of women vs. men published in The New Yorker" title="new yorker vida" width="300" height="160" class="size-medium wp-image-3337" /></a>[/caption]There’s a small chance you haven’t heard the conversation that VIDA started in response to the Publishers’ Weekly list of the best books of 2009: it didn’t include any books by women. The PW editors offered a convoluted defense and VIDA started <a href="http://www.vidaweb.org/the-2011-count">counting</a> and hasn’t stopped. Each year VIDA tabulates the number of male vs. female authors published or reviewed in major literary journals. The disparity is mind-boggling and you know which way the numbers fall.
<!--more-->
The numbers haven’t changed for the better in the past three years but the conversation has. The literary world takes note of Vida's <a href="http://www.vidaweb.org/the-2011-count">COUNT</a>, including book critics of major newspapers and magazines—even <a title="Forbes on VIDA" href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/jasonoberholtzer/2012/02/29/women-in-publication-the-2011-count/" target="_blank">Forbes</a>.

And special kudos to <a title="Granta" href="http://www.granta.com/" target="_blank">Granta</a> for publishing female and male writers in equal numbers. That’s all VIDA--and women such as Cynthia and I--are asking for.

VIDA will keep counting if we keep supporting them during its annual fundraising drive. You can <a href="http://www.vidaweb.org/donate-now">DONATE</a> here.
<a href="http://twopens.com/?attachment_id=1016" rel="attachment wp-att-1016"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-1016" title="2011 Emily Warn signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Emily-Warn-signature-with-contrast-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>

Emily

PS You can read about the panel of women’s literary organizations at AWP in Cynthia’s <a title="" href="http://www.shewrites.com/profiles/blogs/is-awp-for-you" target="_blank">"Is AWP for You?"</a> post featured on She Writes, an online community of 19,000 women writers.]]></content:encoded>

]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Advice for bloggers and would-be authors</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/advice-for-bloggers-rebecca-agiewich/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 24 Mar 2012 17:09:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3406</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3416" align="alignleft" width="269" caption="Author and Blogger Rebecca Agiewich"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/Rebecca-Agiewich.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/Rebecca-Agiewich.jpg" alt="Rebecca Agiewich" title="Rebecca Agiewich" width="269" height="202" class="size-full wp-image-3416" /></a>[/caption]<em>Our guest blogger today is a terrific blog-to-book success story. Rebecca Agiewich is a novelist, journalist, and writing teacher living in Seattle. She got her big break in the publishing world when she started a blog called Breakup Babe in the summer of 2002 to vent about a horrible breakup and to chronicle her dating adventures. This led to <strong>BreakupBabe: A Novel</strong>, published in 2006 by Ballantine Books. You can read an excerpt of Rebecca's funny and fascinating journey at <a href="http://www.rebeccaagiewich.com/">www.RebeccaAgiewich.com</a> and find articles first published in the Seattle PI, OutdoorNW Magazine, MSNBC, and others.</em>

<h3>The four blogging musts</h3>
Blogging, like any form of writing, is a very personal endeavor. There is no one right way to make your blog compelling. What is most important is that you create the blog that is right for your needs and your audience’s needs.

But there are a few elements that are crucial to all successful blogs. Whether you’re writing about parenting or Disney, scholarly publishing or grammar; whether your tone is chatty, snarky, profound, or irreverent—here are my top four blogging “musts.”
<!--more-->
<ul>
	<li>Passion. Passion about your subject will help you commit to blogging and engage readers.</li>
	<li>Focus. The most popular (and financially remunerative) blogs have a clear focus.</li>
	<li>Consistency. Once you create a formula that readers like, they’ll want you to stick with it (this formula includes what you write about and how often you post).</li>
	<li> Voice. Blogging demands a personal, highly subjective voice.</li>
</ul>

<h3><strong>Promoting your blog</strong></h3>
It’s a time-honored tradition in the blogosphere to promote other bloggers. My own blog eventually became popular because *one* other blogger linked to it via her “blogroll” (or list of favorite blogs). Here are a few tips for increasing your blog’s visibility.
<ul>
	<li>Create a blogroll where you link to other blogs in your genre, blogs you like, or blogs that you would love to see a reciprocal link to your blog on. (Bloggers will see that you’re linking to them via their site stats, and, in an ideal world, link back to you.)</li>
	<li>Comment on other blogs and include the URL to your own blog in your comment.</li>
	<li>When you write a new post, link to it via Facebook and/or Twitter.</li>
	<li>Include the link to your blog in your email signature.</li>
</ul>

<h3>Want to write a book?</h3>
Blogging is a great way to get your writing noticed and build a platform for a book. But writing a compelling blog is very different from writing a compelling book-length narrative. When/if the time comes that you want to use your blog as a launching pad for a book, be sure to study up on the basics of writing a book in your genre.

While I was great at writing blog entries that were compelling in themselves, I realized I needed to understand dramatic story structure in order to write a long narrative. I tried pitching an idea for a memoir based on my blog before studying story structure, and again afterward. Guess which time I succeeded?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Make Your Headlines Work.  Add a Visual.</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/make-headlines-work-with-visuals/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Apr 2012 16:41:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3502</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You might be surprised to know that headlines are lazy. They often lie dank and listless without an interesting visual.

Take it from me—a former ad agency creative director with more years of experience than I care to admit: almost any headline can be saved with a great image.

“Real” copywriters—not the Copyblogger hacks, but the kind who work for creative agencies such as Wieden + Kennedy (the agency that gave us Chrysler’s “Imported from Detroit” campaign) and BBDO-Taiwan (the agency that created the Melchers Travel ad below), have used this technique for eons.

They combine intelligent headlines with visuals that complete the idea.

Let me break it down for you. In this ad for Harley-Davidson created by Momapropaganda, you, the reader, have to “get” that the six-year-old we’re looking at is a tattooed and bitchin’ Harley rider in the making.

[caption id="attachment_3504" align="aligncenter" width="900" caption="Momapropaganda let its photo of the Harley-Davidson buyer in the making do most of the heavy lifting."]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/harley.png"><img class="size-large wp-image-3504" title="Harley Spirit You're Born With It" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/harley-1024x682.png" alt="Harley Spirit You're Born With It" width="900" height="600" /></a>[/caption]
<!--more-->

Remember, the best visuals supply a missing piece of information when combined with words. When the reader can barely see the mom-and-child photo because the desktop is so busy, they “get” instinctively that it’s time for a vacation. And the lazy copywriter doesn’t even have to say the word.

[caption id="attachment_3505" align="aligncenter" width="1024" caption="Time to Take a Holiday"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/desktop-ad.png"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/desktop-ad-1024x644.png" alt="Time to Take a Holiday" title="Time to Take a Holiday" width="1024" height="644" class="size-large wp-image-3505" /></a>[/caption]

Great visuals are available everywhere these days, with the rise of Creative Commons on Flickr and many inexpensive photo-sharing sites. Just be sure to comply with the usage rights for each image (they’re always visible if you right-click the photo); it’s bad karma to steal something that doesn’t belong to you.

And just for fun, here’s a free image from me that’s dying to mate with a lovely headline from you. Shoot me your creative pairing and I’ll run the winner in a future blog post.

[caption id="attachment_3519" align="aligncenter" width="1000" caption="Traffic Cop "© 2011 Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/traffic-cynthia-hartwig.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/traffic-cynthia-hartwig.jpg" alt="Traffic Cop 2011 Cynthia Hartwig" title="Traffic Cop  2011 Cynthia Hartwig" width="1000" height="750" class="size-full wp-image-3519" /></a>[/caption]

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" width="300" height="150" class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Minding your editorial P&#039;s and Q&#039;s </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/three-great-editorial-sites/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Apr 2012 04:48:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3545</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3555" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="P&#39;s and Q&#39;s of Editing<br />© 2012 Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/ps-and-qs.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3555" title="The P's and Q's of Editing" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/ps-and-qs-300x225.jpg" alt="P's and Q's of Editing" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

I can say with complete confidence that all editors learn on the job. Some add tabs to The Chicago Manual of Style, while others dog-ear sections; my favorite one covers the use of quotations. Most of our bookshelves are weighed down with reference books and at least one dictionary. Then there’s the daunting task of learning to use the many copy-markup tools in Microsoft Word or other word-processing programs.

Lucky for us, leading editors and toolmasters offer their advice on blogs and websites. Here are three that we find particularly useful.
<!--more-->

<h3>The Subversive Copy Editor</h3>
Carol Saller has every copy editor’s dream job—she’s a senior manuscript editor at the University of Chicago Press and the editor of the Q&A at <a href="http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/CMS_FAQ/new/new_questions01.html">The Chicago Manual of Style online</a>. That would be enough cachet for most editors, but she doesn’t stop there: Carol writes for the <a href="http://chronicle.com/blogs/linguafranca/author/csaller/">Lingua Franca blog</a> on the Chronicle of Higher Education website, and she’s the author of novels for young adults as well; her latest is <a href="http://www.carolsaller.com/"><em>Eddie’s War</em></a> (for ages 11 and up). My favorite place to read her, though, is her own blog, <a href="http://www.subversivecopyeditor.com/blog/">The Subversive Copy Editor</a>. Recently she took on editors complaining about the Modern Language Association’s new style guidelines for citing a tweet. “Twitter is a legitimate source of information for scholars,” she wrote, not just “a wasteland of inane blather.”

<h3>Grammar Girl</h3>
There are dozens of blogs on the Quick &amp; Dirty Tips site, but <a href="http://grammar.quickanddirtytips.com/">Grammar Girl</a> (written by Mignon Fogarty) is by far the wittiest and best written. It has to be, given its subject matter. Fogarty’s tips read like tweets and her explanations like flash fiction. Her topics range from the simple to the complex, from the difference between <a href="http://grammar.quickanddirtytips.com/a-national-grammar-day-tale.aspx">“alright” and “all right”</a> to the <a href="http://grammar.quickanddirtytips.com/first-second-third-conditional.aspx">first, second, and third conditionals</a>. This range is how she has built a reputation on the web: both those who simply google for a quick grammatical answer and those who resist splitting infinitives will find what they’re seeking.

<h3>Editorium</h3>
Despite its name, <a href="http://www.editorium.com/">Editorium</a> is not an editorial shopping mall where you can buy grammatical reference books, get Strunk &amp; White on sale, or quibble about the overuse of exclamation points. This site is a site for the hard-core editor or freelancer who measures every hour by words tidied up or cranked out. It offers Microsoft Word macros that can help you improve the speed and consistency of your editing work. A macro records a series of actions and then shrinks them to one or two steps. For example, let’s say you need to insert the same text over and over in a document. If you create a macro, all you have to do is hit a key to do it. You can download macros from the site and books too, some free and some not. (Word of warning: you won’t find an elegantly designed site here, but you will find plenty of useful tools.)]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>three-great-editorial-sites</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="grammar-usage"><![CDATA[Grammar &amp; Usage]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_focuskw</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[editing]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Three sites for learning the P's and Q's of editing]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Luckily for us, lots of leading editors and toolmasters offer advice on websites. Here are three editorial sites Two Pens likes.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-noindex</wp:meta_key>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-nofollow</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-adv</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[none]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-include</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-prio</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_canonical</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_redirect</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Twitter 101:  Why Twitter isn’t TMI</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/twitter-101-why-twitter-isnt-tmi/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 May 2012 21:08:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3664</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3683" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Is Twitter TMI?© 2012 Cynthia Hartwig"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/twitter-on-book.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/twitter-on-book-300x225.jpg" alt="Is Twitter TMI?" title="Is Twitter TMI?" width="300" height="225" class="size-medium wp-image-3683" /></a>[/caption]<em>Twitter is overwhelming.  Twitter is noise. Twitter is the definition of TMI.</em> 
&nbsp;
How many times have you heard people say that? I won’t argue with them. Twitter is all of the above if you don’t know how to join the conversation. And that’s all Twitter really is:  a captivating discussion that at any given moment can be entertaining, informative, intimate, playful, impassioned, boisterous, or deadly serious.
<!--more-->

<h3>Coffee Klatch &amp; Stadium Crowd</h3>
Although Twitter can seem like one big hubbub, there are really two basic types of conversations going on:
<ul>
	<li>A gigantic one held in a public stadium where a crowd of people interact with celebrities, thought-leaders, or the issue of the day.</li>
	<li>A more intimate coffee klatch with people who share your interests</li>
</ul>
Each has its own rewards.  Each needs a strategy to join in.  But you only have to learn one set of tools to participate in each.
<h3>Talking in a Public Crowd</h3>
In a way, Twitter is the world’s largest water-cooler conversation-- anyone can listen to it and chime in. The difference between the one at your office and on Twitter is that presidential hopefuls, CEO’s, rappers, best-selling authors, movie stars, and other celebrities are part of the conversation. When you add your two cents, Jay-Z might respond right back.

The discussion also serves as a ticker tape. For example a tweet can break news about an earthquake (a real one or a political one). And, then you and millions of others can follow the news as it develops or share your experience of an event as it unfolds.
<h3>Talking around a Kitchen Table</h3>
If you only follow celebrities or the latest hot issue, you’ll feel lonely in the crowd. Growing your own following can make Twitter feel more like a Friday coffee with friends. You’ll meet people who care about things that you do, whether that’s making fiber art or brewing beer or Jane Austen. You can also find colleagues in your profession who you can share information with about the latest conferences, books or ideas.

This type of conversation changes Twitter from an unmanageable stream of information into a place where you can keep up with what’s new and what old friends are doing or thinking. You’ll start wanting to tune in as opposed to tune out the latest tweet.
<h3>Tools of the Twitter Trade</h3>
Part of Twitter’s success is a set of simple tools that let you easily interact with others. In the next post in this series, we’ll show you the basics to get you tweeting and re-tweeting, messaging and round-tripping. Soon you’ll stop worrying about attracting followers and start having fun responding to them.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Rap Grammar Tips: Mac Lethal Speeds By Strunk &amp; White</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/a-grammar-tip-from-a-rappe/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Jun 2012 01:16:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3748</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The link between rap and poetry has been made in abundance; the link between rap and grammar, not so much.

But that was before Mac Lethal, a Kansas City rapper, mounted his jihad against illiterate idiots who say “Your a ho” when they really mean “You’re a ho.”

Aided by handy typewritten cue cards bearing the words YOUR and YOU’RE, Mac Lethal delivers a rapid-fire rap to the tune of <em>Somebody I Used to Know</em>, taking aim at Internet trolls who sound off in Web forums but can’t tell a possessive from a contraction.

He offers up a handy mnemonic for how to keep the two straight: “Look, this one belongs to you / and this one is something that you are, it’s true.”

What I’d like him to address next is the misuse of “Whose my baby?” for “Who’s my baby?” 

A free Tupac download if Mr. Lethal also addresses “Howz it my baby?”

Warning: grammatically correct bad language.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

&nbsp;

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/32p8d6OudgU" frameborder="0" width="560" height="315"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>On vs. About: The Definitive Answer?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/on-vs-about/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 09 Jun 2012 23:28:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3781</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3784" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="On vs. about? Emily and Cynthia rowed on a shell about Lake Washington today and whined about rowing on and on."]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/onabout_cynem-3.png"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/onabout_cynem-3-300x225.png" alt="Cynthia and Emily holding two signs, one says &quot;on,&quot; the other says &quot;about&quot;" title="On vs About" width="300" height="225" class="size-medium wp-image-3784" /></a>[/caption]I needed advice on a point of grammar. I couldn’t remember when to use “on” rather than “about.” I turned to the editor’s bible—The Chicago Manual of Style (CMOS), which handily is now online. 

I posted my question in the CMOS Online forum and waited. A day later, an editor asked me for an example of a sentence so as to better answer my question. 
<!--more-->
I asked about whether to use “on” or “about” in the following sentence: 



<blockquote>She gave a lecture on recycled plastics [or about recycled plastics].</blockquote>


Lots of editors chimed in, but the answer from one editor (user name deannacl) made the most sense:



<blockquote>Use “on” or “about”; it just doesn’t matter. The meaning is perfectly clear either way. You could also say the same thing half a dozen other ways: She gave a lecture covering recycled plastics. She gave a lecture regarding recycled plastics. She gave a lecture explaining recycled plastics. 


Now, if you really want to rev up this “on” versus “about” debate, try an illustration like this: “He gave a lecture on an aircraft carrier deck.” versus “He gave a lecture about an aircraft carrier deck.” Big difference there. Duck! Here comes the wing of an F-18 Super Hornet! </blockquote>
								
To which another editor (user name usertk) replied, “I once attended a lecture on the surface of Mars. ’Twas rather chilly.”


<h3>The definitive answer?</h3>
So what's the answer to the question about when to "use" on vs. "about?" If the sentence means the same thing using either one, you get to choose. If the sentence means something silly, or downright hysterical, you've chosen the wrong one. 

In other words, you need to evaluate which one to use within the context of the sentence, and then decide. For example, using "on" rather than "about" in my example sentence led to so many possible meanings that the editors had a hay day.  In that case, I would have chosen "about." 

Bottom line:  there is no definitive answer--as with so many questions about grammar and usage.
]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-prio</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_canonical</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_redirect</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_google-plus-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_linkdex</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[68]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>In Social Signals We Trust</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/great-writing-increases-social-signals/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Jun 2012 00:09:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3839</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3883" align="alignleft" width="153"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/305px-Rello_thumbs_up1-e1340927938714.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/305px-Rello_thumbs_up1-153x300.jpg" alt="" title="Signaling Thumbs Up 2012 dmattt © 2012" width="153" height="300" class="size-medium wp-image-3883" /></a> Signaling Thumbs Up © 2012 dmattt[/caption]Who do you turn to for recommendations about movies, the best foodie blogs, or which water heater to buy (mine recently burst)? Friends and family, obviously! Connecting with those people online is the force behind the magnitude 8.0 social-media earthquake.

And now it seems that everywhere we turn online, someone is recommending something to us based on a five-star review by someone we know, and also based on our own previous choices—what we search for, read online, bookmark, share, snack on at midnight … <!--more-->

<h3>Socialize That</h3>
That’s because search has gotten personal. Google and Bing (and others) now shape results based in part on “social signals”—all those interactions and things we do online, especially the recommendations we make. If the signals are flashing to and from our networks, Google and Bing’s latest search algorithms tag them as trustworthy.

And that’s a big switcheroo from how search engines previously established trust—by counting up how many sites linked to you, and of those, which had high authority. A link from the <em>New York Times </em>food section to your cooking blog could have meant a book deal. Think <em>Julie and Julia</em> to understand the importance of backlinks back then. 

Now think about how many times a day you Like, tweet, or share a link, or check out what your friends are liking, tweeting, and so on. Search engines tally those thousands of mini-recommendations as votes for which sites or people to trust. A human thumbs-up is, after all, a better measure of authority than a hyperlink.

<h3>'Bots Love Affair</h3>
With social search, then, the quality of content matters even more. If people like what you write, your content gets more high-fives, and more high-fives boost it to the top of search results. But wait—it isn’t quite that simple. If the <em>New York Times</em> tweets about you, it’s the <em>New York Times</em>. It means more when a site or person with mega-authority votes for you, it’s like stuffing the ballot box. You win. Your content is on its way to earning a Girl Scout badge for being honorable, upright, and honest—that is, trustworthy. 

But getting the New York Times to recognize you online still happens in the same way it does offline: by working on your writing and by making connections in the world one person at a time. (And that’s also basically how you build a social media following.)

<h3>Case in Point</h3>
My tweeting-genius partner, Cynthia Hartwig, struck up a Twitter conversation about social media with @speechwriterguy, aka Guy Bergstrom, the writer behind the <a href="http://redpenofdoom.com/">Red Pen of Doom </a>blog, who lives in Olympia, Washington. Cynthia happened to visit Olympia and asked him to coffee. More friendship ensued. When Cynthia wrote a cool post on a <a href="http://twopens.com/a-grammar-tip-from-a-rappe/">rapper’s grammar tip</a>, @speechwriterguy blasted it to his following. Why? Because he trusts her and the quality of her writing. 

If you want to learn more about how to write content that amplifies your signal, check out this presentation on “<a href="http://www.slideshare.net/emilywarn/balancing-sticky-content-with-seo">Balancing Sticky Content with SEO</a>,” which I gave at the last <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Content-Strategy-Seattle/events/57290592/" target="_blank">Content Strategy Seattle Meetup</a>. (If you live in Seattle, come and say hi next time.) If you like the content, send us your social signal and we'll like you back.

<div style="width:425px" id="__ss_13375253"> <strong style="display:block;margin:12px 0 4px"><a href="http://www.slideshare.net/emilywarn/balancing-sticky-content-with-seo"  target="_blank">Balancing Sticky Content with SEO</a></strong> <iframe src="http://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/13375253?rel=0" width="425" height="355" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" style="border:1px solid #CCC;border-width:1px 1px 0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </div> ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Grow Your Twitter Following with Great Writing about...an Office Vasectomy?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/grow-your-twitter-following-through-writing-funny-tweets/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 21 Jul 2012 02:24:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=3922</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3613" align="alignnone" width="600"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/Bathroom-graffit-for-Mundane-twitter-post.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3613" title="Mundane Tweets" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/Bathroom-graffit-for-Mundane-twitter-post.jpg" alt="Example of a mundane tweet" width="600" height="448" /></a> Yes, even bathroom graffiti is fair game for tweets ©2012 Cynthia Hartwig[/caption]

Remember the good old days when you could tweet about inhaling a greasy chili dog and your ‘tweeps would be OK about getting a glimpse of your exciting gastro-life? Now that Twitter has grown more sophisticated (dare I say discriminating?), people who tweet boring status updates like “I am at 4th and Vine,” or “Just ordered a Caesar salad with a diet Coke,” make us yawn.

But before you dismiss the “status update” as dead as the do-do, consider a basic tenet of memoir writing: Writers get no credit for living a life of hell. We only get credit for how we tell the tale.<!--more-->
&nbsp;
Consider <a title="Joshua P. Simon" href="https://twitter.com/JoshuaPSimon">Joshu P. Simon's</a> report of a recent diaper change.

.<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/diaper-change-scare-orange-border.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3960" title="Diaper Change Scare" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/diaper-change-scare-orange-border.png" alt="" width="524" height="72" /></a>


Joshua could have tweeted “I changed my kid’s stinky diaper.” But instead, Joshua, a writer of fantasy fiction, used his writerly wit to turn ordinary yuck into odoriferous metaphor
&nbsp;

<a title="Bern Morley" href="https://twitter.com/Bern_Morley">Bern Morley</a> transformed an ordinary trip to the mall into Twitter existentialism worthy of (and shorter than) Camus. Note how Bern improved her tweet with a clever hashtag.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/jpeg-megaplex-orange-border.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3934" title="jpeg megaplex orange border" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/jpeg-megaplex-orange-border.jpg" alt="" width="525" height="70" /></a>

&nbsp;

Remember that just about any normal activity is an opportunity for creativity. Here’s how a brilliant creative director, <a title="Kurt Reifschneider" href="https://twitter.com/kreifschneider">Kurt Reifschneider</a>, went Christmas tree shopping.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/reifschneider-drunk-xmas-tree-orange.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3959" title="Drunk XMAS Tree" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/reifschneider-drunk-xmas-tree-orange.png" alt="" width="522" height="75" /></a>

&nbsp;

Here's how smart and clever <a title="Michael C. Miller" href="https://twitter.com/spaceneedl">Michael C. Miller</a>, Creative Director at Verathon in Seattle, enjoyed the eye doctor.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/eyes-dilated-orange.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3956" title="Eyes Dilated" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/eyes-dilated-orange.png" alt="" width="516" height="80" /></a>

&nbsp;

I like the sage advice on tweeting from <a title="Susan Orlean" href="https://twitter.com/susanorlean">Susan Orlean</a>, a writer who knows her social media.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/susan-orlean-friendliness-not-enough-orange.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3957" title="Susan Orleans Friendliness is not Enough" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/susan-orlean-friendliness-not-enough-orange.png" alt="" width="518" height="84" /></a>

&nbsp;

Tweets are quick and fleeting but the instantaneous nature of Twitter is no excuse for lackluster writing. If you reward readers with funny and insightful content, I guarantee you’ll grow your following. And if you follow any of the folks in this post or others on my list of "<a title="TwitWits" href="https://twitter.com/#!/TwoPens2/twit-wits">TwitWits</a>," you've got some great role models to aspire to.

Just don’t forget that hell is story friendly.
&nbsp;

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/office-baby-shower-vasectomy-orange.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3958" title="office baby shower vasectomy orange" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/office-baby-shower-vasectomy-orange.png" alt="" width="524" height="66" /></a>

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Confessions of a Twitter-Phobe]]></wp:comment_author>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[...] how Cynthia describes the year it took her to build a Twitter following. She’s the resident Twit-Wit of Two Pens. She’s got a knack for one-liners, some hilarious, some serious, but no matter [...]]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Twitter How-To: Curate Better-Quality Tweeps</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/twitter-how-to-curate-better-quality-tweeps/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Aug 2012 17:35:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4019</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4037" align="none" width="500"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/500-px-door.png" alt="" title="Caution: This Door Swings Bothways" width="500" height="333" class="size-full wp-image-4037" />© 2012 Cynthia Hartwig[/caption]

Yeah, yeah, I know that most Twitter mavens tout “follower grubbing” as if it’s the Holy Grail. To the mavens, deleting people who follow you is anathema.

I say, bunk.

Following people just because they follow you is at best stupid, and at worst boring. You’ll enjoy Twitter more by curating a tweet stream based on quality, not quantity.

I keep people in my Twitter stream based on how interesting they are, how interested in me they are, and often both. People who tweet “buy this, buy that,” write poorly, swear too much, tweet porn, or otherwise show they’re boorish get dumped.
<!--more-->

<h3>Meet at least one of these criteria, and you can be my tweep.</h3>

<ol>
	<li>You are a student of mine, and thus are demonstrating on Twitter how you’re putting my social-media writing lessons into practice (something I care deeply about).</li>
	<li>You are a wit and a word player, and thus a person who rewards me on a regular basis for reading your writing.</li>
	<li>You are a thought leader in one of my areas of interest, such as social media, business communication, writing, photography, or presenting.</li>
	<li>You make me laugh.</li>
</ol>

<h3>The vast majority of Twitter followings number less than 500. And that’s OK.</h3>

According to @erictpeterson of Twitalyzer, <a href="http://www.slideshare.net/eefsafe/twitalyzer-the-average-twitter-user">http://www.slideshare.net/eefsafe/twitalyzer-the-average-twitter-user</a> the average “active” user (someone who tweets about ten times a week; about 10 percent of Twitter users fall into this category) has 403 followers and follows 398 people. (This is in contrast to “Truly Exceptional” Twitterites, “who have an average of 46,000 followers and follow 8,600 people.”)

After a year of active tweeting, my stats are consistent with the average: I follow about 700 people and have about 650 people following me.

Every day, my small but choice band rewards me with news, information, wit, and wonder.  I know most of my tweeps—either in the old-fashioned way, i.e., I’ve met them in real life, or in the virtual way, i.e., I’ve come to know them because they tweet regularly and I enjoy their points of view.

<h3>Cut the deadwood and enjoy the view.</h3>

Twitter is good for news and community, none of which rely on vast numbers of followers.

The sooner you get past the numbers game, the sooner you can enjoy making friends and rewarding yourself with the kind of Twit Wits who make you laugh. Here’s are a people I thoroughly enjoy.

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/evewrites" title="Eve Glicksman" target="_blank">Eve Glicksman</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/kreifschneider" title="Kurt Reifschneider" target="_blank">Kurt Reifschneider</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/spaceneedl" title="Michael C. Miller" target="_blank">Michael C. Miller</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/speechwriterguy" title="Guy Bergstrom" target="_blank">Guy Bergstrom</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/colsonwhitehead" title="Colson Whitehead" target="_blank">Colson Whitehead</a></li>
</ul>

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" width="300" height="150" class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Signing Up for a Twitter Account: Hey, Nice to Meet You</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/getting-started-on-twitter/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Sep 2012 20:24:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://tombooster.wpengine.com/?p=4083</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Imagine you’re competing for gold in the completely obscure sport of canoe slalom. A reporter out for an angle interviews you. What do you tell him to make the billions of people transfixed by Michael Phelps ogle you?

Signing up for an account on Twitter is like talking to that reporter. It’s your hello to the world—in this case, the world of 500 million tweeters, according to <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2012/07/30/analyst-twitter-passed-500m-users-in-june-2012-140m-of-them-in-us-jakarta-biggest-tweeting-city/">TechCrunch</a>.

But don’t be intimidated. The steps in signing up for a Twitter account help you say hello. And these three tips will make your “hello” pique people’s curiosity right from the get-go.
<!--more-->
<h3>Step 1: Sign Up</h3>
The first step is like signing up for just about any other online account. Go to Twitter.com, type in your name, email address, and password, and then click “Sign up for Twitter.”

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/sign-up-1.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4092" title="Twitter Sign-up Step 1" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/sign-up-1.png" alt="How to sign up for Twitter" width="240" height="166" /></a>
<h3>Step 2: Pick Your Twitter “Handle”</h3>
On the next page you pick your username. In Twitter lingo, your username is called a handle and is always preceded by an @ sign, such as @emilywarn or @canoeslalomqueen.

We recommend that you use your name as your handle. You’re the person you want people to remember—not what you do, not the name of your book, and especially not a cutesy nickname (the most common Twitter profile misstep).

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/username-image-21.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4093" title="How to choose a Twitter handle" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/username-image-21.png" alt="How to choose a Twitter handle" width="502" height="244" /></a>

Enter your name in the Username box, then click Create an Account, and you’re in. (If you make a blooper in your username or elsewhere in your profile, you can change it later.)

Note: The symbol @ means “at.” Your tweets are sent to someone at their Twitter account, akin to sending a real letter to someone at 111 Canal Street.
<h3>Step 3: Start hanging out</h3>
We think the Twitter staff got step 3 and 4 backward. In Step 3, they suggest some people you might want to follow and let you add some of your own.

But that’s like pushing you through the door into a party even though your hair’s a mess or there’s a coffee stain on your shirt—meaning you haven’t even filled out your own profile (step 4). If people you choose want to find out who you are, there’s nobody there.

You can go ahead and pick some people to follow, but be prepared to change your choices later. Twitter suggests some random people and some famous people. A better way to find people to follow is to search on one of your interests:

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/followers-image-3-two.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4106" title="Picking followers" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/followers-image-3-two.png" alt="" width="311" height="404" /></a>

For now, just know that figuring out who to follow is an art form and a wonderfully organic process as you meet people in Twitter streams and conversations.
<h3>Step 4: Make yourself presentable—fill out your profile</h3>
How many times has a website asked you to create a profile when you signed up for its service? How many times have you skipped the step? On Twitter it’s as essential to primp for the party as it is to prep for a business pitch. Your profile is what makes people decide whether to connect with you.

So slow down. Mull it over. Who do you want to be on Twitter? Here are four tips to help you create a memorable and single-minded persona.

<strong>Tip 1: Avoid making a list to describe yourself</strong>

All of us live many different lives. We’re quilters, gearheads, brothers, sisters, bosses, junk food addicts. If you present a list of all the things you are, you end up being no one. Who is Erika really?

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/erika-sorenson-image-41.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4104" title="List Profile" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/erika-sorenson-image-41.png" alt="" width="366" height="86" /></a>

<strong>Tip 2: Focus your interests</strong>

What are the one or two things that you’re most passionate about? Think about what one thing you want to be known for or to know about. For this (fictional) Olympic athlete from Tunisia, it’s all about canoe slalom.

“I won a bronze medal at the 2012 Olympics—and I know the best place to capsize—Tunisia, my motherland.”

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/add-character.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4088" title="Give your profile character" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/add-character.png" alt="Give your profile character" width="313" height="397" /></a>

Here’s what you know about her in less than 140 characters: She’s a canoe slalom specialist (that’s what they call themselves) with a sense of pride and humor. And she rocks because she won a medal and she’s a woman athlete from Tunisia. Of course, she’s also someone’s daughter and may like drinking espressos, but do you really care?

<strong>Tip 3: Add a complementary photo</strong>

How else does Canoeslalom help us decide whether to follow her? She's shows off her master stroke in a photo of herself, further reinforcing her identity and making herself more human.

<strong>Tip 4: Humor is a high five or a hug on Twitter</strong>

Think about how you feel when you’re kidding around with friends at a neighborhood baseball game. What a relief laughter provides from the same old, same old. It makes you feel included in the group. It makes you look forward to hanging out again.

Adding humor to your Twitter profile does the same thing. It’s welcoming and warm. If you make people smile, you make them curious about what you’ll you say next.

Here are two graduate students on Twitter, Christopher and John. Their profiles are almost identical. Which one do you want to get to know?
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/christopher-ivie-image-six-two.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4103" title="Boring Twitter Profile " src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/christopher-ivie-image-six-two.png" alt="" width="420" height="127" /></a>

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/john-gallagher-image-71.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4094" title="Good twitter profile" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/john-gallagher-image-71.png" alt="Good twitter profile" width="423" height="125" /></a>
<h3>Next Step?</h3>
Now the fun begins. To learn more about using Twitter, read our previous blog posts listed below:

<a title="Twitter How-To: Curate Better-Quality Tweeps" href="http://twopens.com/twitter-how-to-curate-better-quality-tweeps/">Twitter How-To: Curate Better-Quality Tweeps</a>
<a title="Grow Your Twitter Following with Great Writing about…an Office Vasectomy?" href="http://twopens.com/grow-your-twitter-following-through-writing-funny-tweets/">Grow Your Twitter Following with Great Writing about…an Office Vasectomy?</a>
<a title="Twitter 101:  Why Twitter isn’t TMI" href="http://twopens.com/twitter-101-why-twitter-isnt-tmi/">Twitter 101: Why Twitter isn’t TMI</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4088]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>167</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Tweet-Talk 101: How to Write Tweets that Start Conversations]]></wp:comment_author>

			<wp:comment_author_url>http://twopens.com/twitter-101-how-to-write-tweets-to-start-conversations/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>50.116.20.29</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[...] in Times Square.) To add an @reply, all you have to do is put an @ symbol before someone’s Twitter handle—for example, @jiroono. When you do that, it guarantees that your tweet will show up in that [...]]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Avoid Using Big Words Unless You Want to Look asinine, imbecilic, insensate, deficient, idiotic, ludicrous, moronic, stupefied, puerile, Stupid</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/avoid-using-big-words/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Sep 2012 18:14:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4096</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/head31.jpg" alt="Avoid Using Big Words" />
<blockquote>Therefore, what has been proposed above as a means of <strong>redirecting</strong> the <strong>development</strong> of <strong>postmodernity</strong> toward more livable, human <strong>dimensions</strong> is a <strong>heterotelic narrative transitivity</strong>—an active <strong>reimmersion</strong> of <strong>narrative</strong> in the social—which contrasts sharply with the <strong>autotelic</strong> concern for their own <strong>procedures</strong> and the <strong>hermetic intransitivity</strong> of <strong>modernist self-consciousness</strong> and late <strong>modernist self-reflexivity</strong>.
—Joseph Francese, <em>Narrating Postmodern Time and Space</em></blockquote>
<!--more-->

I normally like to teach by positive example. I read a great sentence, a carefully crafted argument, a metaphor that grabs me by the necktie and pulls me in, and I hold it up like a bird in a well-built nest and praise it to the sky.

Today’s sentence by Joseph Francese, author of <em>Narrating Postmodern Time and Space</em> flies in the face of positivity. In fact, it flies in the face of good writing in general: nothing concrete, no sunrises, no tastes of octopus or nettles, no stench of rotten egg or gasoline, no sigh of wind in aspens or sense of how the hair on your arms quivers and flexes in a storm.

Joseph Francese’s sentence uses 18 abstract, headbanger terms that defy understanding. If the job of writing is to clarify, Francese has tried to make himself look smart by making you feel stupid.

Go back two paragraphs to “Today’s sentence by Joseph Francese.” Now count the number of words you can see, taste, hear, feel, or see. There are 19, if you allow me to count “flies” and “face” twice.

Which sentence would you rather read?
<h3>If you know what Francese is trying to say, please act as our translator.</h3>
Send in your best guess for what he’s trying to say, and I’ll send you a Word Czar Hat.

Don’t know what a Word Czar Hat looks like? Well, for starters, it doesn’t look like the dunce cap that Francese ought to be wearing for writing like this.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4096</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-09-17 18:14:23</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>avoid-using-big-words</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Getting Started on Twitter: Decide Who to Follow with a Bucket Strategy</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/getting-started-on-twitter-use-the-bucket-strategy-to-decide-who-to-follow/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 17:31:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4114</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4125" align="none" width="300"]<img class="size-full wp-image-4125" title="four buckets_300px" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/four-buckets_300px.png" alt="Divide your following into buckets." width="300" height="200" /> Getting started on Twitter will go more quickly if you pick tweeps who fall into buckets of business builders, career builders and reputation builders.[/caption]

When getting started on Twitter, there is a very human temptation to obsess about that Big Fat Zero in your “follower” column. Instead, we recommend using our bucket strategy to decide on a following that can help you grow your reputation and your business.
<!--more-->

<h3>Start out by dividing your Twitter following into "self-help" buckets.</h3>
If you’re interested in photography, look up your favorite photographers, or follow <a title="follow the Magnum pros" href="http://www.magnumphotos.com/">the Magnum pros</a> or seek out fabulous photo aggregation sites on Twitter and put this group into a bucket. If writing or literature is your passion, <a title="cozy cat mystery people" href="http://www.cozy-mystery.com/blog/kittens-cats-and-cozies-cat-mysteries.html">cozy cat mystery people</a> or <a title="the Poetry Foundation " href="http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poem/180818">the Poetry Foundation </a>and its insight into the poetry of Ovid becomes another group. The point is: the people you decide to put in your buckets should be there to feed you with insight and news about topics you like.

<h3>Create another bucket of industry or business contacts.</h3>
[caption id="attachment_4118" align="none" width="300"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-4118" title="two buckets multi flowers" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/two-buckets-multi-flowers-300x200.png" alt="Stock business contacts in another bucket." width="300" height="200" /> Rather than grubbing for followers, put industry contacts and newsmakers in your buckets.[/caption]

Twitter isn’t just for fun; it’s a great resource for keeping up with trends in your industry; it's a place to learn who’s been hired or fired; it's a timely source of insight for when to jump if you see an opening or an opportunity. Follow those people who provide a pulse on your business community, your colleagues, and your competition. Over time, this group will become a hub of important career or sales-building.

<h3>Make only a small bucket of friends you want to keep up with.</h3>
Facebook is the social medium of choice for keeping up with friends. I think of Twitter as a better forum for business, mostly because it's so public. I only follow a few folks in my social circle on Twitter based on whether they “tweet sweet” and make me laugh. You may decide to fill your bucket differently. Just remember: it’s hard to drop real friends from your stream (for some reason, people take it personally!).

<h3>Make a bucket for the ten Influentials you really want to know.</h3>
Think about your industry and your career path. There are important people on Twitter who aren’t celebrities exactly—but who are leaders in the spheres you operate in.
[caption id="attachment_4129" align="alignnone" width="300"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/glads_500px-300x225.png" alt="" title="glads_500px" width="300" height="225" class="size-medium wp-image-4129" /> Twitter gives you unprecedented access to influential people in any industry. Pick your “top ten” and start cultivating a connection by listening to the conversation.[/caption]
Figure out ten or so movers and shakers in your industry or interest area who could help your business reputation: who are the people who appear at the important conferences? Who speaks out on key issues? Who gets quoted on TV or in the industry publications you read? Who’s on a board you might like to join? Ask yourself: whose recommendation or testimonial would mean the most to your career? 

<h3>Now do nothing except listen and RT your Influentials’ tweets.</h3>
If you want to “know” someone on Twitter, the fastest way to a tweeter’s heart is the share button. Your task with your bucket of Influentials is to spend three to six months listening in to their conversations (this will take less time with people who are players in local or regional niches; you should plan on a much longer time with Influentials with a national following). When one of your Top Tens says something you like or agree with, hit the RT button and share it with your followers. Do this regularly enough, and a Red Letter Day will come when one of your Influentials will send you an @reply saying, “Thx for the RT.” Whoo-hoo. This is the start of a Twitter relationship.

<h3>After three to six months, you can RT your Influentials’ comments with a comment of your own.</h3> 
There’s an etiquette to Twitter that is a lot like a party conversation. If Mrs. National Spokesperson stood in the middle of a group of gin drinkers at a cocktail party, you would naturally hang out on the fringes and listen in on the conversation. You would not elbow your way in the face of Mrs. Spokesperson and try to buy her a Manhattan in return for a testimonial on your website.

So too, in Twitter: etiquette requires that you listen to the conversation for some time before you try to engage with the rock stars of your profession. I guarantee that if over time you share Mrs. Spokesperson’s comments, she will begin to notice you. When that happens, you can add your own salient comments or a new line of thinking to your RT. You’ll see that your reputation for thoughtful discourse is growing by the number of followers you gain. 

Once you establish a Twitter relationship of shares and thoughtful comments, you can do exactly what you would ordinarily do in the real world. If Mrs. Spokesperson will be speaking at a conference in town, you buy a ticket. You listen to her speech and go up to her when it ends and introduce yourself as one of her ‘tweeps. You tell her your name and remind her that you’ve been reading her tweets with pleasure for the past year. Voilà. Mrs. Spokesperson puts your face to your name. You’re connected. Where you go from there is up to you.
[caption id="attachment_4122" align="none" width="300"]<img class="size-full wp-image-4127" title="dahlia_300px" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/dahlia_300px.png" alt="After 3-6 months, watch the relationship bloom" width="300" height="225" /> The wait will be worth it if you listen, RT and then connect to your community.[/caption]
<h3>Got recommendations for other "Getting Started on Twitter" buckets? It’s worth a Word Czar hat.</h3>

I’d love to hear any other strategies you’ve used for identifying people to follow. Seems like Twitter is a garden that we should control, rather than the other way round. So weigh in. We’ve bought a supply of popular Word Czar hats to reward the winning comment.

<h3>More Twitter insights here.</h3>

<a title="Twitter How-To: Curate Better-Quality Tweeps" href="http://twopens.com/twitter-how-to-curate-better-quality-tweeps/">Twitter How-To: Curate Better-Quality Tweeps</a>
<a title="Grow Your Twitter Following with Great Writing about…an Office Vasectomy?" href="http://twopens.com/grow-your-twitter-following-through-writing-funny-tweets/">Grow Your Twitter Following with Great Writing about…an Office Vasectomy?</a>
<a title="Twitter 101:  Why Twitter isn’t TMI" href="http://twopens.com/twitter-101-why-twitter-isnt-tmi/">Twitter 101: Why Twitter isn’t TMI</a>

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

Cynthia Hartwig]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Hashtags #Unhashed </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/understanding-twitter-hashtags/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Oct 2012 18:48:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4134</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4136" align="alignnone" width="500"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/stylized-hashtag1-e1349973849657.png" alt="" title="stylized hashtag" width="500" height="333" class="size-full wp-image-4136" /> Understand the Twitter hashtag and you’ve mastered a creative word play tool.[/caption]Lots of beginners have trouble understanding Twitter hashtags. We get anxious questions in our Writing for Social Media classes all the time. What are they? How do you use them?  Do I look like an idiot if my tweets don't have them?

<!--more-->

<h3>A Twitter Hashtag is just a Searchable Tag or Keyword Preceded by the # Sign.</h3>

Back in Twitter-yore (eons ago, like maybe three years?), hashtags developed as the signposts that helped people discover breaking news and topics. Think "# + keyword= hashtag." But don’t let the techie definition fool you. Hashtags are elegant and supple writing tools.

<h3>Understand That Hashtags are Tools for Search.</h3>
 
Hashtags from #arabspring to #Syriabombings to #S.E.Asianearthquake all sprung up in recent history to give people a way to find, react and discuss world events. In last week’s Presidential debate, #mittwins and #obamatanked trended in Twitter popularity. If something great or terrible happens in your local area, you, too, can start a #breakingnews hashtag and lead a searchable discussion.

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/shortfacebook.png" alt="Use hashtags to search for #investing advice" title="shortfacebook" width="517" height="99" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4139" />

<h3>Understand That Hashtags Help Spread the Word Beyond your Followers.</h3> 

Hashtags also help you find many ongoing conversations on everything from #pubtibs to #Twitter101 to #weedkillers. These discussions wax and wane, depending on who wants to join in.  Find #hashtags in your area of expertise and you have an instantaneous way to share your wisdom beyond your following. 

Say you’re a writer, like I am; you can use hashtags like #amwriting and #writetips to deliver tweets about writerly pain or gain or wisdom. If you design children’s rooms, like my pal @elizabethtraub, you can tweet about morphing a toddler’s room into a teenager’s room on #kidrooms or #shabbychic. Like gardening? Look for robust conversations on #gardeningadvice and #weedkillers.

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/nolfipubtip.png" alt="#pubtip is a searchable hashtag" title="nolfipubtip" width="522" height="100" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4142" />

<h3>Understand That Hashtags are Great for Twitticisms.</h3>

My favorite Twitter nuance is how hashtags have developed as a tool for word play and social commentary. In a good writer’s hands, a hashtag can help you earn a reputation as a Twit Wit.  

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/rosenrazors.png" alt="use hashtags with humor" title="rosenrazors" width="519" height="88" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4140" />

The tweet from Professor Snape, for example won the “best tweet on Oscar night” award.
 
<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Snapeoscars.png" alt="Professor Snape tweets wins &quot;best Oscar&quot; of the night" title="Snapeoscars" width="518" height="99" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4143" /> 

You’ll often see people playing word games with hashtags like the #beatlesplants hashtags below.(As if we didn't have plenty of other ways to waste time!)

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/johnandyuccagame.png" alt="#beatleplants John and Yukka" title="johnandyuccagame" width="454" height="88" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4138" /> 

<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/paperbirchwriter.png" alt="#beatlesplants Paper Birch Writer" title="paperbirchwriter" width="506" height="97" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4141" />

<h3>What’s Your Favorite Hashtag?</h3>

I’d love to hear some fun #hashtags you've admired. If you submit the winning example, one of our famous Word Czar hats will be winging its way to you.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

Cynthia Hartwig


	]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Web headers should help you find information</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/web-headers-should-help-you-find-information/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Oct 2012 20:18:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4145</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When you’re writing webpage headlines, remember that their role is to tell readers what the content is about. Readers are busy, so don’t irritate them by making them hunt for what they’re looking for. Augment an informative header with subheads that lead readers through the copy to the information they want.
]]></content:encoded>
