	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Tweet-Talk 101: How to Write Tweets that Start Conversations </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/twitter-101-how-to-write-tweets-to-start-conversations/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Oct 2012 17:26:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4146</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4158" align="alignnone" width="500"]<img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/conversation500px.jpg" alt="" title="Starting a conversation in &lt;140 characters" width="500" height="333" class="size-full wp-image-4158" /> Everybody wants to get into a conversation but how do you start? Master a few Twitter conventions and you'll be tweet-talking in no time.  © 2012 Cynthia Hartwig[/caption]

Shouting through a megaphone doesn’t work very well in Times Square on New Year’s Eve. Nor is it any fun. It’s a little like sending a tweet to the 500 million tweeters out there and expecting to be heard. One person trying to talk one-way to thousands of people just doesn’t work very well.

But what if, as you were stamping your feet in the cold waiting for the ball to fall, you began or joined a conversation with the people around you, and that conversation spread to other people, and they spread it to others and so on? That’s how Twitter works. And, luckily, it’s easy to learn how to write tweets that are conversation starters.<!--more-->

<h3>Short and Tweet</h3>

One hundred and forty characters. Just spell it out and you’re a third of the way there. Not much room to say what’s on your mind. With practice, though, you’ll soon be a master of brevity. You’ll think nothing of explaining your politics or tips on how to make great sushi in &lt;140.

But concise tweets still need to be conversational. When you try to write one, think of all the ways you get someone talking or listening. Asking questions is one way. Being funny or ranting are some others. All the tweeting fools out there will tell you that they never stop inventing icebreakers.

One way to start is by writing a long version of a tweet and pretend you’re talking to someone. I began the one below like this: “Hi, I love making sushi and got to wondering if famous sushi chefs harvest their own seaweed. WDYT?”
The problem with this? Way too long and clumsy. (Would you retweet it?) I shrunk it by asking and answering a question, and added the snob factor (“five-star sushi”) to hook people:

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/sushi-example.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4151" title="A twitter conversation starter" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/sushi-example.png" alt="" width="299" height="258" /></a>

[Note: Cynthia is tweet-erific so she’s the headliner on our Two Pens Twitter account. )
<h3>Spread the Word with #hashtags and @reply</h3>
Two must-know Twitter conventions help nudge the conversation beyond hello: #hashtags and @reply.

A #hashtag is a way to categorize your tweet. Every other tweet categorized in the same way shows up as one conversation on Twitter.

So if you want to find a lot of other wannabe sushi makers, type #japanesecooking into Twitter’s search box, and you’ll find some friends. Now you can learn how to cook tonkotsu noodle soup from @AnnyChow—and let her know what you think. (This is a very simple explanation of hashtags. Cynthia has a lot more to say about them in <a href="http://twopens.com/understanding-twitter-hashtags/">Hashtags #Unhashed</a>.)

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/japanese-cooking-hashtag.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4150" title="Example of a hashtag: #japanesecooking" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/japanese-cooking-hashtag.png" alt="" width="468" height="514" /></a>

@reply lets you talk to anyone on Twitter, no matter how famous they are. (If they’re as famous as Jiro Ono, the world’s most well-known sushi chef, then it’s more like tugging on someone’s shirtsleeve in Times Square.) To add an @reply, all you have to do is put an @ symbol before someone’s <a href="http://twopens.com/getting-started-on-twitter/">Twitter handle</a>—for example, @jiroono. When you do that, it guarantees that your tweet will show up in that person’s Twitter stream.

Sadly, I can’t use @jiroono as an example—it’s all in Japanese—so I’ll switch to Rick Bayless as a teaching tool.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/bayless-at-reply.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4149" title="@reply to rick bayless" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/bayless-at-reply.png" alt="" width="468" height="495" /></a>

Having commuted between Seattle and Chicago (the home of Bayless’s famous Frontera Grill) dozens of times, I agree with Jessie Schupack—he should open a restaurant at Midway Airport. Now I can second Jessie’s motion, and maybe he’ll notice. I click “reply,” and a tweet box opens with two @replies: @rick_bayless and @jschupack.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/jschupack.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4148" title="@reply to famous person" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/jschupack.png" alt="" width="463" height="497" /></a>

Ok, so now how do I join the conversation? I concur heartily (“Definitely!”), then I try to make a real connection. I show off my knowledge of Chicago (Gold Coast Dogs and lime-green pickle relish) and add an emotive hashtag (#missingchicago).

Just for fun, I decide to search on the hashtag #missingchicago. Holy cow! Crazy people who like the cold! And me at the top of the stream! Maybe next time I’m in Chicago, one of them will take me to a Cubbies game. You never know.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/missing-chicago.png"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4147" title="#missingchicago" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/missing-chicago.png" alt="" width="475" height="424" /></a>

Have you ever made a wacky real-world connection via Twitter? Let us know by leaving a comment.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_sitemap-include</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why Telling a Story Works Better on Video than Selling </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/two-pens-story/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Oct 2012 19:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4161</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KUK12nCgrWs&w=500&rel=0]

If you want to move people, telling stories is the fastest and most direct route to tears, laughter and joy. That’s why business videos that tell stories are more effective than those that sell.
<h3>Business videos need stories to make people lean in.</h3>
Next time you’re in front of a group of business people, test the phrase “Let me tell you a story,” and you’ll see people turn toward you, incline their heads, and relax.

Now try this with the phrase, “Let me sell you.” Hmm. People will cross their arms and sit back in their seats in an instinctive effort to get away or protect themselves.
<!--more-->
<h3>There are a million ways to tell a story.</h3>
Typical stories start off with a hero or heroine in trouble. Think Cinderella in rags, sweeping cinders from the fireplace. Then there’s a villain, like the Evil Stepmother, who blocks Cinderella’s goal, which today is usually either finding a good job (the movie <a title="Working Girl" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_Girl">Working Girl</a>), making the mean kids bleed from their ears and eyeballs (the movie <a title="Carrie" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrie_(1976_film)">Carrie</a>), or finding the handsome prince and leaving the ugly stepsisters without toes (<a title="the original Brothers Grimm version of Cinderella" href="http://classiclit.about.com/library/bl-etexts/grimm/bl-grimm-cinderella.htm">the original Grimm’s Brother’s version of the Cinderella story</a>).

Often, there’s also a fairy godmother who helps the heroine by providing the spell, the pumpkin for the carriage, and the designer dress to catch the prince’s eye, setting the love plot in motion or bringing it to a happy conclusion.
<h3>What do you think of our story?</h3>
Because we’re big believers in stories, we chose two master storytellers, Chris Caldwell and Zeek Earl, of <a href="http://vimeo.com/zeekearl/videos" title="Shep Films">Shep Films</a> to tell Two Pens story on film. These young <a title="indie filmmakers (In the Pines)" href="http://vimeo.com/32213929">indie filmmakers</a> conducted interviews with Emily and me. Their questions set up a natural narrative structure that allowed Emily and me to be both the “heroines” of our little company and the narrators of our tale.
In the film, a lack of skill in writing for social media is the Evil Stepmother that we—and our students—have to conquer in order to woo a social media following. Watch the film and you’ll see us in action, teaching, cajoling, encouraging, and providing the sharp pens that allow our students to tell their own riveting tales.
<h3>Short and tweet? Or…?</h3>
The best business videos on YouTube are even shorter than a short story. That’s why our little film lasts 2 minutes and 48 seconds. We’d love to know if it keeps your attention and makes you want to know more.
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

Cynthia Hartwig]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>You are a key part of your blog</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/you-are-a-key-part-of-your-blog/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Oct 2012 08:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Make your blog stickier by adding your own personality to it. Include photos of yourself and your home (we like portraits that show you at work or in your place of business). Write about your own take on life and your experiences as they relate to whatever you’re posting about. Even your personal signature adds a piece of information that makes you more real. Readers want to know about you so they can judge whether you are a credible resource for information. You’ve learned a lot in this life; your blog is the place to show it.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Good headlines take time and effort</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/good-headlines-take-time-and-effort/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Oct 2012 08:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4164</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Take it from an advertising copywriter: the first headline you write is rarely the best you can do. Brainstorm a list of options without judgment, and don’t pick the one you’re going to use till the end. If you have time, set the list aside for a while and come back to it with fresh eyes. (This is the Two Pens approach in action: first you generate, then you edit.)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Figure out the takeaway before you write a headline</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/figure-out-the-takeaway-before-you-write-a-headline/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Oct 2012 08:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4165</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many headlines fail because they don’t help readers decide whether they want to read more. A headline that sums up the subject matter will always trump an oblique attempt to be clever. Before you write a headline, do a pre-write on the single most important thing you want to say. If you know what the reader will take away, you can apply that standard to choose the best headline.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What’s the role of cleverness in a headline?</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/whats-the-role-of-cleverness-in-a-headline/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Oct 2012 08:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4166</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Copyblogger advises avoiding cleverness in heads, but we say, “Bunk!” A headline that plays with language entices the reader to read more. It’s a sign that the reader is in good hands with this writer. Typically, an attempt at cleverness has to be vetted by someone other than yourself (that’s why they pay Cynthia the big bucks as a creative director). Shop around the head in question and ask, “Do you get it? Does it make you want to read more?” If people laugh, smile, or nod, you’re golden. If they squint or wrinkle their foreheads, try again.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4166</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-10-28 08:00:38</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
		<title>Collect good headlines and emulate them</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/collect-good-headlines-and-emulate-them/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Oct 2012 08:00:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4167</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There’s a reason newspapers typically have one person write the headlines for all of their articles. Writing headlines is an art that requires creativity, compression, and an understanding of what grabs attention. If you want to become a better headline writer, start by collecting good examples. Study how ads and article heads work. Then use them as a guide when you write your own. And remember, headline writers at newspapers and creative directors at ad agencies get paid a lot for their skill. It’ll pay off for you too.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Short is better than long, unless long is better than short</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/short-is-better-than-long-unless-long-is-better-than-short/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Oct 2012 08:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4168</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I’ve seen plenty of great three-word headlines, and I've seen three-line headlines that knocked my socks off. Good headlines can be any length, as long as they speak to readers and pull them in. A short headline is revered by creative directors the world over, but a long headline can often provide a compelling thought that shows the writer at his or her most engaging and persuasive. I used to tell my copywriters to expand their repertoire with all types of heads: screamers, word play, puns, alliteration, super-long, and even none at all (so the visual could do the work). All the tricks of language are at your disposal; in this, headline writing is the same as other kinds of writing. It’s up to you to experiment.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Headlines work in partnership with visuals</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/headlines-work-in-partnership-with-visuals/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 31 Oct 2012 08:00:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4169</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You may be surprised to know that headlines are lazy. They often lie dank and listless without an interesting visual.

Take it from Cynthia, a longtime ad agency creative director: almost any headline can be saved with a great image. Select an interesting photo or illustration that adds information to the headline and doesn’t just repeat it. If the reader puts together the headline and the visual to come up with the answer, all the better. Look at the way gawker.com and lifehacker.com use headlines and visuals together if you need a role model.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4169</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Twitter 101:  Operating Manual for a Tweet </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/twitter-101-how-to-retweet-and-reply/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Nov 2012 22:23:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4177</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4186" align="alignnone" width="500"]<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/greengoddess-500px.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-4186" title="Green Goddess" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/greengoddess-500px.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="669" /></a> You may be as interesting as Lady Gaga, but who will know if you don't tweet up? Copyright 2012 Cynthia Hartwig[/caption]

Unless you’re Lady Gaga (no. 1), the Dalai Lama (no. 96), or any other in the Twitterati's <a href="http://twittercounter.com/pages/100">top 100</a>, very few people will read your tweets--no matter how witty, hashtag-stuffed, or timely you make them. You're more likely to find followers when you're new to Twitter by first listening to what others are saying, and then responding. How you respond depends on both good old-fashioned dinner-table manners and an understanding of a how a tweet box works.<!--more-->
<h3>Tweet Operating Manual</h3>
Think about a dinner at a big wedding. You have to be on your best behavior. But there are plenty of people (including strangers) to chat with on the sidelines beside the dance floor, where snide remarks and ogling are allowed.

Choosing between a polite response or a snarky one, or any other kind, works the same on Twitter—it depends on the situation. But unlike at a real wedding, you also need to learn how to use these three tools in the tweet box:
<ul>
	<li>Re-tweet</li>
	<li>@reply</li>
	<li>Favorite</li>
</ul>
To see these different options on a tweet box, you need to hover over Expand with your mouse. Here’s a tweet by Margaret Atwood that I want to respond to:

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-tweet-collapsed.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4181" title="Margaret Atwood Tweet About Ann Patchett Collapsed" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-tweet-collapsed.png" alt="" width="632" height="120" /></a>

I hover over Expand and see this:

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-expanded.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4182" title="Margaret Atwood Tweet About Ann Patchett Expanded" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-expanded.png" alt="" width="660" height="123" /></a>

Then I click Retweet and…
<h3>Retweet after me</h3>
In many real-world conversations, if you’re polite or shy, you nod your head and say “uh-huh,” just to let the person know you’ve heard and liked what they said.

That nods is the equivalent of a retweet. When you Retweet a tweet, the person who wrote it knows you liked what they said. But there’s one big difference. Since your retweet shows up in their Twitter feed, all their followers can read it.

Back at the metaphorical wedding, that means when you repeat something someone said because you think it’s a hoot, it’s heard by everyone on the sidelines.

When I read the tweet by Margaret Atwood, I wanted all my Twitter friends to know that two of the world's most incredible novelists, both of whom write sci-fi parables (though they eschew the label) about women in society, are about to meet for the first time. How cool is that? So I clicked Retweet.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/retweet-to-your-followers.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4180" title="Click Retweet" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/retweet-to-your-followers.png" alt="" width="655" height="252" /></a>

See that question at the top of the box? Twitter is giving me a second chance to decide if I really want to send the tweet to all of my followers. It asks because it will not give me a chance to add a note. Click Retweet, and presto, it shows up in your Twitter feed and the original author’s. (When it does show up in the feed, the green arrow at the upper-right corner of the tweet is a signal that it’s been retweeted.)
<h3>@reply–the Twitter Mailman</h3>
Now, what if you stopped being shy and wanted to broadcast your thoughts so widely that you decided to announce them on the dance floor? The Twitter equivalent would be to click <strong>@reply</strong> in the tweet box to send a response.

When you do, another box opens with the person’s Twitter handle—in this case, @margaretatwood.

I certainly wanted to let Margaret Atwood know how much I admired both her and Ann Patchett, and how curious I was about what they might say to each other, so I clicked @reply and typed the following tweet:

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-reply.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4178" title="@reply to Margaret Atwood tweet" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/atwood-reply.png" alt="" width="646" height="427" /></a>

After I finish, I click Tweet and off it goes to all her followers and mine. Whenever you add @reply to a tweet, it always shows up in that person’s Twitter feed. You can also add @reply when you compose an original retweet with the same result--it shows up in the person’s feed.

For example, let’s say I wanted to tweet about how Atwood’s <em>Handmaid’s Tale</em> and Ann Patchett’s <em>State of Wonder</em> are similar. Once I finished crafting the most perfectly literary and witty tweet, I would include @margaretatwood and @annpatchett, then start praying they notice me and reply.

Even if they don’t, one of their followers might, say someone who likes both authors and wants to engage in a conversation. Soon you’re debating whether Patchett or Atwood’s imaginary society is most like our own. You read each other’s every tweet and, most likely, make friends with some of each other’s followers who chime in. Watch as your conversations, and followers, widen.
<h3>Give It a Gold Star—Choose Favorite</h3>
The Favorite tool is super easy. Just click it when you want to tell all of your followers about a Tweet you like. The tweet shows up in your Twitter feed with a gold star in the upper-right corner.  I liked this tweet by Margaret Atwood advising us to time travel:

&nbsp;

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Favorite-Margaret-Atwood-Tweet.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4184" title="Favorite Margaret Atwood Tweet" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Favorite-Margaret-Atwood-Tweet.png" alt="" width="651" height="141" /></a>

So…. what would you ask Margaret Atwood or Lady Gaga to get a response?]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How to write a creative brief  (with help from Pinterest)</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/how-to-write-a-creative-brief-with-help-from-pinterest/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Nov 2012 17:47:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4191" align="alignnone" width="300"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-4191" title="Lady Lion Tamer from Look Magazine" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Slide2-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /> Pat English, lady lion tamer, uses whip and chair to manage wild creatures with teeth; all you need is a creative brief. Photo courtesy of <em>Look Magazine</em>.[/caption]

I have a secret to tell you about managing creative people.

You know how a lion tamer typically wields a chair in one hand and a whip in the other? To get the best work from those wildly imaginative copywriters and art directors, you need the equivalent. It’s called a creative brief.
<h3>Write a creative brief as a cage to provide safety and order to creatives.</h3>
<!--more-->
A creative brief is just a short overview of the creative assignment. It describes the audience, provides an overview of the creative problem, and states the <em>one</em> key thing you want to say that will solve it. 

Without a well-written brief, you’ll never get the best work from your creative teams. Chaos will reign if these wildly fertile brains aren’t given a box to work within so they can deliver a web site, a blog post, a video, or a banner ad that is on strategy.
<h3>The takeaway is the most important part of the creative brief.</h3>
A great brief requires that you articulate the most important thing you want your audience to remember. This is sometimes called the takeaway; sometimes it’s referred to as the creative strategy statement; sometimes it's just called the message.

It must be a single thing. It must be meaty. This is the T-bone steak for all creative people. It is the main thing in a brief that you can be sure your creative team will read. (Let me confess, as one of those wild and wooly creative types, it is sometimes the <em>only</em> thing your team will read.)

My favorite takeaway formula is from <a title="Larry Asher" href="http://www.workerbees.com/content/about.html">Larry Asher</a>, co-director of the School of Visual Concepts<a href="http://svcseattle.com" title="School of Visual Concepts"> and creative director of Worker Bees, an advertising agency in Seattle.

<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-4189" title="brief takeaway" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/brief-takeaway-300x239.png" alt="" width="300" height="239" />

(See the SlidesShare presentation from the class Larry Asher and I co-teach on </a><a title="" href="http://www.slideshare.net/svcseattle/evaluating-and-encouraging-better-creative-work">“Evaluating (and Encouraging) Better Creative Work”</a> for further enlightenment on this vast and important topic.)

Here's how the formula looks when it's applied to one of the all-time great brand campaigns for Federal Express.

You should send (verb) your package (noun) because FedEx guarantees it will get there overnight (single compelling reason).”
<h3>The creative solution? "Fed Ex. When it absolutely, positively has to be there overnight.”</h3>
Who could forget this brilliant FedEx TV commercial with John Moschitta?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NeK5ZjtpO-M
<h3>How Pinterest can improve a creative brief.</h3>
Remember the metaphor I started this post with to talk about creative teams? The one about the lion tamer wielding a chair? Turns out that the lion tamer isn’t actually holding the big cats off; she’s getting them to focus on the obstacle in front of them rather than eating her arm.

So, too, with a creative brief: writing a single-minded one is half the battle. Getting the creative team to read and (forgive the pun, “ingest” it) is the other.

That’s why I like to use Pinterest. Creative teams see hundreds of briefs each year so it's not wise to bore them with yet another dry, unappetizing memo. Pinterest gives me all the power of images and videos to explain any assignment with style and attitude.

Take a look at the demo <a title="Creative Brief Pinboard" href=" http://pinterest.com/cynthiahartwig/creative-brief/">Creative Brief Pinboard</a> I created on Pinterest for a made-up Starbucks Via packaging assignment. On the cover is the all-important takeaway.

[caption id="attachment_4188" align="alignnone" width="300"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-4188" title="Slide51" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Slide51-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /> This takeaway for a made-up Starbucks Via packaging assignment has one thought--and only one--to convey.[/caption]

The rest of my Pinboard contains the elements of a standard creative brief, illustrated with pictures and explained in captions.

Come back next week and I will walk you through all the elements you need on a Pinterest creative brief. And if you've got other ways to tame those pussycats in the creative department, I'd love to hear them.

<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1015" title="2011 Cynthia signature with contrast" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/2011-Cynthia-signature-with-contrast1-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

Cynthia Hartwig]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Dangling participles</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/dangling-participles/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 12 Nov 2012 01:27:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chartwig</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4194</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Dangling participles are the curse of writers and comic relief for editors. Usually they happen when a writer forgets what a participle is qualifying.

<blockquote>"Waiting in line at the grocery store, the eggs fell off the shopping cart and splattered the woman behind me."</blockquote>

This sentence literally means that the eggs were waiting in line instead of the person. Fix it by adding a subject to the action, such as “While I waited in line, the eggs…”
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4194</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Confessions of a Twitter-Phobe: Learn to Tweet or Die</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/learn-to-tweet-or-die/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Nov 2012 22:53:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?p=4199</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/dont-reach-in.png"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-4200" title="Don't Reach In Or I Will Bite" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/dont-reach-in-300x225.png" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>

Brutal. That’s how Cynthia describes the year it took her to build a Twitter following. She’s the resident <a href="http://twopens.com/grow-your-twitter-following-through-writing-funny-tweets/">Twit-Wit</a> of Two Pens. She’s got a knack for one-liners, some hilarious, some serious, but no matter which, they make you want to respond or lurk.

Equally important, she focuses her topics only on those related to our brand—teaching people to write from both sides of the brain. Follow her on Twitter and you’ll see how ambidextrous she is.
<h3>On the Twitter Sidelines</h3>
In contrast, I’m the Two Pens’ Twitter wallflower. My earnest nature is more comfortable with blogging where I can qualify things I want to say, hedging what so-and-so might think. Truth be told, I’m still shy, as many other women are, about jousting in a public space.

So how do I grow a following of my own from scratch?
<!--more-->
<h3>Experiment</h3>
If you concoct a strategy and then see if it works, you’ll have a plan to follow. You can tweet, retweet, @reply, etc., with purpose. So that’s my strategy with one additional component—I’m going to blog about how well my strategy works. After all, that’s Two Pens’ mission—to teach people how to write social media content that builds an online presence. You can follow me along my way.
<h3>Pick 10 Thought-Leaders to Follow</h3>
You or your business might not need thousands of followers to accomplish your social media goals. Maybe you’re a researcher who studies crustaceans or a retail business that sells outdoor gear. You only need to reach people engaged in those communities.

How do you reach them? By engaging with who is engaging them. In other words, find thought leaders with buff Twitter muscles who can lift up your reputation. At least that’s the theory—Cynthia suggested it. I plan on picking 10 to see if I can capture their attention—my first choice is below.
<h3>My Thought-Leader Pick No. 1: Danny Sullivan</h3>
<a href="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/DannySullivan-lg.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-4201" title="Danny Sullivan - Search Engine Land" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/DannySullivan-lg.jpg" alt="" width="152" height="152" /></a> Last April I gave a talk, “<a href="http://www.slideshare.net/emilywarn/balancing-sticky-content-with-seo">Balancing Sticky Content with SEO</a>,” at a company-wide Microsoft  conference on SEO. I got to hear <a href="http://searchengineland.com/author/danny-sullivan">Danny Sullivan</a> of <a href="http://searchengineland.com/">Search Engine Land</a> give a talk on social signals. He’s down-to-earth, super-smart and knowledgeable. He helped me understand how you need to think about <a href="http://twopens.com/great-writing-increases-social-signals/">social signals</a> as part of creating great social media content.

At Two Pens, SEO and content are my areas of expertise. If I become a Twitter thought leader in that area, I will distinguish my account from Cynthia’s and broaden our brand. So … on opening my own Two Pens Twitter account, Danny was the first person I followed. Then a funny thing happened.
<h3>Somebody Who Knows Somebody Who Knows Somebody</h3>
As a consultant at Microsoft, I’m part of an email alias that shares a lot of info about social media marketing and SEO. Last week someone posted a link to Danny Sullivan’s blog post on social signals, which is way old—first published in 2010. Someone else chimed in with a more recent blog post called <a href="http://www.seomoz.org/blog/your-guide-to-social-signals-for-seo">Your Guide to Social Signals for SEOmoz</a>—a website I already follow.

The post not only provided useful information but was written by a guy named Jayson DeMers (<a href="https://twitter.com/jaysondemers">@jaysondemers</a>), who happens to live in Seattle, where he runs <a href="http://www.audiencebloom.com/">AudienceBloom</a>, LLC, an SEO and social media marketing agency that provides <a href="http://www.audiencebloom.com/services/guest-blogging-services/">guest-blogging services</a>. Now, some of Two Pens’ writer-followers might definitely like to know about that. If I passed that info on to my imagined following of a thousand, they would thank me with one hundred bows.

I began following Jayson immediately, and am now listening and waiting for the right moment to chime in—when I have something to say that even my Twitter jitters won’t get in the way of. Who knows? I might even invite him to coffee.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>$50 Four O’Clock: Re-Tweet After Me</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/50-four-o%e2%80%99clock-re-tweet-after-me/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 May 2011 18:36:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dangayle</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1203</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Don’t get Twitter? Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream? In this class, you’ll learn Twitter basics—its lingo, tools, and how to write tweets to huge followings. We’ll give you writing prompts that will help you join the conversation and learn how to get re-tweeted. As models, we’ll share great tweets from elite tweeters who have built their reputations in 140 characters or less. 

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />

]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Attracting Followers in Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 May 2011 18:04:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1255</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks, especially if you’re a writer. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will provide examples of successful social media strategies of other writers and the content that made them happen. Course includes blog, Twitter and Facebook writing exercises. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences. Recommended for all writers who want to build their careers.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base-become-a-social-media-star/"target="_blank">More Info</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1255</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-05-20 11:04:00</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-05-20 18:04:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>$50 Four O&#039;Clock: Building Your Brand on Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/blog-yourself-a-brand/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 May 2011 18:06:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1262</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Building a personal identity, or brand, is essential to using social media effectively. The first step is identifying the authentic you so you can stand out in the social media crowd. Are you a technocrat with more passion and knowledge about technology?  Are you deeply interested in film and want to build a reputation as an insightful movie critic? Are you a tireless advocate for a cause like water quality or Alzheimer’s research or people with chronic pain?  Whatever your passion, we’ll show you how to use it as a springboard to create a presence on social media that that grows over time. ]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Re-Tweet After Me - Hugo House</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/re-tweet-after-me-hugo-house/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 May 2011 16:23:06 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sign up for a dizzying day of timed writing and support <a href="http://www.hugohouse.org/content/write-o-rama-1" target="_blank">Hugo House</a>, Seattle’s premier writing resource, at the same time. Write-O-Rama, one of Hugo House’s most popular events, takes place on June 4th from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., featuring classes from more than 30 Hugo House writing teachers, including Two Pens.
Two Pens will donate a class on Twitter tweets for this annual Hugo House fundraiser. You’ll learn to get noticed in 140-characters or less and build your social media reputation at Re-Tweet After Me, slated for 4 p.m.
Peruse the <a href="http://www.hugohouse.org/content/write-o-rama" target="_blank">schedule</a> and <a href="https://co.clickandpledge.com/advanced/default.aspx?wid=38432" target="_blank">register</a> for Write-O-Rama soon.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>$50 Four O&#039;Clock: Re-Tweet After Me</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/50-four-oclock-re-tweet-after-me/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 May 2011 16:55:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1304</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Don’t get Twitter? Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream? In this class, you’ll learn Twitter basics—its lingo, tools, and how to write tweets to huge followings. We’ll give you writing prompts that will help you join the conversation and learn how to get re-tweeted. As models, we’ll share great tweets from elite tweeters who have built their reputations in 140 characters or less.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Grow Your Following: Writing for Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/attract-followers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 May 2011 16:57:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1305</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? Attend our Grow Your Following class at the School of Visual Concepts. This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/grow-your-following/" target="_blank">More Info</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Creative Nonfiction for Grantwriters</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/creative-nonfiction-for-grantwriters/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 May 2011 16:59:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1307</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ask anyone to define what a "grantwriter" does, and you'll find that most of the emphasis is on the "grant" part—i.e., researching the funders, defining the need, identifying the goals and objectives, describing the activities, and outlining the evaluation process. Our Two Pens’ grantwriting class assumes you already know that stuff is important, and you know how to find the information you need. This class is going to focus on the "writer" part of the equation, instead. We're going to send our inner reference librarian on vacation for a few hours and give our inner best-selling author a chance to shine.

Activities will include group discussions, writing exercises, and sharing your work with your peers. After a short introduction to the basic literary elements—plot, character, conflict, setting, etc.-- we'll spend our time thinking about, talking about and practicing creative ways to apply them to actual grants.

I'll provide some imaginary grant scenarios, but please feel free to bring an actual grant you're working on. Bring paper, pen, or laptop and be prepared to write like you're Charles Dickens!

Guest taught by <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/" target="_blank">Alix Wilber</a>.

]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Social Media Content Workshop for Non-Profits </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/a-social-media-content-workshop-for-non-profits/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jun 2011 19:24:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1644</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Social networks are fundamentally changing how non-profits and the communities they serve communicate, collaborate, and learn together. Quickly sharing information across a network contributes to successful advocacy campaigns and fundraising. Listening to the online conversation helps identify the latest trends and takes advantage of just-breaking information. Using networks to direct people to services or in-depth information helps organizations deliver on their promises.

But building a useful social network requires more than just putting up a Facebook page, opening a Twitter account, or even designing a great strategy. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook. We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing writing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever-widening audience. During the first hour, we’ll provide examples and analyze the strategies of non-profits who are successfully using social media. Then we’ll teach you how to write blog posts that get shared, tweets that attract followers, and Facebook status updates that build credibility and grow a fan base.  
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/social-media-content-workshop-for-non-profits/">More Info</a>

&nbsp;

<strong>
</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Non-Profit Blogger Super Stars</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/non-profit-blogger-super-stars/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 09 Aug 2011 06:20:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1845</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What can your organization learn from some of the most talented bloggers writing for non-profits and causes today? Three non-profit star bloggers will show you how content quality can help build a social media presence and a community, two key ingredients for advocacy campaigns and delivering services.

Guest taught by bloggers <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/"target="_blank">Carla Saulter</a> and <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/" target="_blank">Lauren Braden</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1845</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-08 23:20:48</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-09 06:20:48</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>non-profit-blogger-super-stars</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>sp_events</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="sp_events_cat" nicename="non-profit"><![CDATA[Non-Profit]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_EventShowMapLink</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[true]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_EventShowMap</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1846</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1846</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Grow your fan base and become a social media thought leader. Writing tweets to attract followers and status updates to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. And these days, many agents and editors expect you to know how. Building an online audience makes it more likely they’ll take a look at your manuscript. How can you create an online following? During the first hour, we’ll provide examples of writers who have, along with social media strategies that work. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook. We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever-widening audience.
Read More]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing to Think</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1853</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 09 Aug 2011 06:01:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1853</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you find yourself ruminating, cogitating and chewing the end of a pen while staring into blankness. This course will teach you how to let the pen do the thinking while you sit back and play. Bring a nettlesome problem to class: something you don’t understand, an issue you’re trying to solve, something that interests or bugs you, or simply a question whose answer eludes you. Through a series of writing prompts, you’ll learn how to follow the pen’s meanderings across the page and make meaning where you thought chaos reigned. This class is a blast. It involves a lot of writing, but the environment is low-stress and low stakes, i.e., no pressure. You’ll walk out of this class with new confidence in your writing and a tool to get at what you already know that’s buried in the rubble of your brain.
<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/writing-to-think/"target="_blank">More Information</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO for Non-Profits  </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-content-for-social-media-and-seo-for-non-profits-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 09 Aug 2011 06:40:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1854</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Social networks are fundamentally changing how non-profits and the communities they serve communicate, collaborate, and learn together. Quickly sharing information across a network contributes to successful advocacy campaigns and fundraising. Listening to the online conversation helps identify the latest trends and takes advantage of just-breaking information. Using networks to direct people to services or in-depth information helps organizations deliver on their promises.

Co-taught with SEO master <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/"target="_blank">Dan Gayle</a>.

<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/social-media-content-workshop-for-non-profits/"target="_blank">More Information</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Social Media Content</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2029</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Aug 2011 22:07:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2029</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences. <!--more More Information-->Some of the topics we’ll cover:
&nbsp;
	<li>The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels</li>
	<li>How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can</li>
	<li>How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared</li>
	<li>Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite</li>
	<li>Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear</li>
	<li>Understand the tricks of writing for “findability” so your communications call out to the search engines</li>
	<li>How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</li>
&nbsp;

]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2029</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-26 15:07:34</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-26 22:07:34</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>writing-social-media-content</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>sp_events</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="sp_events_cat" nicename="social-media-and-seo"><![CDATA[Social Media and SEO]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_EventShowMapLink</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[true]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_EventShowMap</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Grow Your Following: Writing for Social Media (at SVC)</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2591</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2591</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than merely use social media as a one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you the successful strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate them. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe, supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get retweeted, and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Creative Briefs</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/creative-briefs/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 25 Nov 2012 13:00:27 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you wonder why assignments to creative people often run amok? Build the sturdy box called a creative brief to corral wild and woolly writers and art directors so they can deliver on-target work. Boil down the key selling proposition—what you most want to convey—into a single message. Creatives will kiss your feet, and you’ll be able to lay down your sword.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing Content for Social Media and SEO </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-contentfor-social-media-and-seo/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Aug 2011 01:35:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1847</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Grow your fan base and become a social media thought leader.  Writing tweets to attract followers and status updates to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. Building an online audience makes it more likely they’ll take a look at your manuscript. How can you create an online following? During the first hour, we’ll provide examples of writers who have, along with social media strategies that work. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook. We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever-widening audience.

Taught by the two pens, <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Emily Warn</a> and <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Cynthia Hartwig</a>

<a href="http://twopens.com/courses/attract-followers-grow-your-fan-base-become-a-social-media-star/">More Information</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tell Your Story in Words &amp; Pictures</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/tell-your-story-in-words-and-pictures-hugo-house/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Aug 2011 00:40:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1928</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Building an author identity is essential to building a writing career. What trips up many writers is not the paucity, but the plethora, of things that could define your brand. Working with a branding expert, you’ll start by looking at yourself the way marketers do; draft an author’s statement; and create a marketing strategy. Then, you’ll switch from words to pictures and learn how to make them work together. You’ll identify strong imagery; pick a graphic style that conveys your personality; and working with a great photographer, you’ll shoot an environmental portrait of yourself you’ll be proud to show off.

Join us for this amazing class at the <a href="http://www.hugohouse.org/"target="_blank">Hugo House</a>, co-taught by <a href="http://twopens.com/about/"target="_blank">Cynthia Hartwig</a> and talented guest photographer <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/"target="_blank">Iris Taboh</a>.

]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>tell-your-story-in-words-and-pictures-hugo-house</wp:post_name>

		<category domain="sp_events_cat" nicename="build-your-brand"><![CDATA[Build Your Brand]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Tell Your Story in Words &amp; Pictures</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/tell-your-story-in-words-and-pictures/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Aug 2011 00:54:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1931</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Building an author identity is essential to building a writing career. What trips up many writers is not the paucity, but the plethora, of things that could define your brand. Working with a branding expert, you’ll start by looking at yourself the way marketers do; draft an author’s statement; and create a marketing strategy. Then, you’ll switch from words to pictures and learn how to make them work together. You’ll identify strong imagery; pick a graphic style that conveys your personality; and working with a great photographer, you’ll shoot an environmental portrait of yourself you’ll be proud to show off.

Co-taught by the two pens, <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Emily Warn</a> and <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Cynthia Hartwig</a>, and talented guest photographer <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/">Iris Taboh</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Attract A Social Media Following: For Writers</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/attract-a-social-media-following-for-writers/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Aug 2011 01:17:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=1934</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. And these days, many agents and editors expect you to know how.  Building an online audience makes it more likely they’ll take a look at your manuscript. How can you create an online following?  During the first hour, we’ll provide examples of writers who have and social media strategies that work. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook.  We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever widening audience. 

Join <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Emily Warn</a> and <a href="http://twopens.com/about/">Cynthia Hartwig</a> at the <a href="http://www.hugohouse.org/">Hugo House</a> to learn social media strategies that work.

]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Creating a Powerful Brand via Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/creating-a-powerful-brand-via-social-media/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Aug 2011 20:22:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2031</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Creating an identity is essential to building a successful social media presence. What trips up most people is not the paucity, but the plethora, of things that could define your online brand. During the morning half of this class, you’ll write with Cynthia Hartwig, a branding expert, to define your identity in words. You’ll start by looking at yourself the way marketers do; draft an elevator statement; and create a mini-editorial calendar to add focus to what and when you post, whether on your web site, in a blog, or on Facebook and Twitter. In the afternoon, you’ll switch from words to pictures and work with Iris Taboh, graphic designer and photographer extraordinare and Cynthia Hartwig  to learn how to make them work together. You'll practice identifying strong imagery; ways in which gestures and expressions reveal the character of a person; and how a subject’s personality can be revealed through portraiture. iris will demonstrate how to set up an environmental portrait you’ll be proud to show off.

Recommended for people who want to use social media to build their careers.

Co-Taught by <a href="http://twopens.com/about/"target="_blank">Cynthia Hartwig</a> and <a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/"target="_blank">Iris Taboh</a>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>In-House Seminar at Daimler Trucks North America</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/daimler-benz-in-house-seminar/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Aug 2011 23:05:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>emilyw</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2034</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Two Pens is teaching an in-house seminar in North Carolina for Daimler Trucks this September.  This custom tailored seminar focuses on email effectiveness, retooling powerpoint and writing to think.

Two Pens frequently presents on-site writing seminars to corporations and small businesses as well as not-for-profit organizations and foundations. <strong>We are happy to arrange a session for your company</strong>.  <!--more More Information-->

We like to meet with you before we schedule a training so that we can better understand the problems or issues you’d like us to address. We’ll come back to you with a proposal for a workshop that’s tailored to your industry and your people.

We typically book half-day or full-day sessions, but can teach shorter, multiple-day sessions if you are in the Seattle-Tacoma area.
Seminar prices are based on the number of people attending. We prefer to limit class size to 15 so that everyone receives personal attention. Travel and expenses are billed net; 50% of the seminar fee is due two weeks prior to the event.

All topics related to writing from both sides of the brain are fair game for in-house seminars. Large corporations consistently book classes on Effective Email Writing and The PowerPoint Make-Over. How to Write a Creative Brief is popular with in-house creative groups. And small business owners often ask for Branding 101 and Attracting a Social Media Following. We can provide you with a full list of possible classes. Just email cynthia@twopens.com and we’ll be happy to provide you with more details.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Two Pens to Teach “Re-Tweet After Me” at Hugo House’s Write-O-Rama</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/two-pens-to-teach-%e2%80%9cre-tweet-after-me%e2%80%9d-at-hugo-house%e2%80%99s-write-o-rama/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov 2011 04:23:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2546</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sign up for a dizzying day of genre hopping and support Hugo House at the same time. This popular semi-annual Write-O-Rama fundraiser takes place December 3rd from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hugo House’s writing teachers will offer more than 30 one-hour workshops. And Emily Warn will represent Two Pens by teaching Re-Tweet After Me by popular demand at both 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. Now’s your chance to learn how to use Twitter to build an author platform!
<!--more-->
<strong>Class Description:</strong>
Don’t get Twitter? Do you want to create a Twitter following but feel overwhelmed by its always-on information stream? In this class, you’ll learn Twitter basics—its lingo, tools, and how to write tweets to huge followings. We’ll give you writing prompts that will help you join the conversation and learn how to get re-tweeted. As models, we’ll share great tweets from elite tweeters who have built their reputations in 140 characters or less.
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>In-House Workshop—Global Washington</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/in-house-workshop%e2%80%94global-washington/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Dec 2011 23:22:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2567</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Two Pens is teaching an in-house seminar for Global Washington on December 9. Global Washington is a broad-based membership association that promotes and supports the global development sector in the state of Washington. This custom workshop focuses on showing nonprofits how to write social media content that helps them grow their community and succeed in their advocacy efforts. 
<!--more-->
Two Pens frequently presents on-site writing seminars to corporations and small businesses as well as not-for-profit organizations and foundations. <strong>We are happy to arrange a session for your company. </strong>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Learn Social Media from Two Non Profit Success Stories </title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/learn-social-media-2012-01-19/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 03 Dec 2011 03:51:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2569</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s easy to start a blog and open a Facebook or Twitter account, but how can your organization use social media to build a community for your nonprofit or cause? In this class, you’ll learn how to grow your following from two of the most successful bloggers writing for nonprofits and causes in Seattle. Carla Saulter, aka Buschick, started her transportation blog as a hobby, became a sought-after transit authority, and now works full time in the field. Lauren Braden built a Twitter following of more than 13,000 people for Washington Trails Association, where she is the communications director. They’ll share their stories and offer writing exercises and social network mapping exercises to get you going.
<!--more-->
<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-283" title="spacer" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/spacer.jpg" alt="" width="1" height="20" />
<strong>Guest Bloggers:</strong>
<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">
<a href="http://twopens.com/class/learn-social-media-2012-01-19/carla-saulter-5/" rel="attachment wp-att-2575"><img src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/12/trans_carla22-150x150.jpg" alt="" title="Carla Saulter" width="150" height="150" class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2575" /></a><a href="http://www.buschick.com/" target="_blank">Carla Saulter</a>
Carla Saulter has been living without a car-and using public transit as her primary form of transportation-since March of 2003. Though she gave up driving because of concerns about the detrimental effects of car culture (pollution, traffic, sprawl), the decision has profoundly and positively changed her life. Some of these positive changes include: enforced exercise, time to read, reduced expenses, and contact with her community on a level that would never have been possible in the isolated bubble of a single-occupancy vehicle.</div>
<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

<a href="http://twopens.com/about/two-pens-team/lauren-wta-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-1870"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-1870" title="lauren WTA" src="http://twopens.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/lauren-WTA-150x150.jpg" alt="Lauren Branden" width="150" height="150" /></a><a href="http://twitter.com/#!/WTA_hikers" target="_blank">Lauren Braden</a>
Given her passion for hiking trails, Lauren jumped at the chance to join the staff at Washington Trails Association as the Communications and Outreach Director in 2003. Lauren coordinates WTA’s media relations, messaging, program communications, and publicity. Lauren enjoys hiking, gardening, birdwatching, and traveling with her husband and son, and runs a travel blog in her spare time. Her favorite areas to hike are North Cascades National Park, Marmot Pass, Umtanum Canyon, and anywhere with lots of Ponderosa Pine.

</div>

]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New Media for New (and Old) Authors and Writers</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/new-media-for-authors-and-writers-20120301/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 03 Dec 2011 04:04:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2576</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Cynthia Hartwig, along with other Northwest panelists, addresses the tangled web that writers must now weave on social media. What do writers need to know about blogging, tweeting, Facebook connecting, LibraryThing, <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/" target="_blank">Goodreads.com</a>, YouTube, SheWrites, <a href="http://www.amazon.com/" target="_blank">Amazon.com</a>, etc.? What is essential? What is too much? What about that book trailer? What considerations and issues should we authors and writers reflect on as we negotiate these new ways of connecting and communicating? Is ignoring all this an option? What is the down side?  Other writers appearing with Cynthia include Priscilla Long, Rebecca Agiewich, Matt Briggs, and Waverly Fitzgerald.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2576</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>new-media-for-authors-and-writers-20120301</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>On Being a Jewish Poet: Writing and Identity</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/being-a-jewish-poet-20120301/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Dec 2011 16:18:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2584</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Emily Warn along with five other poets ask what does it mean to be a Jewish poet in the 21st century. What is a Jewish poem? Some Jewish poets resist a fixed Jewish identity. Jewishness for C. Bernstein is “a practice of dialogue... an openness to the unfolding performance of the everyday.” Others write poetry rooted in Jewish tradition. M.L. Rosenthal writes, “A Jewish poem is a poem written by a Jew.” Marina Tsvetaeva goes so far as to say, “Every poet is a Jew.” Five Jewish poets discuss how poetry relates to identity. Other poets on the panel are Patty Seyburn, Jacqueline Osherow, Richard Chess, and Yehoshua November
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tribute to Carolyn Kizer</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/tribute-to-carolyn-kizer-2012030/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Dec 2011 16:21:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Anna Pepper</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2587</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Emily Warn along with poets Kevin Craft and David Rigsbee will discuss Carolyn Kizer’s work and significance to American poetry. Kizer has combined private lyricism with a Confucian sense of public responsibility. At a time when it was unfashionable to proclaim oneself feminist or political, Kizer proudly proclaimed herself both. Founding editor of Poetry Northwest and first Literary Director for the National Endowment for the Arts, legendary teacher Kizer has produced a moving body of work that dazzles with clarity and passion.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Grow Your Following: Writing for Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-for-social-media-2012032/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Jan 2012 04:37:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2590</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences. Some of the topics we’ll cover:
<ul>
	<li>The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels</li>
	<li>How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can</li>
	<li>How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared</li>
	<li>Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite</li>
	<li>Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear</li>
	<li>Understand the tricks of writing for “findability” so your communications call out to the search engines</li>
	<li>How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Grow Your Following (at Hugo House)</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/grow-your-following/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Feb 2012 04:11:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=2840</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets to attract followers and status reports to grow a fan base is not as easy as it looks. And these days, many agents and editors expect you to know how.  Building an online audience makes it more likely they’ll take a look at your manuscript. How can you create an online following?  During the first hour, we’ll provide examples of writers who have and social media strategies that work. Every strategy succeeds or fails based on whether other people share your content across blogs, Twitter, and Facebook.  We’ll spend an hour on each social media space, providing exercises that teach you how to tailor content that reaches an ever widening audience.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How to Rock a Presentation</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/how-to-rock-a-presentation/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 13 Mar 2012 05:48:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=3398</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Description</strong>
Having trouble wowing your audience and selling your ideas? It’s not enough to learn a few PowerPoint basics and call it good. You need to figure out how to create a conversation and get the audience engaged with your material. Cynthia Hartwig, veteran of thousands of advertising presentations and a frequent national speaker, will lead you through an inspiring day of exercises designed to move you away from one way (and dead end) presenting. You’ll learn how to use a whiteboard, how to mind map and work with other brainstorming exercises to wake up your listeners. You’ll practice storytelling and use your own personal experiences to get an audience on your side. You’ll master pushing the Great Bugaboo of Nervousness behind you.  And yes, you’ll get a tutorial on how to use PowerPoint without looking like a tool.  Guarantee: You’ll never think about presenting in the same way.

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
Anyone who needs to increase your authority and power in front of a group, improve your ability to persuade people and make yourself look great in front of your boss.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
