	<item>
		<title>Writing for Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-for-social-media/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Apr 2012 13:44:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=3531</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.  Some of the topics we’ll cover:

<ul>
	<li>The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels</li>
	<li>How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can</li>
	<li>How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared</li>
	<li>Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite</li>
	<li>Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear</li>
	<li>Understand the tricks of writing for “findability” so your communications call out to the search engines</li>
	<li>How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Writing for Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-for-social-media-july-25-201/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2012 04:03:08 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you’re writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.  Some of the topics we’ll cover:
<ul>
	<li>The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels</li>
	<li>How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can</li>
	<li>How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared</li>
	<li>Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite</li>
	<li>Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear</li>
	<li>Understand the tricks of writing for “findability” so your communications call out to the search engines</li>
	<li>How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to Rock a Presentation</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/how-to-rock-a-presentation-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 05:29:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=3819</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Description</strong>
Having trouble wowing your audience and selling your ideas? It’s not enough to learn a few PowerPoint basics and call it good. You need to figure out how to create a conversation and get the audience engaged with your material. Cynthia Hartwig, veteran of thousands of advertising presentations and a frequent national speaker, will lead you through an inspiring day of exercises designed to move you away from one way (and dead end) presenting. You’ll learn how to use a whiteboard, how to mind map and work with other brainstorming exercises to wake up your listeners. You’ll practice storytelling and use your own personal experiences to get an audience on your side. You’ll master pushing the Great Bugaboo of Nervousness behind you. And yes, you’ll get a tutorial on how to use PowerPoint without looking like a tool.  Guarantee: You’ll never think about presenting in the same way.

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
Anyone who needs to increase your authority and power in front of a group, improve your ability to persuade people and make yourself look great in front of your boss.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3819</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-06-12 22:29:49</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-06-13 05:29:49</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>how-to-rock-a-presentation-2</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_type>sp_events</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Evaluating (and Encouraging Better) Creative Work</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/evaluating-and-encouraging-better-creative-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 05:37:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=3820</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Description</strong>
Being a client is one of the toughest jobs in the world. You’re often faced with having to make quick judgments about creative concepts and the fine points of writing and design, even though you’re admittedly no expert on creativity, writing, or design.

The second hardest job is being a creative director or supervisor put in the same evaluator role. You’re probably a capable designer or writer yourself, but that’s a far different task than giving useful critical feedback.

Whichever of these two boats you’re in, you’ll find this workshop to be worth its weight in antacids for the grief it will help you avoid at the time of creative decision-making. Here are a few of the topics we’ll cover:

<ul>
	<li>Setting the stage for getting the very best work out of your creative teams</li>
	<li>The importance of a well-crafted creative brief, and how to use one to assess creative concepts against your business goals</li>
	<li>Approaching a concept from the audience’s perspective, rather than your own (or your boss’s)</li>
	<li>The art of giving clear, precise, unemotional feedback, and the necessity of giving exuberant, emotional praise</li>
	<li>Why telling your creative team to start over isn’t the worst thing in the world</li>
</ul>

Since this is a workshop—not a seven-hour lecture—we’ll do lots of role-playing and have many opportunities to review work.

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
This workshop is for anyone put in the position of critiquing and approving creative work, whether you’re on the client side or a supervisor within a creative services company.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3820</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>How to Rock a Presentation</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/how-rock-presentation/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Aug 2012 21:18:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=4005</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Having trouble wowing your audience and selling your ideas? It’s not enough to learn a few PowerPoint basics and call it good. You need to figure out how to create a conversation and get the audience engaged with your material. Cynthia Hartwig, veteran of thousands of advertising presentations and a frequent national speaker, will lead you through an inspiring day of exercises designed to move you away from one way (and dead end) presenting. You’ll learn how to use a whiteboard, how to mind map and work with other brainstorming exercises to wake up your listeners. You’ll practice storytelling and use your own personal experiences to get an audience on your side. You’ll master pushing the Great Bugaboo of Nervousness behind you. And yes, you’ll get a tutorial on how to use PowerPoint without looking like a tool.  Guarantee: You’ll never think about presenting in the same way.

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
Anyone who needs to increase your authority and power in front of a group, improve your ability to persuade people and make yourself look great in front of your boss.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Evaluating (and Encouraging Better) Creative Work</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/evaluating-and-encouraging-better-creative-work-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Aug 2012 21:28:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=4006</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Being a client is one of the toughest jobs in the world. You’re often faced with having to make quick judgments about creative concepts and the fine points of writing and design, even though you’re admittedly no expert on creativity, writing, or design.

The second hardest job is being a creative director or supervisor put in the same evaluator role. You’re probably a capable designer or writer yourself, but that’s a far different task than giving useful critical feedback.

Whichever of these two boats you’re in, you’ll find this workshop to be worth its weight in antacids for the grief it will help you avoid at the time of creative decision-making. Here are a few of the topics we’ll cover:

<ul>
	<li>Setting the stage for getting the very best work out of your creative teams</li>
	<li>The importance of a well-crafted creative brief, and how to use one to assess creative concepts against your business goals</li>
	<li>Approaching a concept from the audience’s perspective, rather than your own (or your boss’s)</li>
	<li>The art of giving clear, precise, unemotional feedback, and the necessity of giving exuberant, emotional praise</li>
	<li>Why telling your creative team to start over isn’t the worst thing in the world</li>
</ul>

Since this is a workshop—not a seven-hour lecture—we’ll do lots of role-playing and have many opportunities to review work.

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
This workshop is for anyone put in the position of critiquing and approving creative work, whether you’re on the client side or a supervisor within a creative services company.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Writing for Social Media</title>
		<link>http://twopens.com/class/writing-social-media/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Aug 2012 21:37:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>tomboo</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://twopens.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=4007</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Writing tweets, blog posts, and Facebook status updates to attract followers is not as easy as it looks. How can you join the online conversation rather than use it as another one-to-many marketing channel? This course will show you successful social media strategies of social media stars and challenge you to emulate the kind of content that made them happen. This is a pen-to-paper class, all about creating the kind of content readers want to follow. You’ll do exercises designed to help you create an authentic social media identity. You’ll also identify who you are writing to and brainstorm possible topics. Working with writing prompts in a safe, supportive environment, you’ll draft starter posts, tweets that get re-tweeted and Facebook attention-getters. You’ll learn how to tailor content to each social media space so that it breaks away to reach ever-widening audiences.  Some of the topics we’ll cover:

<ul>
<li>The basics of web and social media you need to understand in order to create for those channels</li>
<li>How to identify your personal brand and create an authentic identity no one else can</li>
<li>How to come up with blog topics and interesting posts that get shared</li>
<li>Identifying role models like Andy Borowitz and Sarah Silverman so you can tweet with the elite</li>
<li>Learning where the intersection is between what you want to say and what the reader wants to hear</li>
<li>Understand the tricks of writing for findability, so your communications call out to the search engines</li> 
<li>How to use emotion, whether in anger, sadness or joy, to make your content sing</li>
</ul>

<strong>Who should take this class?</strong>
This workshop is for anyone who writes for social media whether to build their personal brand, or on behalf of an organization or company.]]></content:encoded>
